entry.note: The name (aitch) is from the French ache; its form is from the Latin, and this from the Greek H, which was used as the sign of the spiritus asper (rough breathing) before it came to represent the long vowel, Gr. η. The Greek H is from Phœnician, the ultimate origin probably being Egyptian. Etymologically H is most closely related to c; as in E. horn, L. cornu, Gr. ke`ras; E. hele, v. t., conceal; E. hide, L. cutis, Gr. ky`tos; E. hundred, L. centum, Gr. "e-kat-on, Skr. �ata.

cs.cd: the part of a plunger pump which contains the valve.

entry.def: the eighth letter of the English alphabet, is classed among the consonants, and is formed with the mouth organs in the same position as that of the succeeding vowel. It is used with certain consonants to form digraphs representing sounds which are not found in the alphabet, as shth�, as in shallthing�inefor zh see §274); also, to modify the sounds of some other letters, as when placed after c and p, with the former of which it represents a compound sound like that of tsh, as in charmwritten also tch as in catch), with the latter, the sound of f, as in phasephantom. In some words, mostly derived or introduced from foreign languages, h following c and g indicates that those consonants have the hard sound before ei, and y, as in chemistry chiromancy chyle Ghent Ghibelline, etc.; in some others, ch has the sound of sh, as in chicane. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 153, 179, 181-3, 237-8.

entries.entry: H hä. Mus The seventh degree in the diatonic scale, being used by the Germans for B natural. See B.

entry.def: The chemical formula for water.

An exclamation denoting surprise, joy, or grief. Both as uttered and as written, it expresses a great variety of emotions, determined by the tone or the context. When repeated, ha, ha, it is an expression of laughter, satisfaction, or triumph, sometimes of derisive laughter; or sometimes it is equivalent to “Well, it is so.”
entry.q: Ha-has, and inarticulate hootings of satirical rebuke.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. & Sw. haf the sea, Dan. hav, perh. akin to E. haven
entry.def: The deep-sea fishing for cod, ling, and tusk, off the Shetland Isles.
A sea fish. See Hake.
A fog; esp., a fog or mist with a chill wind.

entries.entry: ‖Ha"be*as cor"pus hā"b�*ăs kôr"pŭs. L. you may have the body Law A writ having for its object to bring a party before a court or judge; especially, one to inquire into the cause of a person's imprisonment or detention by another, with the view to protect the right to personal liberty; also, one to bring a prisoner into court to testify in a pending trial.

entry.def: That part of a deed which follows the part called the premises, and determines the extent of the interest or estate granted; -- so called because it begins with the word Habendum.
To deal in small wares.
entry.q: To haberdash in earth's base ware.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Icel. hapurtask trumpery, trifles, perh. through French. It is possibly akin to E. haversack, and to Icel. taska trunk, chest, pocket, G. tasche pocket, and the orig. sense was perh., peddler's wares

sn.def: A dealer in small wares, as tapes, pins, needles, and thread.
A dealer in items of men's clothing, such as hats, gloves, neckties, etc.
sn.q: The haberdasher heapeth wealth by hats.

sn.def: A dealer in drapery goods of various descriptions, as laces, silks, trimmings, etc.

entry.def: The goods and wares sold by a haberdasher; also Fig, trifles.

entry.ety: D. abberdaan labberdaan; or a French form, cf. OF. habordeau, from the name of a Basque district, cf. F. Labourd, adj. Labourdin. The l was misunderstood as the French article
entry.def: A cod salted and dried.

entry.ety: F. haubergeon a small hauberk, dim. of OF. hauberc, F. haubert. See Hauberk
entry.def: Properly, a short hauberk, but often used loosely for the hauberk.
A genus of chiefly terrestrial orchids with tubers or fleshy roots often having long slender spurs and petals and lip lobes; it includes species formerly placed in the genus Gymnadeniopsis.
Of or pertaining to clothing; wearing clothes.

entry.ety: F. habile, L. habilis. See Able Habit
entry.def: Fit; qualified; also, apt.

entry.ety: F. habillement, fr. habiller to dress, clothe, orig., to make fit, make ready, fr. habile apt, skillful, L. habilis. See Habile

sn.def: A garment; an article of clothing.
Dress, in general.

entry.def: Clothed.

entry.ety: LL. habilitatus, p. p. of habilitare to enable
entry.def: Qualified or entitled.
To fit out; to equip; to qualify; to entitle.
Equipment; qualification.
Ability; aptitude.

entry.usage: Habit Custom. Habit is a disposition or tendency leading us to do easily, naturally, and with growing certainty, what we do often; custom is external, being habitual use or the frequent repetition of the same act. The two operate reciprocally on each other. The custom of giving produces a habit of liberality; habits of devotion promote the custom of going to church. Custom also supposes an act of the will, selecting given modes of procedure; habit is a law of our being, a kind of “second nature” which grows up within us.
entry.ety: OE. habit abit, F. habit, fr. L. habitus state, appearance, dress, fr. habere to have, be in a condition; prob. akin to E. have. See Have, and cf. Able Binnacle Debt Due Exhibit Malady.

sn.def: The usual condition or state of a person or thing, either natural or acquired, regarded as something had, possessed, and firmly retained; as, a religious habit; his habit is morose; elms have a spreading habit ; esp., physical temperament or constitution; as, a full habit of body.

entry.sn: Biol The general appearance and manner of life of a living organism. Specifically, the tendency of a plant or animal to grow in a certain way; as, the deciduous habit of certain trees.

sn.def: Fixed or established custom; ordinary course of conduct; practice; usage; hence, prominently, the involuntary tendency or aptitude to perform certain actions which is acquired by their frequent repetition; as, habit is second nature; also, peculiar ways of acting; characteristic forms of behavior.
sn.q: A man of very shy, retired habits.

sn.def: Outward appearance; attire; dress; hence, a garment; esp., a closely fitting garment or dress worn by ladies; as, a riding habit .
sn.q: Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy.
There are, among the statues, several of Venus, in different habits.

sn.def: The distinctive clothing worn commonly by nuns or monks; as, in the late 1900's many orders of nuns discarded their habits and began to dress as ordinary lay women.
sn.syn: Practice; mode; manner; way; custom; fashion.
sn.q: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
He who reigns . . . upheld by old repute, Consent, or custom

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Habited; p. pr. & vb. n. Habiting
entry.ety: OE. habiten to dwell, F. habiter, fr. L. habitare to have frequently, to dwell, intens. fr. habere to have. See Habit n.

sn.def: To inhabit.
sn.q: In thilke places as they [birdshabiten.

sn.def: To dress; to clothe; to array.
sn.q: They habited themselves like those rural deities.

sn.def: To accustom; to habituate.

entry.def: Habitableness.
Capable of being inhabited; that may be inhabited or dwelt in; as, the habitable world.

entry.ety: F. habitacle dwelling place, binnacle, L. habitaculum dwelling place. See Binnacle Habit v.
entry.def: A dwelling place.
Same as Habitant, 2.
entry.q: General Arnold met an emissary . . . sent . . . to ascertain the feelings of the habitans or French yeomanry.

entry.def: Dwelling; abode; residence.
Same as Inhabitancy.

entry.ety: F. habitant. See Habit v. t.

sn.def: An inhabitant; a dweller.
An inhabitant or resident; -- a name applied to and denoting farmers of French descent or origin in Canada, especially in the Province of Quebec; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: The habitants or cultivators of the soil.

entry.ety: L., it dwells, fr. habitare. See Habit v. t.

sn.def: The natural abode, locality or region of an animal or plant.
Place where anything is commonly found.
sn.q: This word has its habitat in Oxfordshire.

sn.def: The act of inhabiting; state of inhabiting or dwelling, or of being inhabited; occupancy.
Place of abode; settled dwelling; residence; house.
sn.q: The Lord . . . blesseth the habitation of the just.

entry.def: A dweller; an inhabitant.

sn.def: Clothed; arrayed; dressed; as, he was habited like a shepherd.
Fixed by habit; accustomed.
sn.q: So habited he was in sobriety.

sn.def: Inhabited.
sn.q: Another world, which is habited by the ghosts of men and women.

entry.ety: Cf. F. habituel, LL. habitualis. See Habit n.

sn.def: Formed or acquired by habit or use.
sn.q: An habitual knowledge of certain rules and maxims.

sn.def: According to habit; established by habit; customary; constant; as, the habitual practice of sin.
sn.q: It is the distinguishing mark of habitual piety to be grateful for the most common and ordinary blessings.
sn.syn: Customary; accustomed; usual; common; wonted; ordinary; regular; familiar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Habituated hȧ*bĭt"�*ā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Habituating hȧ*bĭt"�*ā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. habituatus, p. p. of habituare to bring into a condition or habit of body: cf. F. habituer. See Habit

sn.def: To make accustomed; to accustom; to familiarize.
sn.q: Our English dogs, who were habituated to a colder clime.
Men are first corrupted . . . and next they habituate themselves to their vicious practices.

sn.def: To settle as an inhabitant.

entry.def: Firmly established by custom; formed by habit; habitual.
The act of habituating, or accustoming; the state of being habituated.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. habitudo condition. See Habit

sn.def: Habitual attitude; usual or accustomed state with reference to something else; established or usual relations.
sn.q: The same ideas having immutably the same habitudes one to another.
The verdict of the judges was biased by nothing else than their habitudes of thinking.

sn.def: Habitual association, intercourse, or familiarity.
sn.q: To write well, one must have frequent habitudes with the best company.

sn.def: Habit of body or of action.
sn.q: It is impossible to gain an exact habitude without an infinite number of acts and perpetual practice.

entry.ety: F., p. p. of habituer. See Habituate
entry.def: One who habitually frequents a place; as, an habitué of a theater.
Habitude.
Habitude; mode of life; general appearance.
See Habile.
By chance.

entry.ety: F., fr. hacher to hack. See Hatching
entry.def: A short line used in drawing and engraving, especially in shading and denoting different surfaces, as in map drawing. See Hatching.

entry.ety: Sp., fr. OSp. facienda employment, estate, fr. L. facienda, pl. of faciendum what is to be done, fr. facere to do. See Fact

sn.def: A large estate where work of any kind is done, as agriculture, manufacturing, mining, or raising of animals; a cultivated farm, with a good house, in distinction from a farming establishment with rude huts for herdsmen, etc.; -- a word used in Spanish-American regions.
The main residence of a hacienda{1}.
A frame or grating of various kinds; as, a frame for drying bricks, fish, or cheese; a rack for feeding cattle; a grating in a mill race, etc.
Unburned brick or tile, stacked up for drying.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hacked hăkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Hacking
entry.ety: OE. hakken, AS. haccian; akin to D. hakken, G. hacken, Dan. hakke, Sw. hacka, and perh. to E. hew. Cf. Hew to cut, Haggle

sn.def: To cut irregulary, without skill or definite purpose; to notch; to mangle by repeated strokes of a cutting instrument; as, to hack a post.
sn.q: My sword hacked like a handsaw.

sn.def: Fig.: To mangle in speaking.
To program (a computer) for pleasure or compulsively; especially, to try to defeat the security systems and gain unauthorized access to a computer.
To bear, physically or emotionally; as, he left the job because he couldn't hack the pressure.

entry.def: To kick the shins of (an opposing payer).
To cough faintly and frequently, or in a short, broken manner; as, a hacking cough.

cs.cd: a handsaw having a narrow blade stretched in an iron frame, for cutting metal.

sn.def: A notch; a cut.
An implement for cutting a notch; a large pick used in breaking stone.
A hacking; a catch in speaking; a short, broken cough.
A kick on the shins, or a cut from a kick.
A clever computer program or routine within a program to accomplish an objective in a non-obvious fashion.
A quick and inelegant, though functional solution to a programming problem.
A taxicab.
A horse, hackneyed or let out for common hire; also, a horse used in all kinds of work, or a saddle horse, as distinguished from hunting and carriage horses.
A coach or carriage let for hire; a hackney coach; formerly, a coach with two seats inside facing each other; now, usually a taxicab.
sn.q: On horse, on foot, in hacks and gilded chariots.

sn.def: The driver of a hack; a taxi driver; a hackman.
A bookmaker who hires himself out for any sort of literary work; an overworked man; a drudge.
sn.q: Here lies poor Ned Purdon, from misery freed, Who long was a bookseller's hack.

sn.def: A procuress.

entry.def: To ride or drive as one does with a hack horse; to ride at an ordinary pace, or over the roads, as distinguished from riding across country or in military fashion.

entry.cs: Hack writer a hack; one who writes for hire. “A vulgar hack writer.” Macaulay.
entry.def: Hackneyed; hired; mercenary.

sn.def: To use as a hack; to let out for hire.
To use frequently and indiscriminately, so as to render trite and commonplace.
sn.q: The word “remarkable” has been so hacked of late.

sn.def: To be exposed or offered to common use for hire; to turn prostitute.
To live the life of a drudge or hack.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. jaquima headstall of a halter
entry.def: A halter consisting of a long leather or rope strap and headstall, -- used for leading or tieing a pack animal.
A genus of trees (Celtis) related to the elm, but bearing drupes with scanty, but often edible, pulp. Celtis occidentalis is common in the Eastern United States.
The greater shearwater or hagdon. See Hagdon.
Same as Hagbut.
The chipmunk; also, the chickaree or red squirrel.
A genus of plants with seeds that stick to clothing, including stickseed and some of the beggar's lice.
One who, or that which, hacks.
A cutting instrument for making notches; esp., one used for notching pine trees in collecting turpentine; a hack.
A cart with wooden wheels, drawn by bullocks.
The driver of a taxicab; a hackman.

sn.def: A comb for dressing flax, raw silk, etc.; a hatchel.
Any flimsy substance unspun, as raw silk.
One of the peculiar, long, narrow feathers on the neck of fowls, most noticeable on the cock, -- often used in making artificial flies; hence, any feather so used.
An artificial fly for angling, made of feathers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hackled hăk"k'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Hackling hăk"klĭng

sn.def: To separate, as the coarse part of flax or hemp from the fine, by drawing it through the teeth of a hackle or hatchel.
To tear asunder; to break in pieces.
sn.q: The other divisions of the kingdom being hackled and torn to pieces.

sn.def: Rough or broken, as if hacked.
Having fine, short, and sharp points on the surface; as, the hackly fracture of metallic iron.

entries.entry: Hack"man hăk"m�n n.; pl.Hackmen hăk"m�n. The driver of a hack or carriage for public hire.

entry.def: The American larch (Larix Americana), a coniferous tree with slender deciduous leaves; also, its heavy, close-grained timber. Called also tamarack.

entries.entry:
Hack"ney -n� n.; pl.Hackneys -nĭz. OE. hakeney hakenay; cf. F. haguenée a pacing horse, an ambling nag, OF. also haquenée, Sp. hacanea, OSp. facanea, D. hakkenei, also OF. haque horse, Sp. haca, OSp. faca; perh. akin to E. hack to cut, and nag, and orig. meaning, a jolting horse. Cf. Hack a horse, Nag
A horse for riding or driving; a nag; a pony.
A horse or pony kept for hire.
A carriage kept for hire; a hack; a hackney coach.
A hired drudge; a hireling; a prostitute.

entry.def: Let out for hire; devoted to common use; hence, much used; trite; mean; as, hackney coaches; hackney authors.
entry.q: Hackneytongue.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hackneyed -nĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hackneying

sn.def: To devote to common or frequent use, as a horse or carriage; to wear out in common service; to make trite or commonplace; as, a hackneyed metaphor or quotation.
sn.q: Had I so lavish of my presence been, So common-hackneyed in the eyes of men.

sn.def: To carry in a hackney coach.

entries.entry: Hack"ney*man -măn n.; pl.Hackneymen -mĕn. A man who lets horses and carriages for hire.

entry.def: A bully; a bravo; a ruffian; an assassin.
Same as Acton.

entries.entry:
Had
Had as lief Had rather Had better Had as soon, etc. with a nominative and followed by the infinitive without to, are well established idiomatic forms. The original construction was that of the dative with forms of be, followed by the infinitive. See Had better, under Better.
Gradually the nominative was substituted for the dative, and had for the forms of be. During the process of transition, the nominative with was or were, and the dative with had, are found. hăd imp. & p. p. of Have. OE. had hafde hefde, AS. hæfde
See Have. And lever me is be pore and trewe.And more agreeable to me it is to be poor and true
Him had been lever to be syke.To him it had been preferable to be sick For him was lever have at his bed's head Twenty bookes, clad in black or red, . . . Than robes rich, or fithel, or gay sawtrie. Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
You were best hang yourself.
Me rather had my heart might feel your love Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.
I hadde levere than my scherte, That ye hadde rad his legende, as have I.
I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself.
I had rather be a dog and bay the moon, Than such a Roman.
I had rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God, than to dwell in the tents of wickedness.

entry.def: Heather; heath.
The haddock.

cs.cd: a marine edible fish (Sebastes marinus) of Northern Europe and America. See Rose fish.

entry.ety: OE. hadok haddok, of unknown origin; cf. Ir. codog, Gael. adag, F. hadot
entry.def: A marine food fish (Melanogrammus æglefinus), allied to the cod, inhabiting the northern coasts of Europe and America. It has a dark lateral line and a black spot on each side of the body, just back of the gills. Galled also haddie, and dickie.

entry.note: ☞ The direction of the hade is the direction toward which the fault plane descends from an intersecting vertical line.
entry.ety: Cf. AS. heald inclined, bowed down, G. halde declivity

sn.def: The descent of a hill.
The inclination or deviation from the vertical of any mineral vein.
The deviation of a fault plane from the vertical.

entry.def: To deviate from the vertical; -- said of a vein, fault, or lode.

entry.ety: Gr. "a',dhs "A'idhs; 'a priv. + 'idei^n to see. Cf. Un- Wit
entry.def: The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abode of the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world; the grave.
entry.q: And death and Hades gave up the dead which were in them.
Neither was he left in Hades, nor did his flesh see corruption.
And in Hades he lifted up his eyes, being in torments.

entry.ety: Ar. hajj, fr. hajja to set out, walk, go on a pilgrimage
entry.def: The pilgrimage to Mecca, performed by Mohammedans. It is the duty of Moslems to make a journey to Mecca at least once ina lifetime, or if that is not possible, three journeys to one of the alternate sacred sites.

sn.def: A Mohammedan who has made a pilgrimage to Mecca; -- used among Orientals as a respectful salutation or a title of honor.
A Greek or Armenian who has visited the holy sepulcher at Jerusalem.

entry.def: any elementary particle that interacts strongly with other particles.

Any member of the genus Hadrosaurus or family Hadrosauridae, an extinct family of heavy bipedal partly aquatic dinosaurs with duck-billed skull and webbed feet; of the Upper Cretaceous in North America.
A natural family of extinct reptiles including the duck-billed dinosaurs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "adro`s thick + say^ros lizard
entry.def: An American herbivorous dinosaur of great size, allied to the iguanodon. It is found in the Cretaceous formation.
Literally, this-ness. A scholastic term to express individuality or singleness; as, this book.

entries.entry:
Hæm"a- hĕm"ȧ- or hē"mȧ- Hæm"a*to- hĕm"ȧ*t�- or hē"mȧ*t�- Hæm"o- hĕm"�- or hē"m�-
☞ Words from Gr. a"i^ma are written hema- hemato- hemo-, as well as hæma- hæmato- hæmo-.. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood Combining forms indicating relation or resemblance to blood association with blood; as, hæmapod, hæmatogenesis, hæmoscope.

entry.def: Hematin.

entry.note: ☞ When deprived of oxygen it is colorless, but becomes quickly blue in contact with oxygen, and is then generally called oxyhæmacyanin. A similar blue coloring matter has been detected in small quantity in the blood of other animals and in the bile.
entry.ety: Hæma- + Gr. ky`anos a dark blue substance
entry.def: A substance found in the blood of the octopus, which gives to it its blue color.

entry.ety: Hæma + Gr. ky`tos a hollow vessel + -meter
entry.def: An apparatus for determining the number of corpuscles in a given quantity of blood.
Toward the hæmal side; on the hæmal side of; -- opposed to neurad.
Same as Hemadrometer.
Same as Hemadrometry.
An instrument for registering the velocity of the blood.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
Same as Hemadynamics.
Pertaining to the blood or blood vessels; also, ventral. See Hemal.
A brownish substance sometimes found in the blood, in cases of jaundice.
An hæmapodous animal.
Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the ventral or hemal side, as in vertebrates; -- opposed to neuropodous.
Blood-forming; as, the hæmapoietic function of the spleen.
Same as Hemapophysis.
Same as Hemastatics.
A form of apparatus (somewhat different from the hemadrometer) for measuring the velocity of the blood.
The measurement of the velocity of the blood.
Same as Hematemesis.

cs.cd: a hypothetical acid, supposed to be formed from hemoglobin during its oxidation in the lungs, and to have the power of freeing carbonic acid from the sodium carbonate of the serum.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the blood; sanguine; brownish red.
Same as Hematin.
Same as Hematinometer.
Same as Hematinometric.
Same as Hematite.
Of a blood-red color; crimson; Bot brownish red.
See Hæma-.

One of the very minute, disk-shaped bodies found in blood with the ordinary red corpuscles and white corpuscles; a third kind of blood corpuscle, supposed by some to be an early stage in the development of the red corpuscles; -- called also blood plaque, and blood plate.
The cold-blooded vertebrates. Same as Hematocrya.
Cold-blooded.
Same as Hematocrystallin.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
The origin and development of blood.
The transformation of venous into arterial blood by respiration; hematosis.
Relating to hæmatogenesis.
Originating in the blood.
Same as Hematoglobulin.
Same as Hematoid.
Same as Hematoidin.

A substance formed from the hematin of blood, by removal of the iron through the action of concentrated sulphuric acid. Two like bodies, called respectively hæmatoporphyrin and hæmatolin, are formed in a similar manner.
See Hæmatoin.
The science which treats of the blood. Same as Hematology.

entry.ety: NL.; hæmato- + Gr. ly`sis a loosing, dissolving, fr. ly`ein to loose, dissolve
entry.def: Dissolution of the red blood corpuscles with diminished coagulability of the blood; hæmolysis.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
An instrument for determining the number of blood corpuscles in a given quantity of blood.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + filei^n to love
entry.def: A division of Chiroptera, including the bloodsucking bats. See Vampire.
Same as Hæmatoblast.
Blood formative; -- applied to a substance in early fetal life, which breaks up gradually into blood vessels.
See Hæmatoin.
A vascular sac connected, beneath the brain, in many fishes, with the infundibulum.
A hæmoscope.
Hematin.
Same as Hematosis.
Same as Hematotherma.
Warm-blooded; homoiothermal.
Same as Hemothorax.
The coloring principle of logwood. It is obtained as a yellow crystalline substance, C16H14O6, with a sweetish taste. Formerly called also hematin.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma blood + xy`lon wood
entry.def: A genus of leguminous plants containing but a single species, the Haematoxylon Campechianum or logwood tree, native in Yucatan.

entries.entry: ‖Hæm`a*to*zo"ön -t�*zō"ŏn n.; pl.Hæmatozoa -ȧ. NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + zw^,on animal Zoöl A parasite inhabiting the blood; esp.: Certain species of nematodes of the genus Filaria, sometimes found in the blood of man, the horse, the dog, etc. The trematode, Bilharzia hæmatobia, which infests the inhabitants of Egypt and other parts of Africa, often causing death.

entry.def: Pertaining to the blood; hemal.
Same as Hemin.
See Hæma-.
Same as Hæmachrome.
A body obtained from hemoglobin, by the action of reducing agents in the absence of oxygen.
An apparatus for measuring the amount of hemoglobin in a fluid, by comparing it with a solution of known strength and of normal color.
Same as Hæmacyanin.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma blood + ky`tos hollow vessel + ly`ein to loosen, dissolve
entry.def: See Hæmocytotrypsis.
See Hæmacytometer.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma blood + ky`tos hollow vessel + tri`bein to rub, grind
entry.def: A breaking up of the blood corpuscles, as by pressure, in distinction from solution of the corpuscles, or hæmocytolysis.
Same as Hæmadromograph.

entries.entry: Hæm`o*dro*mom"e*ter -dr�*mŏm"�*tẽr,n. Same as Hemadrometer.

entry.def: Same as Hemadynamics.
Same as Hemoglobin.
Same as Hemochromometer.
A dark brown powder containing iron, prepared by the action of zinc dust as a reducing agent upon the coloring matter of the blood, used medicinally as a hematinic.
See Hematoidin.
Same as Hæmatolysis Hæmatolytic.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
Same as Hemadynamometer.

entry.ety: L. Hæmonia a name of Thessaly, the land of magic
entry.def: A plant described by Milton as “of sovereign use against all enchantments.”
Same as Hæmatoplastic.
Same as Hemorrhoidal.
An instrument devised by Hermann, for regulating and measuring the thickness of a layer of blood for spectroscopic examination.
Same as Hemostatic.
Same as Hæmatachometer.
Same as Hæmatachometry.

entries.entry: Haf häf imp. of Heave . Hove. Obs

entry.ety: Cf. G. haften to cling, stick to, Prov. G., to stop, stammer
entry.def: To stammer; to speak unintelligibly; to prevaricate.

A metallic element of atomic number 72 present together with zirconium to the extent of 1% to 5% in zirconium minerals. It is a poisonous, ductile metal with a brilliant silver luster, has an atomic weight of 178.49, and has a high melting point (2227° C). It is used in nuclear reactors, and incandescent lamps as a scavenger of oxygen and nitrogen. See also norium.

entry.ety: AS. hæft; akin to D. & G. heft, Icel. hepti, and to E. heave, or have. Cf. Heft

sn.def: A handle; that part of an instrument or vessel taken into the hand, and by which it is held and used; -- said chiefly of a knife, sword, or dagger; the hilt.
sn.q: This brandish'd dagger I'll bury to the haft in her fair breast.

sn.def: A dwelling.

entry.def: To set in, or furnish with, a haft; as, to haft a dagger.

entry.ety: Cf. G. haften to cling or stick to, and E. haffle
entry.def: A caviler; a wrangler.

cs.cd: a moth (Phobetron pithecium), the larva of which has curious side appendages, and feeds on fruit trees.
an ugly irregularity in the pattern of matting or pointing.

entry.ety: OE. hagge hegge, witch, hag, AS. hægtesse; akin to OHG. hagazussa, G. hexe, D. heks, Dan. hex, Sw. häxa. The first part of the word is prob. the same as E. haw hedge, and the orig. meaning was perh., wood woman, wild woman. √12

sn.def: A witch, sorceress, or enchantress; also, a wizard.
sn.q: Silenus] that oldhag.

sn.def: An ugly old woman.
A fury; a she-monster.

An eel-like marine marsipobranch (Myxine glutinosa), allied to the lamprey. It has a suctorial mouth, with labial appendages, and a single pair of gill openings. It is the type of the order Hyperotreta. Called also hagfish borer slime eel sucker, and sleepmarken.
The hagdon or shearwater.
An appearance of light and fire on a horse's mane or a man's hair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hagged hăgd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hagging
entry.def: To harass; to weary with vexation.
entry.q: How are superstitious men hagged out of their wits with the fancy of omens.

entry.ety: Scot. hag to cut; cf. E. hack

sn.def: A small wood, or part of a wood or copse, which is marked off or inclosed for felling, or which has been felled.
sn.q: This said, he led me over hoults and hags; Through thorns and bushes scant my legs I drew.

sn.def: A quagmire; mossy ground where peat or turf has been cut.

entry.def: A plant of the genus Prunus Prunus Padus); the bird cherry.
Born of a hag or witch.

entry.ety: OF. haquebute, prob. a corruption of D. haakbus; haak hook + bus gun barrel. See Hook, and 2d Box, and cf. Arquebus
entry.def: A harquebus, of which the but was bent down or hooked for convenience in taking aim.
A soldier armed with a hagbut or arquebus.

One of several species of sea birds of the genus Puffinus; esp., Puffinus major, the greater shearwarter, and Puffinus Stricklandi, the black hagdon or sooty shearwater; -- called also hagdown haglin, and hag. See Shearwater.

entries.entry: Hag"fish` -fĭsh`,n. Zoöl See Hag, 4.

Hag*ga"da hăg*gä"dȧ n.; pl.Haggadoth -dōth. Rabbinic haggādhā, fr. Heb. higgīdh to relate A story, anecdote, or legend in the Talmud, to explain or illustrate the text of the Old Testament.
hagada

entry.ety: F. hagard; of German origin, and prop. meaning, of the hegde or woods, wild, untamed. See Hedge, 1st Haw, and -ard

sn.def: Wild or intractable; disposed to break away from duty; untamed; as, a haggard or refractory hawk.

sn.ety: For hagged, fr. hag a witch, influenced by haggard wild
sn.def: Having the expression of one wasted by want or suffering; hollow-eyed; having the features distorted or wasted by pain; wild and wasted, or anxious in appearance; as, haggard features, eyes.
sn.q: Staring his eyes, and haggard was his look.

sn.def: A young or untrained hawk or falcon.
A fierce, intractable creature.
sn.q: I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.

sn.def: A hag.

entry.ety: See 1st Haw Hedge, and Yard an inclosed space
entry.def: A stackyard.
In a haggard manner.
Like a hag; lean; ugly.

entry.ety: Scot. hag to hack, chop, E. hack. Formed, perhaps, in imitation of the F. hachisE. hash), fr. hacher
entry.def: A Scotch pudding made of the heart, liver, lights, etc., of a sheep or lamb, minced with suet, onions, oatmeal, etc., highly seasoned, and boiled in the stomach of the same animal; minced head and pluck.
Like a hag; ugly; wrinkled.
entry.q: But on us both did haggish age steal on.

entry.def: In the manner of a hag.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Haggled -g'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Haggling -glĭng
entry.ety: Freq. of Scot. hag, E. hack. See Hack to cut
entry.def: To cut roughly or hack; to cut into small pieces; to notch or cut in an unskillful manner; to make rough or mangle by cutting; as, a boy haggles a stick of wood.
entry.q: Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled o'er, Comes to him, where in gore he lay insteeped.

entry.def: To be difficult in bargaining; to stick at small matters; to chaffer; to higgle.
entry.q: Royalty and science never haggled about the value of blood.

entry.def: The act or process of haggling.

sn.def: One who haggles or is difficult in bargaining.
One who forestalls a market; a middleman between producer and dealer in London vegetable markets.

entry.def: A sacred government; government by holy orders of men.

entry.ety: Gr. "a`gios holy, and kratei^n to govern
entry.def: Government by a priesthood; hierarchy.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. "agio`grafasc. bibli`a), fr. "agio`grafos written by inspiration; "a`gios sacred, holy + gra`fein to write

sn.def: The last of the three Jewish divisions of the Old Testament, comprising Psalms, Proverbs, Job, Canticles, Ruth, Lamentations, Ecclesiastes, Esther, Daniel, Ezra, Nehemiah, and Chronicles, or that portion of the Old Testament not contained in the Law (Tora) and the Prophets (Nevi'im) -- it is also called in Hebrew the Ketuvim. Together with the Tora and Nevi'im, it comprises the Hebrew Bible, which is called in Hebrew the Tanach, a vocalization of the first letters of its three parts.
The lives of the saints.

entry.def: Pertaining to the hagiographa, or to sacred writings.
One of the writers of the hagiographa; a writer of lives of the saints.

sn.def: of or pertaining to the Hagiographa, or to sacred writings; -- same as hagiographal.
of or pertaining to hagiography.

entry.def: Same as Hagiographa.
The invocation or worship of saints.
One who treats of the sacred writings; a writer of the lives of the saints; a hagiographer.
entry.q: Hagiologists have related it without scruple.

entry.def: The history or description of the sacred writings or of sacred persons; a narrative of the lives of the saints; a catalogue of saints.
An opening made in the interior walls of a cruciform church to afford a view of the altar to those in the transepts; -- called, in architecture, a squint.
Ridden by a hag or witch;
afflicted with nightmares; tormented or harassed by nightmares or unreasonable fears.
entry.q: hagridden . . . by visions of an imminent heaven or hell upon earth

entry.def: The offspring of a hag.
The state or title of a hag.
The great woolly mullein (Verbascum Thapsus).
See Hagbut.

entries.entry: Hague Tribunal hāg. The permanent court of arbitration created by the “International Convention for the Pacific Settle of International Disputes.”, adopted by the International Peace Conference of 1899. It is composed of persons of known competency in questions of international law, nominated by the signatory powers. From these persons an arbitration tribunal is chosen by the parties to a difference submitted to the court. On the failure of the parties to agree directly on the arbitrators, each chooses two arbitrators, an umpire is selected by them, by a third power, or by two powers selected by the parties.

entry.def: Same as Ha.
A sunk fence; a fence, wall, or ditch, not visible till one is close upon it.
A mineral consisting chiefly of the arseniate of lime; -- so named in honor of W. Haidinger, of Vienna.

entry.ety: G. haiduck heiduck, fr. Hung. hajdu
entry.def: Formerly, a mercenary foot soldier in Hungary, now, a halberdier of a Hungarian noble, or an attendant in German or Hungarian courts.

entry.ety: Ar. hāïk, fr. hāka to weave
entry.def: A large piece of woolen or cotton cloth worn by Arabs as an outer garment.
The central chapel of the three forming the sanctuary of a Coptic church. It contains the high altar, and is usually closed by an embroidered curtain.
Chinese maritime customs.

entries.entry: Haikwan tael. A Chinese weight (1/10 catty) equivalent to 11/3 oz. or 37.801 g.

entry.ety: OE. hail haȝel, AS. hægel hagol; akin to D., G., Dan., & Sw. hagel; Icel. hagl; cf. Gr. ka`chlhx pebble
entry.def: Small roundish masses of ice precipitated from the clouds, where they are formed by the congelation of vapor. The separate masses or grains are called hailstones.
entry.q: Thunder mixed with hail,Hail mixed with fire, must rend the Egyptian sky.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hailed hāld; p. pr. & vb. n. Hailing
entry.def: To pour down particles of ice, or frozen vapors.
To pour forcibly down, as hail.
Healthy. See Halethe preferable spelling).

entry.ety: OE. hailen heilen, Icel. heill hale, sound, used in greeting. See Hale sound

sn.def: To call loudly to, or after; to accost; to salute; to address.
To name; to designate; to call.
sn.q: And such a son as all men hailed me happy.

sn.def: To declare, by hailing, the port from which a vessel sails or where she is registered; hence, to sail; to come; -- used with from; as, the steamer hails from New York.
To report as one's home or the place from whence one comes; to come; -- with from.

entry.cs: All hail. See in the Vocabulary. Hail Mary a form of prayer made use of in the Roman Catholic Church in invocation of the Virgin. See Ave Maria.
entry.def: An exclamation of respectful or reverent salutation, or, occasionally, of familiar greeting.
entry.q: Hail, brave friend.

entry.def: A wish of health; a salutation; a loud call.
entry.q: Their puissanthail.
The angel hail bestowed.

entry.def: An intimate companion.
entry.q: Hail-fellow well met.

entry.ety: OE. hailsen, Icel. heilsa. Cf. Hail to call to
entry.def: To greet; to salute.
Small shot which scatter like hailstones.
A single particle of ice falling from a cloud; a frozen raindrop; a pellet of hail.
A storm accompanied with hail; a shower of hail.
Of hail.
entry.q: Hailyshowers.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. hägn hedge, inclosure, Dan. hegn hedge, fence. See Hedge
entry.def: To inclose for mowing; to set aside for grass.
entry.q: A ground . . .hainedin.

entries.entry:
Hain't hānt. A contraction of have not or has not; as, I hain't, he hain't, we hain't . Colloq. or illiterate speech
han't

entry.note: ☞ Hairs is often used adjectively or in combination; as, hairbrush or hair brush, hair dye, hair oil, hairpin, hair powder, a brush, a dye, etc., for the hair.
entry.cs:
Against the hair in a rough and disagreeable manner; against the grain. Obs “You go against the hair of your professions.” Shak. Hair bracket Ship Carp a molding which comes in at the back of, or runs aft from, the figurehead. Hair cells Anat cells with hairlike processes in the sensory epithelium of certain parts of the internal ear.
Hair compass Hair divider
a compass or divider capable of delicate adjustment by means of a screw. Hair glove a glove of horsehair for rubbing the skin. Hair lace a netted fillet for tying up the hair of the head. Swift. Hair line a line made of hair; a very slender line. Hair moth Zoöl any moth which destroys goods made of hair, esp. Tinea biselliella. Hair pencil a brush or pencil made of fine hair, for painting; -- generally called by the name of the hair used; as, a camel's hair pencil, a sable's hair pencil, etc.
Hair plate an iron plate forming the back of the hearth of a bloomery fire. Hair powder a white perfumed powder, as of flour or starch, formerly much used for sprinkling on the hair of the head, or on wigs. Hair seal Zoöl any one of several species of eared seals which do not produce fur; a sea lion. Hair seating haircloth for seats of chairs, etc. Hair shirt a shirt, or a band for the loins, made of horsehair, and worn as a penance. Hair sieve a strainer with a haircloth bottom. Hair snake. See Gordius. Hair space Printing the thinnest metal space used in lines of type. Hair stroke a delicate stroke in writing. Hair trigger a trigger so constructed as to discharge a firearm by a very slight pressure, as by the touch of a hair. Farrow. Not worth a hair of no value. To a hair with the nicest distinction. To split hairs to make distinctions of useless nicety.
entry.ety: OE. her heer hær, AS. hǣr; akin to OFries. hēr, D. & G. haar, OHG. & Icel. hār, Dan. haar, Sw. hår; cf. Lith. kasa

sn.def: The collection or mass of filaments growing from the skin of an animal, and forming a covering for a part of the head or for any part or the whole of the body.
One the above-mentioned filaments, consisting, in vertebrate animals, of a long, tubular part which is free and flexible, and a bulbous root imbedded in the skin.
sn.q: Then read he me how Sampson lost his hairs.
And draweth new delights with hoary hairs.

sn.def: Hair (human or animal) used for various purposes; as, hair for stuffing cushions.

A slender outgrowth from the chitinous cuticle of insects, spiders, crustaceans, and other invertebrates. Such hairs are totally unlike those of vertebrates in structure, composition, and mode of growth.
An outgrowth of the epidermis, consisting of one or of several cells, whether pointed, hooked, knobbed, or stellated. Internal hairs occur in the flower stalk of the yellow frog lily (Nuphar).
A spring device used in a hair-trigger firearm.
A haircloth.
Any very small distance, or degree; a hairbreadth.

entry.def: a compact mass of hair that forms in the stomach of animals as a result of licking fur; as, the cat coughed up a hairball right on the new rug.
See Harebell.
The chipping sparrow.
See Harebrained.

entries.entry:
Hair"breadth` -brĕdth Hair's" breadth` hârz"- . The diameter or breadth of a hair; a very small distance; sometimes, definitely, the forty-eighth part of an inch.
hairsbreadth
Every one could sling stones at an hairbreadth and not miss.

entry.def: Having the breadth of a hair; very narrow; as, a hairbreadth escape.
Of a clear tint of brown, resembling brown human hair. It is composed of equal proportions of red and green.
A brush for cleansing and smoothing the hair.
Stuff or cloth made wholly or in part of hair.
One who dresses or cuts hair; a barber.
a toiletry for the hair.

sn.def: Having hair.
sn.q: A beasthairedlike a bear.

sn.def: In composition: Having (such) hair; as, red-haired .

entry.def: Hairy.
entry.q: His hairen shirt and his ascetic diet.

entries.entry: Hair" grass` grȧs`. Bot A grass with very slender leaves or branches; as the Agrostis scabra, and several species of Aira or Deschampsia.

sn.def: The state of abounding, or being covered, with hair.
The quality of being hairy.

entry.def: Destitute of hair; bald.

sn.def: shaped like a hair; long and slender.
long and slender with a very fine internal diameter.
a very thin line.
the natural margin formed by hair on the head, especially the edge of growth of hair on the forehead; as, a receding hairline.

entry.def: a small net that some women wear over their hair to keep it in place.
a covering or bunch of human or artificial hair used for disguise or adornment; a toupee.
A pin, usually forked, or of bent wire, for fastening the hair in place, -- used by women.
A variety of native Epsom salt occurring in silky fibers.
One who makes excessively fine or needless distinctions in reasoning; one who quibbles.
entry.q: The cavilinghairsplitter.

entry.def: Making excessively fine or trivial distinctions in reasoning; overly subtle.

def2.def: The act or practice of making trivial distinctions.

entry.q: The ancient hairsplitting technicalities of special pleading.

entry.def: The slender recoil spring which regulates the motion of the balance in a timepiece.
A butterfly of the genus Thecla; as, the green hairstreak Thecla rubi).
Any species of marine fishes of the genus Trichiurus; esp., Trichiurus lepturus of Europe and America. They are long and like a band, with a slender, pointed tail. Called also bladefish.

entries.entry: Hair" worm` wûrm`. Zoöl A nematoid worm of the genus Gordius, resembling a hair. See Gordius.

sn.def: Bearing or covered with hair; made of or resembling hair; rough with hair; hirsute.
sn.q: His mantle hairy, and his bonnet sedge.

sn.def: Very complicated, difficult, or involved; as, a hairy problem; a hairy equation.
Dangerous or frightening; as, a hairy encounter with a mugger.
a country on the island of Hispaniola.
an island in the West Indies.

entry.def: Same as Haytian; -- now the preferred spelling.
A pilgrimage to Mecca; every Muslim must make this journey at least once.
One who has made a journey to Mecca; Same as hadji.

The Egyptian asp or cobra (Naja haje.) It is related to the cobra of India, and like the latter has the power of inflating its neck into a hood. Its bite is very venomous. It is supposed to be the snake by means of whose bite Cleopatra committed suicide, and hence is sometimes called Cleopatra's snake or asp. See Asp.
A drying shed, as for unburned tile.

entry.ety: Akin to Norweg. hakefisk, lit., hook fish, Prov. E. hake hook, G. hecht pike. See Hook
entry.def: One of several species of marine gadoid fishes, of the genera Phycis Merlucius, and allies. The common European hake is Merlucius vulgaris; the American silver hake or whiting is Merlucius bilinearis. Two American species (Phycis chuss and Phycis tenius) are important food fishes, and are also valued for their oil and sounds. Called also squirrel hake, and codling.
To loiter; to sneak.
See Forkbeard.
Same as Acton.
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Mohammedan.
A Mohammedan title for a ruler; a judge.

entries.entry:
Ha*la"cha hȧ*lä"kȧ n.; pl.Halachoth -kōth. Heb. halāchāh
The general term for the Hebrew oral or traditional law; one of two branches of exposition in the Midrash. See Midrash.

entry.def: An appearance as of a halo of light, surrounding the edges of dark objects in a photographic picture.

entry.ety: F. hallebarde; of German origin; cf. MHG. helmbarte, G. hellebarte; prob. orig., an ax to split a helmet, fr. G. barte a broad ax (orig. from the same source as E. beard; cf. Icel. barða, a kind of ax, skegg beard, skeggja a kind of halberd) + helm helmet; but cf. also MHG. helm halm, handle, and E. helve. See Beard Helmet
entry.def: An ancient long-handled weapon, of which the head had a point and several long, sharp edges, curved or straight, and sometimes additional points. The heads were sometimes of very elaborate form.
One who is armed with a halberd.
Hastate.

entry.ety: L. halcyon alcyon, Gr. "alkyw`n 'alkyw`n: cf. F. halcyon
entry.def: A kingfisher. By modern ornithologists restricted to a genus including a limited number of species having omnivorous habits, as the sacred kingfisher (Halcyon sancta) of Australia.
entry.q: Amidst our arms as quiet you shall be As halcyons brooding on a winter sea.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, the halcyon, which was anciently said to lay her eggs in nests on or near the sea during the calm weather about the winter solstice.
Hence: Calm; quiet; peaceful; undisturbed; happy.
sn.q: Deep,halcyonrepose.

entry.def: Halcyon; calm.
See Alcyonoid.

entry.ety: OE. heil, Icel. heill; akin to E. whole. See Whole
entry.def: Sound; entire; healthy; robust; not impaired; as, a hale body.
entry.q: Last year we thought him strong and hale.

entry.def: Welfare.
entry.q: All heedless of his dearest hale.

entries.entry:
Hale hāl or h�l; 277 v. t.
imp. & p. p. Haled hāld or h�ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Haling
OE. halen halien; cf. AS. holian, to acquire, get. See Haul
To pull; to drag; to haul. See Haul. Chaucer. Easier both to freight, and to hale ashore. As some dark priest hales the reluctant victim.

entry.def: A genus of herbs of Eurasia and the Americas: spurred gentians.
A genus of American shrubs containing several species, called snowdrop trees, or silver-bell trees. They have showy, white flowers, drooping on slender pedicels.

entry.note: ☞ The adjective and noun are often united to form a compound.
entry.cs:
Half ape Zoöl a lemur. Half back. Football See under 2d Back. Half bent the first notch, for the sear point to enter, in the tumbler of a gunlock; the halfcock notch. Half binding a style of bookbinding in which only the back and corners are in leather. Half boarder one who boards in part; specifically, a scholar at a boarding school who takes dinner only. Half-breadth plan Shipbuilding a horizontal plan of one half a vessel, divided lengthwise, showing the lines. Half cadence Mus a cadence on the dominant. Half cap a slight salute with the cap. Obs Shak. At half cock the position of the cock of a gun when retained by the first notch.
Half hitch a sailor's knot in a rope; half of a clove hitch. Half hose short stockings; socks. Half measure an imperfect or weak line of action. Half note Mus a minim, one half of a semibreve. Half pay half of the wages or salary; reduced pay; as, an officer on half pay. Half price half the ordinary price; or a price much reduced. Half round. Arch A molding of semicircular section. Mech Having one side flat and the other rounded; -- said of a file. Half shift Mus a position of the hand, between the open position and the first shift, in playing on the violin and kindred instruments. See Shift. Half step Mus a semitone; the smallest difference of pitch or interval, used in music. Half tide the time or state of the tide equally distant from ebb and flood. Half time half the ordinary time for work or attendance; as, the half-time system. Half tint Fine Arts a middle or intermediate tint, as in drawing or painting. See Demitint. Half truth a statement only partially true, or which gives only a part of the truth. Mrs. Browning. Half year the space of six months; one term of a school when there are two terms in a year.
entry.ety: AS. healf half, half; as a noun, half, side, part; akin to OS., OFries., & D. half, G. halb, Sw. half, Dan. halv, Icel. hālfr, Goth. halbs. Cf. Halve Behalf

sn.def: Consisting of a moiety, or half; as, a half bushel; a half hour; a half dollar; a half view.
Consisting of some indefinite portion resembling a half; approximately a half, whether more or less; partial; imperfect; as, a half dream; half knowledge.
sn.q: Assumed from thence a half consent.

entry.def: In an equal part or degree; in some part approximating a half; partially; imperfectly; as, half-colored, half done, half-hearted, half persuaded, half conscious.
entry.q: Half loth and halfconsenting.
Their children spoke halfin the speech of Ashdod.

entries.entry:
Half
Better half. See under Better. In half in two; an expression sometimes used improperly instead of in halves or into halves; as, to cut in half . Colloq Dickens.
In one's halforOn one's half
in one's behalf; on one's part. Obs To cry halves to claim an equal share with another. To go halves to share equally between two.
häf n.; pl.Halves hävz. AS. healf. See Half a.
Part; side; behalf. Obs The four halves of the house.
One of two equal parts into which anything may be divided, or considered as divided; -- sometimes followed by of; as, a half of an apple. Not half his riches known, and yet despised. A friendship so complete Portioned in halves between us.

entry.def: To halve. Obs See Halve.
A mixture of two malt liquors, esp. porter and ale, in about equal parts.
A person who plays the position of halfback{2} on a football team.

sn.def: The position of either of two players on a football team who typically begins each play behind the line and on either side of the quarterback.
Insufficiently or poorly planned or thought out; impractical or unrealistic; as, a half-baked proposal; half-baked ideas; -- of plans, theories, proposals, etc.
Insufficiently cooked; -- of food.

entry.def: Any slender, marine fish of the genus Hemirhamphus, or of the family Hemiramphidae, having an elongated protruding lower jaw; -- called also balahoo.

entries.entry:
Half" blood` ☞ In the 2d and 3d senses usually with a hyphen. häf"blŭd`. The relation between persons born of the same father or of the same mother, but not of both; as, a brother or sister of the half blood . See Blood n., 2 and 4.
A person so related to another.
A person whose father and mother are of different races; a half-breed.

sn.def: Proceeding from a male and female of different breeds or races; having only one parent of good stock; as, a half-blooded sheep.
Degenerate; mean.

entry.def: A boot with a short top covering only the ankle. See Cocker, and Congress boot, under Congress.
Having only the back and corners in leather, as a book.

sn.def: Half-blooded.
Imperfectly acquainted with the rules of good-breeding; not well trained.

entry.def: Half-blooded.
A person who is half-blooded; the offspring of parents of different races, especially of the American Indian and the white race.
A brother by one parent, but not by both.
One born of a European parent on the one side, and of a Hindu or Mohammedan on the other. Also adjective; as, half-caste parents.
Half-filled.
entry.q: Lions' half-clammed entrails roar for food.

entry.cs: To go off half-cocked To go off halfcocked . To be discharged prematurely, or with the trigger at half cock; -- said of a firearm. To do or say something without due thought or care. Colloq. or Low
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Halfcocked -kŏkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Halfcocking
entry.def: To set the cock of (a firearm) at the first notch.
Half-demented; half-witted.

sn.def: A shell of the genus Crepidula; a boat shell. See Boat shell.
See Half deck, under Deck.

entry.def: Partially decked.
entry.q: The half-decked craft . . . used by the latter Vikings.

entry.def: Wanting half its due qualities.

entry.ety: OE. halfendele. See Half, and Deal
entry.def: Half; by the half part.

sn.def: One who possesses or gives half only; one who shares.
A male fallow deer gelded.

entry.def: Showing only part of the face; wretched looking; meager.
A salmon in its fifth year of growth.
Imperfectly hatched; as, half-hatched eggs.
Imperfectly or partly heard; not heard to the end.
entry.q: And leave half-heard the melancholy tale.

sn.def: Wanting in heart or spirit; ungenerous; unkind.
Lacking zeal or courage; performed with less than a full effort; lukewarm; unenthusiastic; as, a half-hearted attempt; -- of actions.

entry.def: a day on which half of the day is free from work or duty; a holiday of one half of a day.
Done or happening at intervals of half an hour.
Imperfectly learned.
Of half the whole or ordinary length, as a picture.

the time it takes for one-half of a substance decaying in a first-order reaction to be destroyed. For radioactive substances, it is the time required for one-half of the initial amount of the radioactive isotope to decay. The half-lifeis a measure of the rate of the reaction being observed. For processes that are true first-order processes, such as radioactive decay, the half-life is independent of the quantity of material present, and it is thus a constant. The time it takes for one-half the remaining quantity of a radioactive isotope to decay will be the same regardless of how far the decay process has advanced. Some chemical reactions are also first order, and may be characterized as having a half-life. However, for chemical reactions the half-life will depend upon temperature and in some cases other environmental conditions, whereas for radioactive isotopes the rate of decay is largely independent of the environment.
a grayish light (as at dawn or dusk or in dim interiors).
A point some distance below the top of a mast or staff; as, a flag a half-masta token of mourning, etc.

sn.def: The moon at the quarters, when half its disk appears illuminated.
The shape of a half-moon; a crescent.
sn.q: See how in warlike muster they appear, In rhombs, and wedges, and half-moons, and wings.

sn.def: An outwork composed of two faces, forming a salient angle whose gorge resembles a half-moon; -- now called a ravelin.
A marine, sparoid, food fish of California (Cæsiosoma Californiense). The body is ovate, blackish above, blue or gray below. Called also medialuna.

entries.entry: Half nelson. Wrestling A hold in which one arm is thrust under the corresponding arm of the opponent, generally behind, and the hand placed upon the back of his neck. In the full nelson both hands are so placed.

entry.def: The quality of being half; incompleteness.
entry.q: As soon as there is any departure from simplicity, and attempt at halfness, or good for me that is not good for him, my neighbor feels the wrong.

entry.note: ☞ This term and quarterpace are rare or unknown in the United States, platform or landing being used instead.
entry.def: A platform of a staircase where the stair turns back in exactly the reverse direction of the lower flight. See Quarterpace.
an English coin worth half a penny; -- no longer minted.

entries.entry:
half"pen*ny half"-pen*ny
hā"pĕn*n� or häf"-; 277 n.;pl.Half-pence -p�ns or Half-pennies -pĕn*nĭz. An English coin of the value of half a penny, no longer minted; also, the value of half a penny. ha'penny.

entry.def: the amount that can be bought for a halfpenny.
A short pike, sometimes carried by officers of infantry, sometimes used in boarding ships; a spontoon.
One half of a shutter made in two parts for closing a porthole.
A straight line considered as drawn from a center to an indefinite distance in one direction, the complete ray being the whole line drawn to an indefinite distance in both directions.
Informed by insufficient reading; superficial; shallow.

entries.entry: Half" seas` o"ver sēz` ō"vẽr. Half drunk. Slang: used only predicatively

entry.def: Seeing imperfectly; having weak discernment.

entry.def: Constructed of a timber frame, having the spaces filled in with masonry; -- said of buildings.
an intermission between the first and second half of a game, especially a football game. Also used attributively, as the halftime entertainment

sn.def: An intermediate or middle tone in a painting, engraving, photograph, etc.; a middle tint, neither very dark nor very light.
A half step.
A print obtained by the half-tone photo-engraving process.
the etched plate used to reproduce a half-tone illustration.

entries.entry: Half"-tone` häf"tōn` a. Having, consisting of, or pertaining to, half tones; specif. Photo-engraving), pertaining to or designating plates, processes, or the pictures made by them, in which gradation of tone in the photograph is reproduced by a graduated system of dotted and checkered spots, usually nearly invisible to the unaided eye, produced by the interposition between the camera and the object of a screen. The name alludes to the fact that this process was the first that was practically successful in reproducing the half tones of the photograph.

entry.def: A jury, for the trial of a foreigner, composed equally of citizens and aliens.
having caterpillar treads on the rear and wheels in front; as, half-track armored vehicles.
a half-tracked vehicle; -- used mostly of armored military vehicles.

entries.entry: half"-truth` häf"tr�th n.; pl.half-truths häf"tr��z)`. a partially true statement, especially one intended to deceive or mislead.

entry.def: In the middle; at half the distance; imperfectly; partially; as, he halfway yielded.
entry.q: Temples proud to meet their gods halfway.

cs.cd: a practice among the Congregational churches of New England, between 1657 and 1662, of permitting baptized persons of moral life and orthodox faith to enjoy all the privileges of church membership, save the partaking of the Lord's Supper. They were also allowed to present their children for baptism.

entry.def: Equally distant from the extremes; situated at an intermediate point; midway; as, at the halfway mark.

sn.def: partial.
including only half or a portion; incomplete; as, halfway measures.
an inn or place of call midway on a journey.

A residence for former convicts, persons recovering from mental illness, or from drug or alcohol addiction, serving as an intermediate environment between total confinement and complete freedom, and having structured programs designed to ease successful reintegration into society.

entry.def: A foolish person; a dolt; a blockhead; a dunce.

Two in a year; semiannual.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "a`ls "alo`s, sea + cho`ndros cartilage

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "a`ls sea + ko`rh maiden

sn.def: Holy doom; the Last Day.

Description of the sea; the science that treats of the sea.

Native salt; sodium chloride.

entry.ety: OE. halle hal, AS. heal heall; akin to D. hal, OS. & OHG. halla, G. halle, Icel. höll, and prob. from a root meaning, to hide, conceal, cover. See Hell Helmet

sn.def: A building or room of considerable size and stateliness, used for public purposes; as, Westminster Hall, in London.

sd.def: The chief room in a castle or manor house, and in early times the only public room, serving as the place of gathering for the lord's family with the retainers and servants, also for cooking and eating. It was often contrasted with the bower, which was the private or sleeping apartment.
sd.q: Full sooty was her bower and eke her hall.
sd.specif: Hence, as the entrance from outside was directly into the hall:

sn.sd: A vestibule, entrance room, etc., in the more elaborated buildings of later times. Hence:

sd.def: Any corridor or passage in a building.

sn.def: A name given to many manor houses because the magistrate's court was held in the hall of his mansion; a chief mansion house.
A college in an English university (at Oxford, an unendowed college).
The apartment in which English university students dine in common; hence, the dinner itself; as, hall is at six o'clock.
Cleared passageway in a crowd; -- formerly an exclamation.
sn.q: Ahall! a hall!

entry.def: A fee or toll paid for goods sold in a hall.
Praise ye Jehovah; praise ye the Lord; -- an exclamation used chiefly in songs of praise or thanksgiving to God, and as an expression of gratitude or adoration.

In those days, as St. Jerome tells us,“any one as he walked in the fields, might hear the plowman at his hallelujahs.”

entries.entry: Hal*loa" hăl*lō". See Halloo.

entries.entry: hallowed adj. belonging to or derived from or associated with a divine power; made holy. Opposite of unholy.Narrower terms: beatified, blessed ; blessed ; consecrated, sacred, sanctified Also See: consecrated consecrate sacred. holy.

entry.def: The evening preceding Allhallows or All Saints' Day (November 1); also the entire day, October 31. It is often marked by parties or celebrations, and sometimes by pranks played by young people.

entry.def: A claylike mineral, occurring in soft, smooth, amorphous masses, of a whitish color.

cs.cd: a prehistoric civilization of central Europe, variously dated at from 1000 to 1500 b. c. and usually associated with the Celtic or Alpine race. It was characterized by expert use of bronze, a knowledge of iron, possession of domestic animals, agriculture, and artistic skill and sentiment in manufacturing pottery, ornaments, etc.
cs.q: The Hallstattian civilization flourished chiefly in Carinthia, southern Germany, Switzerland, Bohemia, Silesia, Bosnia, the southeast of France, and southern Italy.
cs.cd: the first iron age, represented by the Hallstatt civilization.

a prehistoric civilization of central Europe, variously dated at from 1000 to 1500 b. c. and usually associated with the Celtic or Alpine race. It was characterized by expert use of bronze, a knowledge of iron, possession of domestic animals, agriculture, and artistic skill and sentiment in manufacturing pottery, ornaments, etc.
cs.q: The Hallstattian civilization flourished chiefly in Carinthia, southern Germany, Switzerland, Bohemia, Silesia, Bosnia, the southeast of France, and southern Italy.

entry.ety: L. hallucinatus alucinatus, p. p. of hallucinari alucinari, to wander in mind, talk idly, dream

sn.def: To wander; to go astray; to err; to blunder; -- used of mental processes.
To perceive a non-existent object or phenomenon; to believe that one is experiencing something which in reality does not exist; to experience a hallucination{2}.

entry.def: To experience (something nonexistent) as an hallucination{2}.
Experiencing hallucinations.

entry.def: One whose judgment and acts are affected by hallucinations; one who errs on account of his hallucinations.

A substance capable of producing hallucinations when ingested; a hallucinogenic substance; as, LSD is a powerful hallucinogen .

sn.def: capable of producing hallucinations; as, LSD is a powerful hallucinogenic drug.

an interior passage or corridor in a building, onto which rooms open.

A game played on a board having 256 squares, by two persons with 19 men each, or by four with 13 men each, starting from different corners and striving to place each his own set of men in a corresponding position in the opposite corner by moving them or by jumping them over those met in progress.

entries.entry:
Ha"lo hā"l� n.; pl.Halos -lōz. L. halos, acc. halo, Gr. "a`lws a thrashing floor, also (from its round shape) the disk of the sun or moon, and later a halo round it; cf. Gr. e'ily`ein to enfold, 'ely`ein to roll round, L. volvere, and E. voluble
A luminous circle, usually prismatically colored, round the sun or moon, and supposed to be caused by the refraction of light through crystals of ice in the atmosphere. Connected with halos there are often white bands, crosses, or arches, resulting from the same atmospheric conditions.
A circle of light; especially, the bright ring represented in painting as surrounding the heads of saints and other holy persons; a glory; a nimbus.
An ideal glory investing, or affecting one's perception of, an object.
A colored circle around a nipple; an areola.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Haloed -lōd; p. pr. & vb. n. Haloing
entry.def: To form, or surround with, a halo; to encircle with, or as with, a halo.
entry.q: The fire That haloed round his saintly brow.

entries.entry:
halobacter halobacterium
n.; pl.halobacteria, or halobacters #. Any halophilic bacterium of the archaebacteria group, expecially of the genera Halobacterium and Halococcus, which live in saline environments such as the Dead Sea or salt flats. halobacteria, halobacter.

entry.def: A genus of dioecious trees or shrubs of New Zealand; similar in habit to Dacrydium.
Surrounded with a halo; invested with an ideal glory; glorified.
entry.q: Some haloed face bending over me.

entry.def: An electro-negative element or radical, which, by combination with a metal, forms a haloid salt; especially, chlorine, fluorine, bromine, and iodine; sometimes, also cyanogen. See Chlorine family, under Chlorine.
Of the nature of a halogen.

Resembling salt; -- said of certain binary compounds consisting of a metal united to a negative element or radical, and now chiefly applied to the chlorides, bromides, iodides, and sometimes also to the fluorides and cyanides.
See Alomancy.
An instrument for measuring the forms and angles of salts and crystals; a goniometer.
Alternating transparent and opaque white rings which are seen outside the blastoderm, on the surface of the developing egg of the hen and other birds.
A plant found growing in salt marshes, or in the sea.
An instrument for exhibition or illustration of the phenomena of halos, parhelia, and the like.
An iron alum occurring in silky fibrous aggregates of a yellowish white color.
An explosive mixture, consisting of sawdust, charcoal, niter, and ferrocyanide of potassium, used as a substitute for gunpowder.

entries.entry: Halp hälp imp. of Help . Helped. Obs

3d pers. sing. pres. of Hold, contraction for holdeth.

entry.ety: Formerly alt, It. alto, G. halt, fr. halten to hold. See Hold

entry.q: Without any halt they marched.
Lovers] soon in passion's war contest, Yet in their march soon make a halt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Halted; p. pr. & vb. n. Halting

To stand in doubt whether to proceed, or what to do; to hesitate; to be uncertain.
sn.q: How long halt ye between two opinions?

entry.def: To cause to cease marching; to stop; as, the general halted his troops for refreshment.

entry.ety: AS. healt; akin to OS., Dan., & Sw. halt, Icel. haltr halltr, Goth. halts, OHG. halz

entry.ety: OE. halter helter helfter, AS. hælftre; akin to G. halfter, D. halfter halster, and also to E. helve. See Helve
entry.def: A strong strap or cord.
A rope or strap, with or without a headstall, for leading or tying a horse.
A rope for hanging malefactors; a noose.
entry.q: No man e'er felt the halter draw With good opinion of the law.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Haltered -tẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Haltering
entry.def: To tie by the neck with a rope, strap, or halter; to put a halter on; to subject to a hangman's halter.
entry.q: Ahalteredneck.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "alth^res weights used in jumping, fr. "a`llesqai to leap
entry.def: Balancers; the rudimentary hind wings of Diptera.
A term of reproach, implying that one is fit to be hanged.

Impure ore; dirty ore.
A half.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Halved hävd; p. pr. & vb. n. Halving

sn.def: To divide into two equal parts; as, to halve an apple; to be or form half of.
sn.q: So far apart their lives are thrown From the twin soul that halves their own.

sn.def: To join, as two pieces of timber, by cutting away each for half its thickness at the joining place, and fitting together.
Of a hole, match, etc., to reach or play in the same number of strokes as an opponent.

entry.def: Appearing as if one side, or one half, were cut away; dimidiate.

cs.cd: by one half at once; halfway; fragmentarily; partially; incompletely.

entry.cs: To go halves. See under Go.
entry.def: pl. of Half.
entry.q: I can not believe by halves; either I have faith, or I have it not.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. hālga. See Holy
entry.def: A saint.
A rope or tackle for hoisting or lowering yards, sails, flags, etc.
A genus of Silurian fossil corals; the chain corals. See Chain coral, under Chain.
Home.

entry.ety: AS. ham; akin to D. ham, dial. G. hamme, OHG. hamma. Perh. named from the bend at the ham, and akin to E. chamber. Cf. Gammon ham

sn.def: The region back of the knee joint; the popliteal space; the hock.
The thigh of any animal; especially, the thigh of a hog cured by salting and smoking.
sn.q: A plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams.

sn.def: a person who performs in a showy or exaggerated style; -- used especially of actors. Also used attributively, as, a ham actor.
The licensed operator of an amateur radio station.

cs.cd: to act in a showy fashion or to act so as to attract attention; to ham.

entry.def: To act with exaggerated voice and gestures; to overact.

entries.entry:
Ham"a*dry`ad hăm"ȧ*drī`ăd n.; pl. E. Hamadryads -ădz, L. Hamadryades -drī"ȧ*dēz. L. Hamadryas -adis, Gr. "Amadrya`s; "a`ma together + dry^s oak, tree: cf. F. hamadryade. See Same, and Tree
Class. Myth A tree nymph whose life ended with that of the particular tree, usually an oak, which had been her abode.
Zoöl A large venomous East Indian snake (Ophiophagus bungarus), allied to the cobras.

entry.def: The sacred baboon of Egypt (Cynocephalus Hamadryas).

entry.ety: Turk. & Ar. hammāl, fr. Ar. hamala to carry
entry.def: In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burden bearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
A natural family of plants comprising the genera Hamamelis; Corylopsis; Fothergilla; Liquidambar; Parrotia; and other small genera.

a group of chiefly woody plants considered among the most primitive of angiosperms; they have a perianth poorly developed or lacking, and flowers often unisexual and often in catkins and often wind pollinated. The group contains 23 families including the Betulaceae and Fagaceae (includes the Amentiferae); sometimes it is classified as a superorder.
A genus of fossil plants of the Oligocene having flowers resembling those of the witch hazel; found in Baltic region.
A genus of fossil plants having wood identical with or similar to that of the witch hazel.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "amamhli`s a kind of medlar or service tree; "a`ma at the same time + mh^lon an apple, any tree fruit
entry.def: A genus of plants which includes the witch-hazel (Hamamelis Virginica), a preparation of which is used medicinally.
Hooked; bent at the end into a hook; hamous.
Hooked, or set with hooks; hamate.
See Unciform.

entry.ety: OE. hamelen to mutilate, AS. hamelian; akin to OHG. hamalōn to mutilate, hamal mutilated, ham mutilated, Icel. hamla to mutilate. Cf. Hamper to fetter
entry.def: To hamstring.

entry.cs: Black Hamburg grape. See under Black. Hamburg edging a kind of embroidered work done by machinery on cambric or muslin; -- used for trimming. Hamburg lake a purplish crimson pigment resembling cochineal.
entry.def: A commercial city of Germany, near the mouth of the Elbe.
Home.

entry.ety: Scot. haims hammys hems, OE. ham; cf. D. haam
entry.def: One of the two curved pieces of wood or metal, in the harness of a draught horse, to which the traces are fastened. They are fitted upon the collar, or have pads fitting the horse's neck attached to them.
Same as Hamble.

entry.ety: AS. hāmsōcn. See Home, and Seek
entry.def: The felonious seeking and invasion of a person in his dwelling house.

entry.ety: From a negro minstrel song called “The ham-fat man.”
entry.def: A low-grade actor or performer; a ham.
not skillful in physical movement especially with the hands; clumsy; bungling; -- also used metaphorically of actions; as, ham-handed governmental interference.
entry.syn: bumbling, bungling, butterfingered, handless, heavy-handed, left-handed.

entry.def: Hook-shaped.

entries.entry: Ham"il*ton pe"ri*od hăm"ĭl*tŭn pē"rĭ*ŭd. Geol A subdivision of the Devonian system of America; -- so named from Hamilton, Madison Co., New York. It includes the Marcellus, Hamilton, and Genesee epochs or groups. See the Chart of Geology.

entry.def: A common genus of marine bubble shells of the Pacific coast of North America.
A large edible river fish (Erythrinus macrodon) of Guiana.
A fossil cephalopod of the genus Hamites, related to the ammonites, but having the last whorl bent into a hooklike form.
A descendant of Ham, Noah's second son. See Gen. x. 6-20.

cs.cd: the group of languages spoken mainly in the Sahara, Egypt, Galla, and Somâli Land, and supposed to be allied to the Semitic.

entry.def: Pertaining to Ham or his descendants.

entry.ety: OE. hamelet, OF. hamelet, dim. of hamel, F. hameau, LL. hamellum, a dim. of German origin; cf. G. heim home. √220. See Home
entry.def: A small village; a little cluster of houses in the country.
entry.q: The country wasted, and the hamlets burned.

entry.def: Confined to a hamlet.

entry.cs:
Atmospheric hammer a dead-stroke hammer in which the spring is formed by confined air.
Drop hammer Face hammer, etc. See under Drop Face, etc. Hammer fish. See Hammerhead. Hammer hardening the process of hardening metal by hammering it when cold. Hammer shell Zoöl any species of Malleus, a genus of marine bivalve shells, allied to the pearl oysters, having the wings narrow and elongated, so as to give them a hammer-shaped outline; -- called also hammer oyster. To bring to the hammer to put up at auction.
entry.ety: OE. hamer, AS. hamer hamor; akin to D. hamer, G. & Dan. hammer, Sw. hammare, Icel. hamarr, hammer, crag, and perh. to Gr. 'a`kmwn anvil, Skr. açman stone

sn.def: An instrument for driving nails, beating metals, and the like, consisting of a head, usually of steel or iron, fixed crosswise to a handle.
sn.q: With busy hammers closing rivets up.

entry.sn:
Something which in form or action resembles the common hammer; as: That part of a clock which strikes upon the bell to indicate the hour.
The padded mallet of a piano, which strikes the wires, to produce the tones.
Anat The malleus. See under Ear.
Gun That part of a gunlock which strikes the percussion cap, or firing pin; the cock; formerly, however, a piece of steel covering the pan of a flintlock musket and struck by the flint of the cock to ignite the priming.
Also, a person or thing that smites or shatters; as, St. Augustine was the hammer of heresies.
He met the stern legionaries [of Rome] who had been the “massive iron hammers” of the whole earth.

sn.def: A spherical weight attached to a flexible handle and hurled from a mark or ring. The weight of head and handle is usually not less than 16 pounds.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hammered -mẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hammering

sn.def: To beat with a hammer; to beat with heavy blows; as, to hammer iron.
To form or forge with a hammer; to shape by beating.
sn.q: Hammeredmoney.

sn.def: To form in the mind; to shape by hard intellectual labor; -- usually with out.
sn.q: Who was hammering out a penny dialogue.

sn.def: To be busy forming anything; to labor hard as if shaping something with a hammer.
sn.q: Whereon this month I have been hammering.

sn.def: To strike repeated blows, literally or figuratively.
sn.q: Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.

entry.def: Capable of being/formed or shapeo by a hammer.

A member of one description of roof truss, called hammer-beam truss, which is so framed as not to have a tiebeam at the top of the wall. Each principal has two hammer-beams, which occupy the situation, and to some extent serve the purpose, of a tiebeam.

entries.entry: Ham"mer break. Elec An interrupter in which contact is broken by the movement of an automatically vibrating hammer between a contact piece and an electromagnet, or of a rapidly moving piece mechanically driven.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. D. hemel heaven, canopy, tester (akin to G. himmel, and perh. also to E. heaven) + E. cloth; or perh. a corruption of hamper cloth
entry.def: The cloth which covers a coach box.
Having the surface roughly shaped or faced with the stonecutter's hammer; -- said of building stone.
One who works with a hammer.
To harden, as a metal, by hammering it in the cold state.

sn.def: A shark of the genus Sphyrna or Zygæna, having the eyes set on projections from the sides of the head, which gives it a hammer shape. The Sphyrna zygæna is found in the North Atlantic. Called also hammer fish, and balance fish.
A fresh-water fish; the stone-roller.
An African fruit bat (Hypsignathus monstrosus); -- so called from its large blunt nozzle.

entry.def: A bird of the Heron family; the umber.
Without a visible hammer; -- said of a gun having a cock or striker concealed from sight, and out of the way of an accidental touch.

entries.entry: Hammer lock. Wrestling A hold in which an arm of one contestant is held twisted and bent behind his back by his opponent.
Ham"mer*man -m�n n.; pl.Hammermen -m�n. A hammerer; a forgeman.

entry.def: poor acting by a ham actor; see ham.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. "ammo`chrysos; "a`mmos 'a`mmos, sand + chryso`s gold
entry.def: A stone with spangles of gold color in it.

cs.cd: formerly, nets for stowing hammocks; now, more often, wooden boxes or a trough on the rail, used for that purpose.

entry.ety: A word of Indian origin: cf. Sp. hamaca. Columbus, in the Narrative of his first voyage, says: “A great many Indians in canoes came to the ship to-day for the purpose of bartering their cotton, and hamacas, or nets, in which they sleep.”

sn.def: A swinging couch or bed, usually made of netting or canvas about six feet long and three feet wide, suspended by clews or cords at the ends.
A piece of land thickly wooded, and usually covered with bushes and vines. Used also adjectively; as, hammock land.

entry.def: Having the end hooked or curved.
A large basket, usually with a cover, used for the packing and carrying of articles; as, a hamper of wine; a clothes hamper; an oyster hamper, which contains two bushels.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hampered -pẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hampering
entry.def: To put in a hamper.

entry.ety: OE. hamperen hampren, prob. of the same origin as E. hamble
entry.def: To put a hamper or fetter on; to shackle; to insnare; to inveigle; to entangle; hence, to impede in motion or progress; to embarrass; to encumber.
entry.q: Hamperednerves.
A lion hampered in a net.
They hamper and entangle our souls.

cs.cd: unnecessary spars and rigging kept aloft.

sn.def: A shackle; a fetter; anything which impedes.
Articles ordinarily indispensable, but in the way at certain times.

entry.def: To fasten (an animal) by a rope binding the head to one of the fore legs; as, to hamshackle a horse or cow; hence, to bind or restrain; to curb.
A small European rodent (Cricetus frumentarius). It is remarkable for having a pouch on each side of the jaw, under the skin, and for its migrations. Hamsters are commonly kept as a pets.
One of the great tendons situated in each side of the ham, or space back of the knee, and connected with the muscles of the back of the thigh.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hamstrung; p. pr. & vb. n. Hamstringing. See String
