Harmonic suture Anat an articulation by simple apposition of comparatively smooth surfaces or edges, as between the two superior maxillary bones in man; -- called also harmonia, and harmony. Harmonic triad Mus the chord of a note with its third and fifth; the common chord.
entry.ety: L. harmonicus, Gr. "armoniko`s; cf. F. harmonique. See Harmony

sn.def: Concordant; musical; consonant; as, harmonic sounds.
sn.q: Harmonic twang! of leather, horn, and brass.

sn.def: Relating to harmony, -- as melodic relates to melody; harmonious; esp., relating to the accessory sounds or overtones which accompany the predominant and apparent single tone of any string or sonorous body.
Having relations or properties bearing some resemblance to those of musical consonances; -- said of certain numbers, ratios, proportions, points, lines, motions, and the like.

entry.def: A musical note produced by a number of vibrations which is a multiple of the number producing some other; an overtone. See Harmonics.

entry.ety: Fem. fr. L. harmonicus harmonic. See Harmonic n.

sn.def: A musical instrument, consisting of a series of hemispherical glasses which, by touching the edges with the dampened finger, give forth the tones; it is now called the glass harmonica, to distinguish it from the common harmonica, formerly called the harmonicon.
A toy instrument of strips of glass or metal hung on two tapes, and struck with hammers.

A small wind musical instrument shaped like a flat bar with holes along the thin edges, held in the hand and producing notes from multiple vibrating reeds arranged inside along its length; it was formerly called the harmonicon. See harmonicon.
In an harmonical manner; harmoniously.
In respect to harmony, as distinguished from melody; as, a passage harmonically correct.
In harmonical progression.

entry.def: A small, flat, wind instrument of music, in which the notes are produced by the vibration of free metallic reeds; it is now called the harmonica.

sn.def: The doctrine or science of musical sounds.

Secondary and less distinct tones which accompany any principal, and apparently simple, tone, as the octave, the twelfth, the fifteenth, and the seventeenth. The name is also applied to the artificial tones produced by a string or column of air, when the impulse given to it suffices only to make a part of the string or column vibrate; overtones.
Adapted to each other; having parts proportioned to each other; symmetrical.
sn.q: God hath made the intellectual world harmonious and beautiful without us.

sn.def: Acting together to a common end; agreeing in action or feeling; living in peace and friendship; as, an harmonious family.
Vocally or musically concordant; agreeably consonant; symphonious.

entry.def: An obsolete wind instrument with a keyboard, in which the sound, which resembled the oboe, was produced by the vibration of thin metallic plates, acted upon by blowing through a tube.

sn.def: One who shows the agreement or harmony of corresponding passages of different authors, as of the four evangelists.
One who understands the principles of harmony or is skillful in applying them in composition; a musical composer.

entry.def: One of a religious sect, founded in Würtemburg in the last century, composed of followers of George Rapp, a weaver. They had all their property in common. In 1803, a portion of this sect settled in Pennsylvania and called the village thus established, Harmony.

A musical instrument, resembling a small organ and especially designed for church music, in which the tones are produced by forcing air by means of a bellows so as to cause the vibration of free metallic reeds. It is now made with one or two keyboards, and has pedals and stops.
capable of being made harmonious or consistent.
The act of harmonizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harmonized -nīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Harmonizing -nī"zĭng

sn.def: To agree in action, adaptation, or effect on the mind; to agree in sense or purport; as, the parts of a mechanism harmonize .
To be in peace and friendship, as individuals, families, or public organizations.
To agree in vocal or musical effect; to form a concord; as, the tones harmonize perfectly.
To adjust in fit proportions; to cause to agree; to show the agreement of; to reconcile the apparent contradiction of.
To accompany with harmony; to provide with parts, as an air, or melody.

entry.def: One who harmonizes.

entry.ety: Gr. "armoni`a harmony + meter: cf. F. harmonometre
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the harmonic relations of sounds. It is often a monochord furnished with movable bridges.

entries.entry:
Har"mo*ny
Close harmony Dispersed harmony
etc. See under Close Dispersed, etc. Harmony of the spheres. See Music of the spheres, under Music.
Harmony results from the concord of two or more strains or sounds which differ in pitch and quality. Melody denotes the pleasing alternation and variety of musical and measured sounds, as they succeed each other in a single verse or strain. här"m�*n� n.; pl.Harmonies -nĭz. F. harmonie, L. harmonia, Gr. "armoni`a joint, proportion, concord, fr. "armo`s a fitting or joining. See Article
The just adaptation of parts to each other, in any system or combination of things, or in things intended to form a connected whole; such an agreement between the different parts of a design or composition as to produce unity of effect; as, the harmony of the universe.
Concord or agreement in facts, opinions, manners, interests, etc.; good correspondence; peace and friendship; as, good citizens live in harmony .
A literary work which brings together or arranges systematically parallel passages of historians respecting the same events, and shows their agreement or consistency; as, a harmony of the Gospels.
Mus
A succession of chords according to the rules of progression and modulation.
The science which treats of their construction and progression. Ten thousand harps, that tuned Angelic harmonies.
Anat See Harmonic suture, under Harmonic.
Harmony Melody.

entry.ety: Gr. "armosth`s, fr. "armo`zein to join, arrange, command: cf. F. harmoste. See Harmony
entry.def: A city governor or prefect appointed by the Spartans in the cities subjugated by them.

entry.note: ☞ A related mineral, called lime harmotome, and Phillipsite, contains lime in place of baryta.
entry.ety: Gr. "armo`s a joint + te`mnein to cut: cf. F. harmotome
entry.def: A hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta, occurring usually in white cruciform crystals; cross-stone.

cs.cd: to die with armor on; hence, colloquially, to die while actively engaged in work or duty.

entry.ety: OE. harneis harnes, OF. harneis, F. harnais harnois; of Celtic origin; cf. Armor. harnez old iron, armor, W. haiarn iron, Armor. houarn, Ir. iarann, Gael. iarunn. Cf. Iron

sn.def: Originally, the complete dress, especially in a military sense, of a man or a horse; hence, in general, armor.
sn.q: At least we'll die with harness on our back.

sn.def: The equipment of a draught or carriage horse, for drawing a wagon, coach, chaise, etc.; gear; tackling.
The part of a loom comprising the heddles, with their means of support and motion, by which the threads of the warp are alternately raised and depressed for the passage of the shuttle.

entry.cs: Harnessed antelope. Zoöl See Guib. Harnessed moth Zoöl an American bombycid moth (Arctia phalerata of Harris), having, on the fore wings, stripes and bands of buff on a black ground.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harnessed -nĕst; p. pr. & vb. n. Harnessing
entry.ety: OE. harneisen; cf. F. harnacher, OF. harneschier

sn.def: To dress in armor; to equip with armor for war, as a horseman; to array.
sn.q: Harnessed in rugged steel.
A gay dagger,Harnessed well and sharp as point of spear.

sn.def: Fig.: To equip or furnish for defense.
To make ready for draught; to equip with harness, as a horse. Also used figuratively.
sn.q: Harnessed to some regular profession.

entries.entry: Har"ness cask` kȧsk`. Naut A tub lashed to a vessel's deck and containing salted provisions for daily use; -- called also harness tub.

entry.def: One who harnesses.

entry.ety: Akin to Icel. hjarni, Dan. hierne
entry.def: The brains.

entry.cs: Æolian harp. See under Æolian.

cs.cd: an arctic seal (Phoca Grœnlandica). The adult males have a light-colored body, with a harp-shaped mark of black on each side, and the face and throat black. Called also saddler, and saddleback. The immature ones are called bluesides; their fur is white, and they are killed and skinned to harvest the fur.
a beautiful marine gastropod shell of the genus Harpa, of several species, found in tropical seas. See Harpa.

entry.ety: OE. harpe, AS. hearpe; akin to D. harp, G. harfe, OHG. harpha, Dan. harpe, Icel. & Sw. harpa

sn.def: A musical instrument consisting of a triangular frame furnished with strings and sometimes with pedals, held upright, and played with the fingers.
A constellation; Lyra, or the Lyre.
A grain sieve.

cs.cd: to dwell upon one subject with disagreeable or wearisome persistence.

sn.def: To play on the harp.
sn.q: I heard the voice of harpers, harping with their harps.

sn.def: To dwell on or recur to a subject tediously or monotonously in speaking or in writing; to refer to something repeatedly or continually; -- usually with on or upon.
sn.q: Harpingsupon old themes.
Harping on what I am, Not what he knew I was.

entry.def: To play on, as a harp; to play (a tune) on the harp; to develop or give expression to by skill and art; to sound forth as from a harp; to hit upon.
entry.q: Thou 'st harped my fear aright.

entry.def: A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- so called from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.
A grappling iron.

sn.def: A player on the harp; a minstrel.
sn.q: The murmuring pines and the hemlocks . . . Stand like harpers hoar, with beards that rest on their bosoms.

sn.def: A brass coin bearing the emblem of a harp, -- formerly current in Ireland.

entry.def: Pertaining to the harp; as, harping symphonies.

entries.entry:
Harp"ing i`ron ī`ŭrn. F. harper to grasp strongly. See Harpoon
A harpoon.

entry.def: The fore parts of the wales, which encompass the bow of a vessel, and are fastened to the stem.
A player on the harp; a harper.

cs.cd: a kind of hayfork, consisting of a bar with hinged barbs at one end and a loop for a rope at the other end, used for lifting hay from the load by horse power.
a gun used in the whale fishery for shooting the harpoon into a whale.

entry.ety: F. harpon, LL. harpo, perh. of Ger. origin, fr. the harp; cf. F. harper to take and grasp strongly, harpe a dog's claw, harpin boathook (the sense of hook coming from the shape of the harp); but cf. also Gr. "a`rph the kite, sickle, and E. harpy. Cf. Harp
entry.def: A spear or javelin used to strike and kill large fish, as whales; a harping iron. It consists of a long shank, with a broad, flat, triangular head, sharpened at both edges, and is thrown by hand, or discharged from a gun.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harpooned -p�nd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Harpooning
entry.def: To strike, catch, or kill with a harpoon.
An harpooner.
One who throws the harpoon.
A female harper.
A harpsichord.

entry.ety: OF. harpechorde, in which the harpe is of German origin. See Harp, and Chord
entry.def: A harp-shaped instrument of music set horizontally on legs, like the grand piano, with strings of wire, played by the fingers, by means of keys provided with quills, instead of hammers, for striking the strings. It is now superseded by the piano.
someone who plays the harpsichord.
A fast-growing tree of India and East Indies (Harpullia cupanioides) yielding a wood used especially for building.
any of various tree of the genus Harpullia.

entries.entry:
Har"py
Harpy bat Zoöl An East Indian fruit bat of the genus Harpyiaesp. Harpyia cephalotes), having prominent, tubular nostrils. A small, insectivorous Indian bat (Harpiocephalus harpia). Harpy fly Zoöl the house fly.
här"p� n.; pl.Harpies -pĭz. F. harpie, L. harpyia, Gr. "a`rpyia, from the root of "arpa`zein to snatch, to seize. Cf. Rapacious
Gr. Myth A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the face of a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the face pale with hunger. Some writers mention two, others three. Both table and provisions vanished quite. With sound of harpies' wings and talons heard.
One who is rapacious or ravenous; an extortioner. The harpies about all pocket the pool.
Zoöl
The European moor buzzard or marsh harrier (Circus æruginosus).
A large and powerful, double-crested, short-winged American eagle (Thrasaëtus harpyia). It ranges from Texas to Brazil.

entry.def: A firearm with match holder, trigger, and tumbler, made in the second half of the 15th century. The barrel was about forty inches long. A form of the harquebus was subsequently called arquebus with matchlock.
To harass; to plunder from.
A hinge.

entry.ety: F. haridelle a worn-out horse, jade
entry.def: A worn-out strumpet; a vixenish woman; a hag.
entry.q: Such a weak, watery, wicked old harridan, substituted for the pretty creature I had been used to see.

entry.def: same as harassed.
One of a small breed of hounds, used for hunting hares.

cs.cd: one of several species of American hawks of the genus Micrastur.

sn.def: One who harries.

One of several species of hawks or buzzards of the genus Circus which fly low and harry small animals or birds, -- as the European marsh harrier (Circus æruginosus), and the hen harrier (Circus cyaneus).

entry.def: A genus of slender often treelike spiny cacti with solitary showy nocturnal white or pink flowers; Florida and Caribbean to South America.

entry.cs: Bush harrow a kind of light harrow made of bushes, for harrowing grass lands and covering seeds, or to finish the work of a toothed harrow. Drill harrow. See under 6th Drill. Under the harrow subjected to actual torture with a toothed instrument, or to great affliction or oppression.
entry.ety: OE. harowe harwe, AS. hearge; cf. D. hark rake, G. harke, Icel. herfi harrow, Dan. harve, Sw. harf. √16

sn.def: An implement of agriculture, usually formed of pieces of timber or metal crossing each other, and set with iron or wooden teeth. It is drawn over plowed land to level it and break the clods, to stir the soil and make it fine, or to cover seed when sown.
An obstacle formed by turning an ordinary harrow upside down, the frame being buried.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harrowed hăr"r�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Harrowing
entry.ety: OE. harowen harwen; cf. Dan. harve. See Harrow n.

sn.def: To draw a harrow over, as for the purpose of breaking clods and leveling the surface, or for covering seed; as, to harrow land.
sn.q: Will he harrow the valleys after thee?

sn.def: To break or tear, as with a harrow; to wound; to lacerate; to torment or distress; to vex.
sn.q: My aged muscles harrowed up with whips.
I could a tale unfold, whose lightest word Would harrow up thy soul.

entry.ety: OF. harau haro; fr. OHG. hara hera herot, or fr. OS. herod hither, akin to E. here
entry.def: Help! Halloo! An exclamation of distress; a call for succor; -- the ancient Norman hue and cry.
entry.q: Harrowand well away!
Harrow! alas! here lies my fellow slain.

entry.def: To pillage; to harry; to oppress.
entry.q: Meaning thereby to harrow his people.

entry.def: One who harrows.
One who harries.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harried -rĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Harrying
entry.ety: OE. harwen herien herȝien, AS. hergian to act as an army, to ravage, plunder, fr. here army; akin to G. heer, Icel. herr, Goth. harjis, and Lith. karas war. Cf. Harbor Herald Heriot

sn.def: To strip; to pillage; to lay waste; as, the Northmen came several times and harried the land.
sn.q: To harry this beautiful region.
A red squirrel had harried the nest of a wood thrush.

sn.def: To agitate; to worry; to harrow; to harass.
sn.syn: To ravage; plunder; pillage; lay waste; vex; tease; worry; annoy; harass.

entry.def: To make a predatory incursion; to plunder or lay waste.

entry.ety: OE. harsk; akin to G. harsch, Dan. harsk rancid, Sw. härsk; from the same source as E. hard. See Hard a.
entry.sn:
Rough; disagreeable; grating; esp.:
disagreeable to the touch.
Harshsand. Boyle.
disagreeable to the taste. Berriesharshand crude. Milton.
disagreeable to the ear.
Harshdin. Milton.

sn.def: Unpleasant and repulsive to the sensibilities; austere; crabbed; morose; abusive; abusive; severe; rough.
sn.q: Clarence is so harsh, so blunt.
Though harsh the precept, yet the preacher charmed.

sn.def: Having violent contrasts of color, or of light and shade; lacking in harmony.

entry.def: In a harsh manner; gratingly; roughly; rudely.
entry.q: 'T will sound harshly in her ears.

entry.def: The quality or state of being harsh.
entry.q: O, she is Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed, And he's composed of harshness.
'Tis not enough no harshness gives offense, The sound must seem an echo to the sense.
entry.syn: Acrimony; roughness; sternness; asperity; tartness. See Acrimony.

entry.def: See Haslet.

entry.ety: OE. hart hert heort, AS. heort heorot; akin to D. hert, OHG. hiruz hirz, G. hirsch, Icel. hjörtr, Dan. & Sw. hjort, L. cervus, and prob. to Gr. kerao`s horned, ke`ras horn. √230. See Horn
entry.def: A stag; the male of the red deer. See the Note under Buck.
entry.q: Goodliest of all the forest, hart and hind.

sn.def: large African antelope with lyre-shaped horns that curve backward.

entry.ety: D. hertebeest. See Hart, and Beast

sn.def: A large South African antelope (Alcelaphus caama), formerly much more abundant than it is now. The face and legs are marked with black, the rump with white.
Any anteleope of the genus Alcelaphus and certain species of Darnaliscus.

entry.def: To hearten; to encourage; to incite.
The Hartford grape, a variety of grape first raised at Hartford, Connecticut, from the Northern fox grape. Its large dark-colored berries ripen earlier than those of most other kinds.

entries.entry: Hart's" clo`ver härts" klō`vẽr. Bot Melilot or sweet clover. See Melilot.

entry.def: An Asiatic species of Cacalia Cacalia Kleinia), used medicinally in India.

cs.cd: an annual species of plantain (Plantago Coronopus); -- called also buck's-horn.
originally taken from the horns of harts, are now obtained chiefly by planing down the bones of calves. They afford a kind of jelly.
an impure solid carbonate of ammonia, obtained by the destructive distillation of hartshorn, or any kind of bone; volatile salts.

a solution of ammonia in water; -- so called because formerly obtained from hartshorn shavings by destructive distillation. Similar ammoniacal solutions from other sources have received the same name.

sn.def: The horn or antler of the hart, or male red deer.
Spirits of hartshorn (see below); volatile salts.

entry.def: A common British fern (Scolopendrium vulgare), rare in America.
A West Indian fern, the Polypodium Phyllitidis of Linnæus. It is also found in Florida.

entry.note: ☞ The name is often vaguely given to other plants of the same order, as species of Seseli and Bupleurum.
entry.def: A coarse umbelliferous plant of Europe (Tordylium maximum).

entry.ety: Cf. hare,v. t., and scare v. t.
entry.def: Wild; giddy; flighty; rash; thoughtless.
entry.q: They had a quarrel with Sir Thomas Newcome's own son, a harum-scarum lad.

entry.def: See Haruspicy.
A diviner of ancient Rome. Same as Aruspice.
The art or practices of haruspices. See Aruspicy.

entry.cs: Harvest fish Zoöl a marine fish of the Southern United States (Stromateus alepidotus); -- called whiting in Virginia. Also applied to the dollar fish. Harvest fly Zoöl an hemipterous insect of the genus Cicada, often called locust. See Cicada. Harvest lord the head reaper at a harvest. Obs Tusser. Harvest mite Zoöl a minute European mite (Leptus autumnalis), of a bright crimson color, which is troublesome by penetrating the skin of man and domestic animals; -- called also harvest louse, and harvest bug. Harvest moon the moon near the full at the time of harvest in England, or about the autumnal equinox, when, by reason of the small angle that is made by the moon's orbit with the horizon, it rises nearly at the same hour for several days. Harvest mouse Zoöl a very small European field mouse (Mus minutus). It builds a globular nest on the stems of wheat and other plants. Harvest queen an image representing Ceres, formerly carried about on the last day of harvest. Milton. Harvest spider. Zoöl See Daddy longlegs.
entry.ety: OE. harvest hervest, AS. hærfest autumn; akin to LG. harfst, D. herfst, OHG. herbist, G. herbst, and prob. to L. carpere to pluck, Gr. karpo`s fruit. Cf. Carpet

sn.def: The gathering of a crop of any kind; the ingathering of the crops; also, the season of gathering grain and fruits, late summer or early autumn.
sn.q: Seedtime and harvest . . . shall not cease.
At harvest, when corn is ripe.

sn.def: That which is reaped or ready to be reaped or gathered; a crop, as of grain (wheat, maize, etc.), or fruit.
sn.q: Put ye in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe.
To glean the broken ears after the man That the main harvest reaps.

sn.def: The product or result of any exertion or labor; gain; reward.
sn.q: The pope's principal harvest was in the jubilee.
The harvest of a quiet eye.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Harvested; p. pr. & vb. n. Harvesting
entry.def: To reap or gather, as any crop.

sn.def: One who harvests; a machine for cutting and gathering grain; a reaper.
A harvesting ant.
The gathering and bringing home of the harvest; the time of harvest.
sn.q: Showed like a stubble land at harvest-home.

sn.def: The song sung by reapers at the feast made at the close of the harvest; the feast itself.
A service of thanksgiving, at harvest time, in the Church of England and in the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.
The opportunity of gathering treasure.

cs.cd: any species of ant which gathers and stores up seeds for food. Many species are known.

entry.note: ☞ The species found in Southern Europe and Palestine are Aphenogaster structor and Aphenogaster barbara; that of Texas, called agricultural ant, is Pogonomyrmex barbatus or Myrmica molifaciens; that of Florida is Pogonomyrmex crudelis. See Agricultural ant, under Agricultural.
entry.def: a. & n., from Harvest v. t.
Without harvest; lacking in crops; barren.
entry.q: Harvestlessautumns.

entry.def: An erect perennial Old World herb (Agrimonia eupatoria) of dry grassy habitats.

entries.entry:
Har"vest*man -m�n n.; pl.Harvestmen -m�n.
A man engaged in harvesting.
Zoöl See Daddy longlegs, 1.

entry.def: The act of harvesting; also, that which is harvested.

entries.entry: Har"vey proc"ess. Metal A process of hardening the face of steel, as armor plates, invented by Hayward A. Harvey of New Jersey, consisting in the additional carburizing of the face of a piece of low carbon steel by subjecting it to the action of carbon under long-continued pressure at a very high heat, and then to a violent chilling, as by a spray of cold water. This process gives an armor plate a thick surface of extreme hardness supported by material gradually decreasing in hardness to the unaltered soft steel at the back.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. harier to harass, or E. harry v. t.
entry.def: To draw; to drag; to carry off by violence.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Have.
Hazard.
See Haze v. t.

entry.ety: Formerly hachey hachee, F. hachis, fr. hacher to hash; of German origin; cf. G. hippe sickle, OHG. hippa, for happia. Cf. Hatchet

sn.def: That which is hashed or chopped up; meat and vegetables, especially such as have been already cooked, chopped into small pieces and mixed.
A new mixture of old matter; a second preparation or exhibition.
sn.q: I can not bear elections, and still less the hash of them over again in a first session.

sn.def: Hashish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hashed hăsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Hashing
entry.ety: From Hash n.: cf. F. hacher to hash
entry.def: To chop into small pieces; to mince and mix; as, to hash meat.

A slightly acrid gum resin produced by the common hemp (Cannabis sativa), of the variety Indica, when cultivated in a warm climate; also, the tops of the plant, from which the resinous product is obtained. It is narcotic, and has long been used in the East for its intoxicating effect. The active psychoactive principle has been identified as tetrahydrocannabinol. See Bhang, and Ganja.
an insignia worn on the uniform to indicate years of service.
A basket made of rushes or flags, as for carrying fish.

entry.ety: F. hâtelettes broil, for hastelettes, fr. F. haste spit; cf. L. hasta spear, and also OHG. harst gridiron
entry.def: The edible viscera, as the heart, liver, etc., of a beast, esp. of a hog.

entry.ety: OE. hasp hesp, AS. hæpse; akin to G. haspe häspe, Sw. & Dan. haspe, Icel. hespa

sn.def: A clasp, especially a metal strap permanently fast at one end to a staple or pin, while the other passes over a staple, and is fastened by a padlock or a pin; also, a metallic hook for fastening a door.
A spindle to wind yarn, thread, or silk on.
An instrument for cutting the surface of grass land; a scarifier.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hasped hȧspt; p. pr. & vb. n. Hasping
entry.def: To shut or fasten with a hasp.

sn.def: An inconvenience caused by difficulties encountered trying to accomplish a task; as, finding a parking place in midtown is always a hassle .
disorderly fighting; an angry dispute or disturbance.
to dispute or quarrel, often over petty disagreements.
To expend excessive time and energy trying to accomplish a task.

entry.def: to repeatedly annoy; as, He is known to hassle his staff when he is overworked.
entry.syn: harass, harry, chivy, chivvy, chevy, chevvy, beset, plague, molest, provoke.

entry.ety: Scot. hassock hassik, a besom, anything bushy, a large, round turf used as a seat, OE. hassok sedgy ground, W. hesgog sedgy, hesg sedge, rushes; cf. Ir. seisg, and E. sedge

sn.def: A rank tuft of bog grass; a tussock.
A small stuffed cushion or footstool, for kneeling on in church, or for home use.
sn.q: And knees and hassocks are well nigh divorced.

entry.def: 2d pers. sing. pres. of Have, contr. of havest.

entry.ety: L. hastatus, fr. hasta spear. Cf. Gad n.
entry.def: Shaped like the head of a halberd; triangular, with the basal angles or lobes spreading; as, a hastate leaf.

cs.cd: to hasten.

entry.usage: Haste Hurry Speed Dispatch. Haste denotes quickness of action and a strong desire for getting on; hurry includes a confusion and want of collected thought not implied in haste; speed denotes the actual progress which is made; dispatch, the promptitude and rapidity with which things are done. A man may properly be in haste, but never in a hurry. Speed usually secures dispatch.
entry.ety: OE. hast; akin to D. haast, G., Dan., Sw., & OFries. hast, cf. OF. haste, F. hâteof German origin); all perh. fr. the root of E. hate in a earlier sense of, to pursue. See Hate

sn.def: Celerity of motion; speed; swiftness; dispatch; expedition; -- applied only to voluntary beings, as men and other animals.
sn.q: The king's business required haste.

sn.def: The state of being urged or pressed by business; hurry; urgency; sudden excitement of feeling or passion; precipitance; vehemence.
sn.q: I said in my haste, All men are liars.
sn.syn: Speed; quickness; nimbleness; swiftness; expedition; dispatch; hurry; precipitance; vehemence; precipitation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Hasting
entry.ety: OE. hasten; akin to G. hasten, D. haasten, Dan. haste, Sw. hasta, OF. haster, F. hâter. See Haste n.
entry.def: To hasten; to hurry.
entry.q: I 'll haste the writer.
They were troubled and hasted away.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hastened hās"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hastening hās"'n*ĭng
entry.def: To press; to drive or urge forward; to push on; to precipitate; to accelerate the movement of; to expedite; to hurry.
entry.q: I would hasten my escape from the windy storm.

entry.def: To move with celerity; to be rapid in motion; to act speedily or quickly; to go quickly.
entry.q: I hastened to the spot whence the noise came.

sn.def: One who hastens.
That which hastens; especially, a stand or reflector used for confining the heat of the fire to meat while roasting before it.

entry.def: Hasty.
Same as Hastate.

sn.def: In haste; with speed or quickness; speedily; nimbly.
Without due reflection; precipitately; rashly.
sn.q: We hastily engaged in the war.

sn.def: Passionately; impatiently.

entry.def: The quality or state of being hasty; haste; precipitation; rashness; quickness of temper.
Early fruit or vegetables; especially, early pease.

entries.entry: Has"tings sands` săndz`. Geol The lower group of the Wealden formation; -- so called from its development around Hastings, in Sussex, England.

entry.ety: OF. hastif. See Haste n., and cf. Hastif
entry.def: Forward; early; -- said of fruits.

entry.ety: Akin to D. haastig, G., Sw., & Dan. hastig. See Haste n.

sn.def: Involving haste; done, made, etc., in haste; as, a hasty retreat; a hasty sketch.
Demanding haste or immediate action.
sn.q: Hastyemployment.

sn.def: Moving or acting with haste or in a hurry; hurrying; hence, acting without deliberation; precipitate; rash; easily excited; eager.
sn.q: Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? There is more hope of a fool than of him.
The hasty multitude Admiring entered.
Be not hasty to go out of his sight.

sn.def: Made or reached without deliberation or due caution; as, a hasty conjecture, inference, conclusion, etc., a hasty resolution.
Proceeding from, or indicating, a quick temper.
sn.q: Take no unkindness of his hasty words.

sn.def: Forward; early; first ripe.
sn.q: As thehastyfruit before the summer.

entries.entry:
Has"ty pud"ding hās"t� pụd"dĭng. A thick batter pudding made of Indian meal stirred into boiling water; mush. U. S
A batter or pudding made of flour or oatmeal, stirred into boiling water or milk. Eng

entry.def: Hot.

entries.entry:
Hat
sing. pres. of Hote to be called. Cf. Hatte. Obs That onehatabstinence.

cs.cd: a block on which hats are formed or dressed.
to take up a collection of voluntary contributions, which are often received in a hat.

entry.ety: AS. hæt hætt; akin to Dan. hat, Sw. hatt, Icel. hattr a hat, höttr hood, D. hoed hat, G. hut, OHG. huot, and prob. to L. cassis helmet. √13. Cf. Hood
entry.def: A covering for the head; esp., one with a crown and brim, made of various materials, and worn by men or women for protecting the head from the sun or weather, or for ornament.
Capable of being, or deserving to be, hated; odious; detestable.
A band round the crown of a hat; sometimes, a band of black cloth, crape, etc., worn as a badge of mourning.
A box for a hat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hatched hăcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Hatching
entry.ety: F. hacher to chop, hack. See Hash

sn.def: To cross with lines in a peculiar manner in drawing and engraving. See Hatching.
sn.q: Shall win this sword, silvered and hatched.
Those hatching strokes of the pencil.

sn.def: To cross; to spot; to stain; to steep.
sn.q: His weapon hatched in blood.

entry.ety: OE. hacchen hetchen; akin to G. hecken, Dan. hekke; cf. MHG. hagen bull; perh. akin to E. hatch a half door, and originally meaning, to produce under a hatch. √12

sn.def: To produce, as young, from an egg or eggs by incubation, or by artificial heat; to produce young from (eggs); as, the young when hatched .
sn.q: As the partridge sitteth on eggs, and hatcheth them not.
For the hens do not sit upon the eggs; but by keeping them in a certain equal heat they [the husbandmen] bring life into them and hatch them.

sn.def: To contrive or plot; to form by meditation, and bring into being; to originate and produce; to concoct; as, to hatch mischief; to hatch heresy.
sn.q: Fancies hatched In silken-folded idleness.

entry.def: To produce young; -- said of eggs; to come forth from the egg; -- said of the young of birds, fishes, insects, etc.

sn.def: The act of hatching.
Development; disclosure; discovery.
The chickens produced at once or by one incubation; a brood.

cs.mcol: Booby hatch Buttery hatch Companion hatch, etc.
cs.cd: See under Booby Buttery, etc.
to lay tarpaulins over them, and secure them with battens.
to be confined below in a vessel; to be under arrest, or in slavery, distress, etc.

entry.ety: OE. hacche, AS. hæc, cf. haca the bar of a door, D. hek gate, Sw. häck coop, rack, Dan. hekke manger, rack. Prob. akin to E. hook, and first used of something made of pieces fastened together. Cf. Heck Hack a frame

sn.def: A door with an opening over it; a half door, sometimes set with spikes on the upper edge.
sn.q: In at the window, or else o'er the hatch.

sn.def: A frame or weir in a river, for catching fish.
A flood gate; a sluice gate.
A bedstead.
An opening in the deck of a vessel or floor of a warehouse which serves as a passageway or hoistway; a hatchway; also; a cover or door, or one of the covers used in closing such an opening.
An opening into, or in search of, a mine.

entry.def: To close with a hatch or hatches.
entry.q: 'T were not amiss to keep our door hatched.

entry.def: A vessel whose deck consists almost wholly of movable hatches; -- used mostly in the fisheries.

entry.ety: p. p. from hatch v. i.
entry.def: produced from an egg.

entry.ety: OE. hechele hekele; akin to D. hekel, G. hechel, Dan. hegle, Sw. häkla, and prob. to E. hook. See Hook, and cf. Hackle Heckle
entry.def: An instrument with long iron teeth set in a board, for cleansing flax or hemp from the tow, hards, or coarse part; a kind of large comb; -- called also hackle and heckle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hatcheled or Hatchelled -ĕld; p. pr. & vb. n. Hatcheling or Hatchelling
entry.ety: OE. hechelen hekelen; akin to D. hekelen, G. hecheln, Dan. hegle, Sw. häkla. See Hatchel n.

sn.def: To draw through the teeth of a hatchel, as flax or hemp, so as to separate the coarse and refuse parts from the fine, fibrous parts.
To tease; to worry; to torment.

entry.def: One who uses a hatchel.

sn.def: One who hatches, or that which hatches; a hatching apparatus; an incubator.
One who contrives or originates; a plotter.
sn.q: A great hatcher and breeder of business.

entry.def: A house for hatching fish, etc.

entry.cs: hatchet face a thin, sharp face, like the edge of a hatchet; hence: hatchet-faced sharp-visaged. Dryden. To bury the hatchet to make peace or become reconciled. To take up the hatchet to make or declare war. The last two phrases are derived from the practice of the American Indians.
entry.ety: F. hachette, dim. of hache ax. See 1st Hatch Hash

sn.def: A small ax with a short handle, to be used with one hand.
Specifically, a tomahawk.
sn.q: Buried was the bloody hatchet.

sn.def: A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hit man.
A person who deliberately tries to ruin the reputation of another, often unscrupulously, by slander or other malicious communication, often with a political motive, and sometimes for pay.

entry.ety: Named after the discoverer, Charles Hatchett
entry.def: Mineral tallow; a waxy or spermaceti-like substance, commonly of a greenish yellow color.
A mode of execution in engraving, drawing, and miniature painting, in which shading is produced by lines crossing each other at angles more or less acute; -- called also crosshatching.

sn.def: A sort of panel, upon which the arms of a deceased person are temporarily displayed, -- usually on the walls of his dwelling. It is lozenge-shaped or square, but is hung cornerwise. It is used in England as a means of giving public notification of the death of the deceased, his or her rank, whether married, widower, widow, etc. Called also achievement.
sn.q: His obscure funeral; No trophy, sword, or hatchment o'er his bones.

sn.def: A sword or other mark of the profession of arms; in general, a mark of dignity.
sn.q: Let there be deducted, out of our main potation, Five marks in hatchments to adorn this thigh.

entry.def: Same as Hachure.
A square or oblong opening in a deck or floor, affording passage from one deck or story to another; the entrance to a cellar.

entry.usage: Hate is the generic word, and implies that one is inflamed with extreme dislike. We abhor what is deeply repugnant to our sensibilities or feelings. We detest what contradicts so utterly our principles and moral sentiments that we feel bound to lift up our voice against it. What we abominate does equal violence to our moral and religious sentiments. What we loathe is offensive to our own nature, and excites unmingled disgust. Our Savior is said to have hated the deeds of the Nicolaitanes; his language shows that he loathed the lukewarmness of the Laodiceans; he detested the hypocrisy of the scribes and Pharisees; he abhorred the suggestions of the tempter in the wilderness.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hated; p. pr. & vb. n. Hating
entry.ety: OE. haten hatien, AS. hatian; akin to OS. hatan hatōn to be hostile to, D. haten to hate, OHG. hazzēn hazzōn, G. hassen, Icel. & Sw. hata, Dan. hade, Goth. hatan hatjan. √36. Cf. Hate n. Heinous

sn.def: To have a great aversion to, with a strong desire that evil should befall the person toward whom the feeling is directed; to dislike intensely; to detest; as, to hate one's enemies; to hate hypocrisy.
sn.q: Whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer.

sn.def: To be very unwilling; followed by an infinitive, or a substantive clause with that; as, to hate to get into debt; to hate that anything should be wasted.
sn.q: I hate that he should linger here.

sn.def: To love less, relatively.
sn.syn: To Hate Abhor Detest Abominate Loathe.

entry.ety: OE. hate hete, AS. hete; akin to D. haat, G. hass, Icel. hatr, SW. hat, Dan. had, Goth. hatis. Cf. Hate v.
entry.def: Strong aversion coupled with desire that evil should befall the person toward whom the feeling is directed; as exercised toward things, intense dislike; hatred; detestation; -- opposed to love.
entry.q: For in a wink the false love turns to hate.

sn.def: Manifesting hate or hatred; malignant; malevolent.
sn.q: And worse than death, to view with hateful eyes His rival's conquest.

sn.def: Exciting or deserving great dislike, aversion, or disgust; odious.
sn.q: Unhappy, wretched, hateful day!
sn.syn: Odious; detestable; abominable; execrable; loathsome; abhorrent; repugnant; malevolent.

entry.def: Hateful; detestable.
one who arouses hatred for others by speech or writing.
One who hates.
entry.q: An enemy to God, and a hater of all good.

entries.entry: Hath hăth v., 3d pers. sing. pres. of Have, contracted from haveth . Has. Archaic What hath God wrought?

entry.def: A small genus of South American epiphytic or lithophytic cacti.
Having no hat.
a long sturdy pin used by women to secure a hat to their hair.
A hatstand; hattree.

entry.ety: OE. hatred hatreden. See Hate, and cf. Kindred
entry.def: Strong aversion; intense dislike; hate; an affection of the mind awakened by something regarded as evil.
entry.syn: Odium; ill will; enmity; hate; animosity; malevolence; rancor; malignity; detestation; loathing; abhorrence; repugnance; antipathy. See Odium.

entry.def: A stand of wood or iron, with hooks or pegs upon which to hang hats, etc.
pres. & imp. sing. & pl. of Hote, to be called. See Hote.
entry.q: A full perilous place, purgatory it hatte.

entry.def: Covered with a hat.

entry.ety: Prov. E., to entangle; cf. LG. verhaddern, verheddern, verhiddern
entry.def: To tire or worry; -- with out.
One who makes or sells hats.

A New Zealand lizard, which, in anatomical character, differs widely from all other existing lizards. It is the only living representative of the order Rhynchocephala, of which many Mesozoic fossil species are known; -- called also Sphenodon tuatara, and Tuatera.
The business of making hats; also, stuff for hats.

entry.ety: Turk., fr. Ar. khatt a writing + sherīf noble
entry.def: A irrevocable Turkish decree countersigned by the sultan.
A hatstand.
See Habergeon.

entry.ety: OF. hauberc halberc, F. haubert, OHG. halsberc; hals neck + bergan to protect, G. bergen; akin to AS. healsbeorg, Icel. hālsbjörg. See Collar, and Bury v. t.
entry.def: A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of the European Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which is shorter and sometimes sleeveless. By old writers it is often used synonymously with habergeon. See Habergeon.
entry.q: Helm, nor hawberk's twisted mail.

entry.ety: Named after Von Hauer , of Vienna
entry.def: Native sulphide of manganese, a reddish brown or brownish black mineral.
A low-lying meadow by the side of a river.
entry.q: On a haugh or level plain, near to a royal borough.

entry.def: High; elevated; hence, haughty; proud.
In a haughty manner; arrogantly.

entry.usage: Haughtiness Arrogance Disdain. Haughtiness denotes the expression of conscious and proud superiority; arrogance is a disposition to claim for one's self more than is justly due, and enforce it to the utmost; disdain in the exact reverse of condescension toward inferiors, since it expresses and desires others to feel how far below ourselves we consider them. A person is haughty in disposition and demeanor; arrogant in his claims of homage and deference; disdainful even in accepting the deference which his haughtiness leads him arrogantly to exact.
entry.def: The quality of being haughty; disdain; arrogance.

entry.ety: OE. hautein, F. hautain, fr. haut high, OF. also halt, fr. L. altus. See Altitude

sn.def: High; lofty; bold.
sn.q: To measure the most haughty mountain's height.
Equal unto this haughty enterprise.

sn.def: Disdainfully or contemptuously proud; arrogant; overbearing.
sn.q: A woman of a haughty and imperious nature.

sn.def: Indicating haughtiness; as, a haughty carriage.
sn.q: Satan, with vast and haughty strides advanced, Came towering.

entry.cs: To haul over the coals. See under Coal. To haul the wind Naut to turn the head of the ship nearer to the point from which the wind blows.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hauled h�ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Hauling
entry.ety: OE. halen halien, F. haler, of German or Scand. origin; akin to AS. geholian to acquire, get, D. halen to fetch, pull, draw, OHG. holōn halōn, G. holen, Dan. hale to haul, Sw. hala, and to L. calare to call, summon, Gr. kalei^n to call. Cf. Hale v. t. Claim. Class Council Ecclesiastic

sn.def: To pull or draw with force; to drag.
sn.q: Some dance, some haul the rope.
Thither they bent, and hauled their ships to land.
Romp-loving miss Is hauled about in gallantry robust.

sn.def: To transport by drawing, as with horses or oxen; as, to haul logs to a sawmill.
sn.q: When I was seven or eight years of age, I began hauling all the wood used in the house and shops.

cs.cd: to shift to any point of the compass; -- said of the wind.
to sail closer to the wind, in order to get farther away from anything; hence, to withdraw; to draw back.

sn.def: To change the direction of a ship by hauling the wind. See under Haul v. t.
sn.q: I . . . hauled up for it, and found it to be an island.

sn.def: To pull apart, as oxen sometimes do when yoked.
A pulling with force; a violent pull.
A single draught of a net; as, to catch a hundred fish at a haul .
That which is caught, taken, or gained at once, as by hauling a net.
Transportation by hauling; the distance through which anything is hauled, as freight in a railroad car; as, a long haul or short haul .
A bundle of about four hundred threads, to be tarred.

entry.def: A bargelike vessel with steel hull, large hatchways, and coal transporters, for coaling war vessels from its own hold or from other colliers.
Act of hauling; as, the haulage of cars by an engine; charge for hauling.

A trucking company; a freight transporter using trucks.

entry.def: a haulage contractor.

entry.ety: OE. halm, AS. healm; akin to D., G., Dan., & Sw. halm, Icel. hālmr, L. calamus reed, cane, stalk, Gr. kalamo`s. Cf. Excel Culminate Culm Shawm Calamus
entry.def: The denuded stems or stalks of such crops as buckwheat and the cereal grains, beans, etc.; straw.

See Halse.

entry.ety: OF. hault, F. haut. See Haughty

entry.def: See Haulm, stalk.
To enhance.

entry.cs: Haunch bone. See Innominate bone, under Innominate. Haunches of an arch Arch the parts on each side of the crown of an arch. (See Crown n., 11.) Each haunch may be considered as from one half to two thirds of the half arch.
entry.ety: F. hanche, of German origin; cf. OD. hancke hencke, and also OHG. ancha; prob. not akin to E. ankle

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Haunted; p. pr. & vb. n. Haunting

sn.def: To frequent; to resort to frequently; to visit pertinaciously or intrusively; to intrude upon.

Those cares that haunt the court and town.

sn.def: To inhabit or frequent as a specter; to visit as a ghost or apparition; -- said of spirits or ghosts, especially of dead people; as, the murdered man haunts the house where he died.
sn.q: Foul spirits haunt my resting place.

sn.def: To practice; to devote one's self to.
sn.q: That other merchandise that men haunt with fraud . . . is cursed.

sn.q: Haunt thyself to pity.

entry.def: To persist in staying or visiting.
entry.q: I've charged thee not to haunt about my doors.

entry.note: ☞ In Old English the place occupied by any one as a dwelling or in his business was called a haunt.
Often used figuratively.The household nook, The haunt of all affections pure. Keble. The feeble soul, a haunt of fears. Tennyson.

sn.def: A place to which one frequently resorts; as, drinking saloons are the haunts of tipplers; a den is the haunt of wild beasts.
The habit of resorting to a place.
sn.q: The haunt you have got about the courts.

sn.def: Practice; skill.
sn.q: Of clothmaking she hadde such an haunt.

entry.ety: L. hauriens, p. pr. of haurire to breathe
entry.def: In pale, with the head in chief; -- said of the figure of a fish, as if rising for air.
A large sturgeon (Acipenser huso syn. Huso huso) from the region of the Black Sea; also called Beluga. It is sometimes twelve feet long, and provides the highest quality caviar.
A kind of graduated breech sight for a small arm, or a cannon.

entry.ety: NL., fr. haustellum, fr. L. haurire haustum, to draw water, to swallow. See Exhaust

Provided with a haustellum, or sucking proboscis.

‖Haus*to"ri*um h�s*tō"rĭ*ŭm n.; pl.Haustoria h�s*tō"rĭ*ȧ. LL., a well, fr. L. haurire haustum, to drink Bot One of the suckerlike rootlets of such plants as the dodder and ivy.

sn.def: A wind instrument, sounded through a reed, and similar in shape to the clarinet, but with a thinner tone. Now more commonly called oboe. See Illust. of Oboe.

entries.entry:
Ha*van"a hȧ*văn"ȧ prop. a. Of or pertaining to Havana, the capital of the island of Cuba; as, an Havana cigar ; Havannah
n. An Havana cigar.
Young Frank Clavering stole his father's Havannahs, and . . . smoked them in the stable.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Havana, in Cuba.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant, or the people, of Havana.

entry.note: ☞ Have, as an auxiliary verb, is used with the past participle to form preterit tenses; as, I have loved; I shall have eaten. Originally it was used only with the participle of transitive verbs, and denoted the possession of the object in the state indicated by the participle; as, I have conquered him, I have or hold him in a conquered state; but it has long since lost this independent significance, and is used with the participles both of transitive and intransitive verbs as a device for expressing past time. Had is used, especially in poetry, for would have or should have.
entry.cs:
To have a care to take care; to be on one's guard. To have a man out to engage (one) in a duel. To have donewith). See under Do v. i.
To have it out to speak freely; to bring an affair to a conclusion. To have on to wear. To have to do with. See under Do, v. t.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Had hăd; p. pr. & vb. n. Having. Indic. present, I have, thou hast, he has; we, ye, they have
entry.ety: OE. haven habben, AS. habbenimperf. hæfde, p. p. gehæfd); akin to OS. hebbian, D. hebben, OFries. hebba, OHG. habēn, G. haben, Icel. hafa, Sw. hafva, Dan. have, Goth. haban, and prob. to L. habere, whence F. avoir. Cf. Able Avoirdupois Binnacle Habit

sn.def: To hold in possession or control; to own; as, he has a farm.
To possess, as something which appertains to, is connected with, or affects, one.
sn.q: The earth hath bubbles, as the water has.
He had a fever late.

sn.def: To accept possession of; to take or accept.
sn.q: Break thy mind to me in broken English; wilt thou have me?

sn.def: To get possession of; to obtain; to get.
To cause or procure to be; to effect; to exact; to desire; to require.
sn.q: I had the church accurately described to me.
Wouldst thou have me turn traitor also?

sn.def: To bear, as young; as, she has just had a child.
To hold, regard, or esteem.
sn.q: Of them shall I be had in honor.

sn.def: To cause or force to go; to take.
sn.q: The starshaveus to bed.
Haveout all men from me.

sn.def: To take or hold (one's self); to proceed promptly; -- used reflexively, often with ellipsis of the pronoun; as, to have after one; to have at one or at a thing, i. e., to aim at one or at a thing; to attack; to have with a companion.
To be under necessity or obligation; to be compelled; followed by an infinitive.
sn.q: Science has, and will long have, to be a divider and a separatist.
The laws of philology have to be established by external comparison and induction.

sn.def: To understand.
sn.q: You have me, have you not?

sn.def: To put in an awkward position; to have the advantage of; as, that is where he had him.
sn.q: Myself for such a face had boldly died.
sn.syn: To possess; to own. See Possess.

entry.def: Having little or nothing.

entry.ety: From Havelock, an English general distinguished in India in the rebellion of 1857
entry.def: A light cloth covering for the head and neck, used by soldiers as a protection from sunstroke.

entry.ety: AS. hæfene; akin to D. & LG. haven, G. hafen, MHG. habe, Dan. havn, Icel. höfn, Sw. hamn; akin to E. have, and hence orig., a holder; or to heavesee Heave); or akin to AS. hæf sea, Icel. & Sw. haf, Dan. hav, which is perh. akin to E. heave

sn.def: A bay, recess, or inlet of the sea, or the mouth of a river, which affords anchorage and shelter for shipping; a harbor; a port.
sn.q: What shipping and what lading 's in our haven.
Their haven under the hill.

sn.def: A place of safety; a shelter; an asylum.
sn.q: The haven, or the rock of love.

entry.def: To shelter, as in a haven.
Harbor dues; port dues.
Sheltered in a haven.
entry.q: Blissful havened both from joy and pain.

entry.def: A harbor master.
A possessor; a holder.

cs.cd: oaten bread.
oaten cake.
the wild oat.
oatmeal.

entry.ety: D. haver; akin to G. haber
entry.def: The oat; oats.
To maunder; to talk foolishly; to chatter.

entry.ety: F. havresac, G. habersack, sack for oats. See 2d Haver, and Sack a bag

sn.def: A bag for oats or oatmeal.
A bag or case, usually of stout cloth, in which a soldier carries his rations when on a march; -- distinguished from knapsack.
A gunner's case or bag used to carry cartridges from the ammunition chest to the piece in loading.

cs.cd: the small canals through which the blood vessels ramify in bone.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Clopton Havers, an English physician of the seventeenth century.

entry.ety: Formerly haver, prob. fr. Half; cf. L. semimas emasculated, prop., half male
entry.def: A castrated deer.
entry.q: Haviers, or stags which have been gelded when young, have no horns.

cs.cd: a native sergeant major in the East Indian army.

entry.def: In the British Indian armies, a noncommissioned officer of native soldiers, corresponding to a sergeant.
Possession; goods; estate.
entry.q: I 'll lend you something; my having is not much.

entry.ety: OE. havour, a corruption of OF. aveir avoir, a having, of same origin as E. aver a work horse. The h is due to confusion with E. have
entry.def: Behavior; demeanor.

entry.ety: W. hafog devastation, havoc; or, if this be itself fr. E. havoc, cf. OE. havot, or AS. hafoc hawk, which is a cruel or rapacious bird, or F. hai, voux! a cry to hounds
entry.def: Wide and general destruction; devastation; waste.
entry.q: As for Saul, he made havoc of the church.
Ye gods, what havoc does ambition make Among your works!

entry.def: To devastate; to destroy; to lay waste.
entry.q: To waste and havoc yonder world.

entry.def: A cry in war as the signal for indiscriminate slaughter.
entry.q: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant.
Cry 'havoc,' and let slip the dogs of war!

entry.ety: OE. hawe, AS. haga; akin to D. haag headge, G. hag hecke, Icel. hagi pasture, Sw. hage, Dan. have garden. √12. Cf. Haggard Ha-ha Haugh Hedge

sn.def: A hedge; an inclosed garden or yard.
sn.q: And eke there was a polecat in his haw.

sn.def: The fruit of the hawthorn.

entry.def: The third eyelid, or nictitating membrane. See Nictitating membrane, under Nictitate.

entry.ety: Cf. ha an interjection of wonder, surprise, or hesitation
entry.def: An intermission or hesitation of speech, with a sound somewhat like haw! also, the sound so made.
entry.q: Hums orhaws.

cs.cd: speaking hesitantly and inarticulately, with numerous pauses and interjections.

entry.def: To stop, in speaking, with a sound like haw; to speak with interruption and hesitation.
entry.q: Cut it short; don't prose -- don't hum and haw.

cs.mcol: To haw and geeorTo haw and gee about
cs.cd: to go from one thing to another without good reason; to have no settled purpose; to be irresolute or unstable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hawed h�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Hawing
entry.ety: Perhaps connected with here hither; cf., however, F. huhau hurhau hue, interj. used in turning a horse to the right, G. hott hü, interj. used in calling to a horse
entry.def: To turn to the near side, or toward the driver; -- said of cattle or a team: a word used by teamsters in guiding their teams, and most frequently in the imperative. See Gee.

cs.mcol: To haw and geeorTo haw and gee about
cs.cd: to lead this way and that at will; to lead by the nose; to master or control.

entry.def: To cause to turn, as a team, to the near side, or toward the driver; as, to haw a team of oxen.
Belonging to Hawaii or the Sandwich Islands, or to the people of Hawaii.
Probably, the baked berry of the hawthorn tree, that is, coarse fare. See 1st Haw, 2.
The common European grosbeak (Coccothraustes vulgaris); -- called also cherry finch, and coble.

sn.def: See Ha-ha.
a loud laugh that sounds like a horse neighing.
a sunken fence (so as not to interfere with the view).

entry.def: To laugh boisterously.
entry.q: We haw-haw'd, I tell you, for more than half an hour.

entry.note: ☞ Among the common American species are the red-tailed hawk (Buteo borealis); the red-shouldered (Buteo lineatus); the broad-winged (Buteo Pennsylvanicus); the rough-legged (Archibuteo lagopus); the sharp-shinned (Accipiter fuscus). See Fishhawk Goshawk Marsh hawk, under Marsh Night hawk, under Night.
entry.cs: Bee hawk Zoöl the honey buzzard. Eagle hawk. See under Eagle. Hawk eagle Zoöl an Asiatic bird of the genus Spizætus, or Limnætus, intermediate between the hawks and eagles. There are several species. Hawk fly Zoöl a voracious fly of the family Asilidæ. See Hornet fly, under Hornet. Hawk moth. Zoöl See Hawk moth, in the Vocabulary. Hawk owl. Zoöl A northern owl (Surnia ulula) of Europe and America. It flies by day, and in some respects resembles the hawks. An owl of India (Ninox scutellatus). Hawk's bill Horology the pawl for the rack, in the striking mechanism of a clock.
entry.ety: OE. haukprob. fr. Icel.), havek, AS. hafoc heafoc; akin to D. havik, OHG. habuh, G. habicht, Icel. haukr, Sw. hök, Dan. hög, prob. from the root of E. heave
entry.def: One of numerous species and genera of rapacious birds of the family Falconidæ. They differ from the true falcons in lacking the prominent tooth and notch of the bill, and in having shorter and less pointed wings. Many are of large size and grade into the eagles. Some, as the goshawk, were formerly trained like falcons. In a more general sense the word is not infrequently applied, also, to true falcons, as the sparrow hawk, pigeon hawk, duck hawk, and prairie hawk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hawked h�kt; p. pr. & vb. n. Hawking

sn.def: To catch, or attempt to catch, birds by means of hawks trained for the purpose, and let loose on the prey; to practice falconry.
sn.q: A falconer Henry is, when Emma hawks.

sn.def: To make an attack while on the wing; to soar and strike like a hawk; -- generally with at; as, to hawk at flies.
sn.q: A falcon, towering in her pride of place, Was by a mousing owl hawked at and killed.

entry.def: To clear the throat with an audible sound by forcing an expiratory current of air through the narrow passage between the depressed soft palate and the root of the tongue, thus aiding in the removal of foreign substances.
To raise by hawking, as phlegm.
An effort to force up phlegm from the throat, accompanied with noise.

entry.ety: Akin to D. hauker a hawker, G. höken höcken, to higgle, to retail, höke höker, a higgler, huckster. See Huckster
entry.def: To offer for sale by outcry in the street; to carry (merchandise) about from place to place for sale; to peddle; as, to hawk goods or pamphlets.
entry.q: His works were hawked in every street.

cs.cd: an attendant on a plasterer to supply him with mortar.

entry.def: A small board, with a handle on the under side, to hold mortar.
A sea turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), which yields the best quality of tortoise shell; -- called also caret.
entry.syn: hawksbill turtle, hawkbill, tortoiseshell turtle, Eretmochelys imbricata.

entry.def: The fall dandelion (Leontodon autumnale).
Curved like a hawk's bill; crooked.
One who sells wares by crying them in the street; hence, a peddler or a packman.
To sell goods by outcry in the street.
A falconer.
See Hockey.
Having very keen vision; sharp-sighted; discerning.

sn.def: alert to possible danger.
sn.syn: argus-eyed, open-eyed, unsleeping, vigilant, wary, watchful.

entries.entry: Hawk"eye` State. Iowa; -- a nickname of obscure origin.

Hawk" moth` ☞ The larvæ of several species of hawk moths feed on grapevines. The elm-tree hawk moth is Ceratomia Amyntor . mŏth`; 115. Zoöl Any moth of the family Sphingidæ, of which there are numerous genera and species. They are large, handsome moths with long narrow forewings capable of powerful flight and hovering over flowers to feed. They fly mostly at twilight and hover about flowers like a humming bird, sucking the honey by means of a long, slender proboscis. The larvæ are large, hairless caterpillars ornamented with green and other bright colors, and often with a caudal spine. See Sphinx, also Tobacco worm, and Tomato worm. hawk moth, sphingid, sphinx moth, hummingbird moth. Tobacco Hawk Moth (Macrosila Carolina), and its Larva, the Tobacco Worm.

entry.def: Any of various plants of the genus Crepis having loose heads of yellow flowers on top of a long branched leafy stem; found in the Northern hemisphere.
See hawkbill.
entry.syn: hawksbill turtle, hawkbill, tortoiseshell turtle, Eretmochelys imbricata.

entry.def: A plant of the genus Hieracium; -- so called from the ancient belief that birds of prey used its juice to strengthen their vision.
A plant of the genus Senecio Senecio hieracifolius).
See Haulm, straw.
To lounge; to loiter.

entry.cs: Athwart hawse. See under Athwart. Foul hawse a hawse in which the cables cross each other, or are twisted together. Hawse block a block used to stop up a hawse hole at sea; -- called also hawse plug. Hawse piece one of the foremost timbers of a ship, through which the hawse hole is cut. Hawse plug. Same as Hawse blockabove). To come in at the hawse holes to enter the naval service at the lowest grade. Cant To freshen the hawse to veer out a little more cable and bring the chafe and strain on another part.
entry.ety: Orig. a hawse hole, or hole in the bow of the ship; cf. Icel. hals hāls, neck, part of the bows of a ship, AS. heals neck. See Collar, and cf. Halse to embrace

sn.def: A hawse hole.

sd.def: The situation of the cables when a vessel is moored with two anchors, one on the starboard, the other on the port bow.
The distance ahead to which the cables usually extend; as, the ship has a clear or open hawse, or a foul hawse; to anchor in our hawse, or athwart hawse.
That part of a vessel's bow in which are the hawse holes for the cables.

entry.def: a hole in the bow of a ship, through which the anchor rope or cable passes.

entry.note: ☞ Three hawsers twisted together make a cable; but it nautical usage the distinction between cable and hawser is often one of size rather than of manufacture.

cs.cd: a calking iron.

entry.ety: From F. hausser to lift, raise (cf. OF. hausserée towpath, towing, F. haussière hawser), LL. altiare, fr. L. altus high. See Haughty
entry.def: A large rope made of three strands each containing many yarns.
Made in the manner of a hawser. Cf. Cable-laid, and see Illust. of Cordage.

entry.ety: AS. hagaþorn hægþorn. See Haw a hedge, and Thorn
entry.def: A thorny shrub or tree (the Cratægus oxyacantha), having deeply lobed, shining leaves, small, roselike, fragrant flowers, and a fruit called haw. It is much used in Europe for hedges, and for standards in gardens. The American hawthorn is Cratægus cordata, which has the leaves but little lobed.
entry.q: Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade To shepherds?

cs.cd: to dance in a ring.

entry.ety: AS. hege: cf. F. haie, of German origin. See Haw a hedge, Hedge

sn.def: A hedge.
A net set around the haunt of an animal, especially of a rabbit.

entry.def: To lay snares for rabbits.

cs.cd: a canvas covering for a haycock.

nasal catarrh accompanied with fever, and sometimes with paroxysms of dyspnœa, to which some persons are subject in the spring and summer seasons. It has been attributed to the effluvium from hay, and to the pollen of certain plants. It is also called hay asthma hay cold rose cold, and rose fever.
a sharp instrument used in cutting hay out of a stack or mow.
a press for baling loose hay.
the juice of hay extracted by boiling, used as food for cattle, etc.
a machine for spreading and turning new-mown hay. See Tedder.

entry.ety: OE. hei, AS. hēg; akin to D. hooi, OHG. hewi houwi, G. heu, Dan. & Sw. hö, Icel. hey ha, Goth. hawi grass, fr. the root of E. hew. See Hew to cut
entry.def: Grass cut and cured for fodder.
entry.q: Make hay while the sun shines.
Hay may be dried too much as well as too little.

entry.def: To cut and cure grass for hay.
The European spotted flycatcher.
The European blackcap.

entry.ety: See Hay hedge, and Bote, and cf. Hedgebote
entry.def: An allowance of wood to a tenant for repairing his hedges or fences; hedgebote. See Bote.
A conical pile or heap of hay in the field.
entry.q: The tanned haycock in the mead.

entry.def: A machine in which hay is chopped short, as fodder for cattle.
A field where grass for hay has been cut; a meadow.

cs.cd: a contrivance for unloading hay from the cart and depositing it in the loft, or on a mow, by horse power.

entry.def: A fork for pitching and tedding hay.
A loft or scaffold for hay.

sn.def: One who cuts and cures hay.
A machine for curing hay in rainy weather.
A forceful punch that results in someone being knocked down or knocked out; as, he delivered a haymaker to his opponent's jaw.

entry.def: The operation or work of cutting grass and curing it for hay.

sn.def: A mow or mass of hay laid up in a barn for preservation.
The place in a barn where hay is deposited.

entry.def: A frame mounted on the running gear of a wagon, and used in hauling hay, straw, sheaves, etc.; -- called also hay rigging and hay rig.
A rake for collecting hay; especially, a large rake drawn by a horse or horses.
A heap or pile of hay, usually covered with thatch for preservation in the open air.
a frame attached to a wagon to increase the amount of hay it can carry.

sn.def: a rural, unsophisticated person; also used in an extended sense for one who is not very intelligent or uninterested in culture.
sn.syn: yokel, rube, hick, yahoo, bumpkin, chawbacon.

sn.def: Seed from grass, especially that which falls out of hay.

entry.def: A stack or conical pile of hay in the open air.
A stalk of hay.
Hawthorn.
Of or pertaining to Haiti; now usually written Haitian.
An officer who is appointed to guard hedges, and to keep cattle from breaking or cropping them, and whose further duty it is to impound animals found running at large.

cs.cd: a table on which hazard is played, or any game of chance for stakes.
to take the chance or risk.
at risk; liable to suffer damage or loss.

entry.ety: F. hasard, Sp. azar an unforeseen disaster or accident, an unfortunate card or throw at dice, prob. fr. Ar. zahr zār, a die, which, with the article al the, would give azzahr azzār

sn.def: A game of chance played with dice.
The uncertain result of throwing a die; hence, a fortuitous event; chance; accident; casualty.
sn.q: I will stand the hazard of the die.

sn.def: Risk; danger; peril; as, he encountered the enemy at the hazard of his reputation and life.
sn.q: Men are led on from one stage of life to another in a condition of the utmost hazard.

sn.def: Holing a ball, whether the object ball (winning hazard) or the player's ball (losing hazard).
Anything that is hazarded or risked, as the stakes in gaming.
sn.q: Your latterhazard.

sn.def: Any place into which the ball may not be safely played, such as bunkers, furze, water, sand, or other kind of bad ground.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hazarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Hazarding
entry.ety: Cf. F. hasarder. See Hazard n.

sn.def: To expose to the operation of chance; to put in danger of loss or injury; to venture; to risk.
sn.q: Men hazard nothing by a course of evangelical obedience.
He hazards his neck to the halter.

sn.def: To venture to incur, or bring on.
sn.q: I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.
They hazard to cut their feet.
sn.syn: To venture; risk; jeopard; peril; endanger.

entry.def: To try the chance; to encounter risk or danger.

sn.def: Liable to hazard or chance; uncertain; risky.
Such as can be hazarded or risked.
A player at the game of hazard; a gamester.
One who hazards or ventures.

entry.def: A hazardous attempt or situation; hazard.
entry.q: Herself had run into that hazardize.

entry.def: Exposed to hazard; dangerous; risky.
entry.q: To enterprise so hazardous and high!
entry.syn: Perilous; dangerous; bold; daring; adventurous; venturesome; precarious; uncertain.

entry.def: the state of being dangerous.

sn.def: Playing at hazard; gaming; gambling.
Rashness; temerity.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. höss gray; akin to AS. hasu heasu, gray; or Armor. aézen ézen, warm vapor, exhalation, zephyr

sn.def: Light vapor or smoke in the air which more or less impedes vision, with little or no dampness; a lack of transparency in the air; hence, figuratively, obscurity; dimness.
sn.q: O'er the sky The silvery haze of summer drawn.
Above the world's uncertain haze.

sn.def: A state of confusion, uncertainty, or vagueness of thought or perception; as, after the explosion, people were wandering around in a haze .

entry.def: To be hazy, or thick with haze.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hazed hāzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hazing
entry.ety: Cf. Sw. haza to hamstring, fr. has hough, OD. hæssen ham

sn.def: To harass by exacting unnecessary, disagreeable, or difficult work.

To harass or annoy by playing abusive or shameful tricks upon; to humiliate by practical jokes; -- used esp. of college students, as an initiation rite into a fraternity or other group; as, the sophomores hazed a freshman.

entry.cs: Hazel earth soil suitable for the hazel; a fertile loam. Hazel grouse Zoöl a European grouse (Bonasa betulina), allied to the American ruffed grouse. Hazel hoe a kind of grub hoe. Witch hazel. See Witch-hazel, and Hamamelis.
entry.ety: OE. hasel, AS. hæsel; akin to D. hazelaar, G. hazel, OHG. hasal hasala, Icel. hasl, Dan & Sw. hassel, L. corylus, for cosylus

sn.def: A shrub or small tree of the genus Corylus, as the Corylus avellana, bearing a nut containing a kernel of a mild, farinaceous taste; the filbert. The American species are Corylus Americana, which produces the common hazelnut, and Corylus rostrata. See Filbert.
A miner's name for freestone.
Consisting of hazels, or of the wood of the hazel; pertaining to, or derived from, the hazel; as, a hazel wand.
sn.q: I sit me down beside the hazel grove.

sn.def: Of a light brown color, like the hazelnut.
sn.q: Thou hasthazeleyes.

entry.def: Destitute of haze.
Of the color of the hazelnut; of a light brown.
The nut of the hazel.
A reddish-brown wood and lumber from the heartwood of the sweet gum tree.
entry.syn: sweet gum, satin walnut, red gum.

entry.def: The asarabacca.
In a hazy manner; mistily; obscurely; confusedly.
The quality or state of being hazy.
To make dry; to dry.

sn.def: Thick with haze; somewhat obscured with haze; not clear or transparent.
sn.q: A tender,hazybrightness.

sn.def: Obscure; confused; not clear; as, a hazy argument; a hazy intellect.

entry.def: The hydrogen bomb, a thermonuclear weapon that releases atomic energy by union of hydrogen nuclei at high temperatures to form helium. The force of its explosion may range from one to hundreds of megatons of TNT equivalent.
entry.syn: hydrogen bomb, fusion bomb, thermonuclear bomb.

entry.def: High density lipoprotein, a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; high levels are thought to be associated with decreased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis; sometimes called good cholesterol. Contrasted with LDL.

entry.note: ☞ When a collective noun or a class is referred to, he is of common gender. In early English, he referred to a feminine or neuter noun, or to one in the plural, as well as to noun in the masculine singular. In composition, he denotes a male animal; as, a he-goat.
entry.nmorph: nom. He; poss. His hĭz; obj. Him hĭm; pl. nom. They �ā; poss. Their or Theirs �ârz or �ārz; obj. Them �ĕm
entry.ety: AS. hē, masc., heó, fem., hit, neut.; pl. hī, or hie hig; akin to OFries. hi, D. hij, OS. he hi, G. heute to-day, Goth. himma, dat. masc., this, hina, accus. masc., and hita, accus. neut., and prob. to L. his this. √183. Cf. It

sn.def: The man or male being (or object personified to which the masculine gender is assigned), previously designated; a pronoun of the masculine gender, usually referring to a specified subject already indicated.
sn.q: Thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.
Thou shalt fear the Lord thy God; him shalt thou serve.

sn.def: Any one; the man or person; -- used indefinitely, and usually followed by a relative pronoun.
sn.q: He that walketh with wise men shall be wise.

sn.def: Man; a male; any male person; -- in this sense used substantively.
sn.q: I stand to answer thee, Or any he, the proudest of thy sort.

entry.def: The chemical symbol for helium.
A variant of -hood.

entry.note: ☞ Head is often used adjectively or in self-explaining combinations; as, head gear or headgear, head rest. Cf. Head a.
entry.cs:
A buck of the first head a male fallow deer in its fifth year, when it attains its complete set of antlers. Shak. By the head. Naut See under By.
Elevator head Feed head, etc. See under Elevator Feed, etc. From head to foot through the whole length of a man; completely; throughout. “Arm me, audacity, from head to foot.” Shak. Head and ears with the whole person; deeply; completely; as, he was head and ears in debt or in trouble. Colloq Head fast. Naut See 5th Fast. Head kidney Anat the most anterior of the three pairs of embryonic renal organs developed in most vertebrates; the pronephros. Head money a capitation tax; a poll tax. Milton. Head pence a poll tax. Obs Head sea a sea that meets the head of a vessel or rolls against her course. Head and shoulders. By force; violently; as, to drag one, head and shoulders. “They bring in every figure of speech, head and shoulders.” Felton. By the height of the head and shoulders; hence, by a great degree or space; by far; much; as, he is head and shoulders above them.
Heads or tailsorHead or tail
this side or that side; this thing or that; -- a phrase used in throwing a coin to decide a choice, question, or stake, head being the side of the coin bearing the effigy or principal figure (or, in case there is no head or face on either side, that side which has the date on it), and tail the other side. Neither head nor tail neither beginning nor end; neither this thing nor that; nothing distinct or definite; -- a phrase used in speaking of what is indefinite or confused; as, they made neither head nor tail of the matter. Colloq Head wind a wind that blows in a direction opposite the vessel's course. off the top of my head from quick recollection, or as an approximation; without research or calculation; -- a phrase used when giving quick and approximate answers to questions, to indicate that a response is not necessarily accurate. Out of one's own head according to one's own idea; without advice or coöperation of another. Over the head of beyond the comprehension of. M. Arnold. to go over the head of (a person to appeal to a person superior to (a person) in line of command. To be out of one's head to be temporarily insane. To come or draw to a head. See under Come Draw.
To give one the headorTo give head
to let go, or to give up, control; to free from restraint; to give license. “He gave his able horse the head.” Shak. “He has so long given his unruly passions their head.” South. To his head before his face. “An uncivil answer from a son to a father, from an obliged person to a benefactor, is a greater indecency than if an enemy should storm his house or revile him to his head.” Jer. Taylor. To lay heads together to consult; to conspire. To lose one's head to lose presence of mind.
To make headorTo make head against
to resist with success; to advance. To show one's head to appear. Shak. To turn head to turn the face or front. “The ravishers turn head, the fight renews.” Dryden.
entry.ety: OE. hed heved heaved, AS. heáfod; akin to D. hoofd, OHG. houbit, G. haupt, Icel. höfuð, Sw. hufvud, Dan. hoved, Goth. haubiþ. The word does not correspond regularly to L. caput head (cf. E. Chief Cadet Capital), and its origin is unknown

sn.def: The anterior or superior part of an animal, containing the brain, or chief ganglia of the nervous system, the mouth, and in the higher animals, the chief sensory organs; poll; cephalon.

The uppermost, foremost, or most important part of an inanimate object; such a part as may be considered to resemble the head of an animal; often, also, the larger, thicker, or heavier part or extremity, in distinction from the smaller or thinner part, or from the point or edge; as, the head of a cane, a nail, a spear, an ax, a mast, a sail, a ship; that which covers and closes the top or the end of a hollow vessel; as, the head of a cask or a steam boiler.
The place where the head should go; as, the head of a bed, of a grave, etc.; the head of a carriage, that is, the hood which covers the head.
The most prominent or important member of any organized body; the chief; the leader; as, the head of a college, a school, a church, a state, and the like.
sn.q: Their princes andheads.
The heads of the chief sects of philosophy.
Your head I him appoint.

sn.def: The place or honor, or of command; the most important or foremost position; the front; as, the head of the table; the head of a column of soldiers.
sn.q: An army of fourscore thousand troops, with the duke of Marlborough at the head of them.

sn.def: Each one among many; an individual; -- often used in a plural sense; as, a thousand head of cattle.
sn.q: It there be six millions of people, there are about four acres for every head.

sn.def: The seat of the intellect; the brain; the understanding; the mental faculties; as, a good head, that is, a good mind; it never entered his head, it did not occur to him; of his own head, of his own thought or will.
sn.q: Men who had lost both head and heart.

sn.def: The source, fountain, spring, or beginning, as of a stream or river; as, the head of the Nile; hence, the altitude of the source, or the height of the surface, as of water, above a given place, as above an orifice at which it issues, and the pressure resulting from the height or from motion; sometimes also, the quantity in reserve; as, a mill or reservoir has a good head of water, or ten feet head ; also, that part of a gulf or bay most remote from the outlet or the sea.
A headland; a promontory; as, Gay Head .
A separate part, or topic, of a discourse; a theme to be expanded; a subdivision; as, the heads of a sermon.
Culminating point or crisis; hence, strength; force; height.
sn.q: Ere foul sin, gathering head, shall break into corruption.
The indisposition which has long hung upon me, is at last grown to such a head, that it must quickly make an end of me or of itself.

sn.def: Power; armed force.
sn.q: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head.

sn.def: A headdress; a covering of the head; as, a laced head; a head of hair.
An ear of wheat, barley, or of one of the other small cereals.

sd.def: A dense cluster of flowers, as in clover, daisies, thistles; a capitulum.
A dense, compact mass of leaves, as in a cabbage or a lettuce plant.

sn.def: The antlers of a deer.
A rounded mass of foam which rises on a pot of beer or other effervescing liquor.
Tiles laid at the eaves of a house.

entry.def: Principal; chief; leading; first; as, the head master of a school; the head man of a tribe; a head chorister; a head cook.

entry.cs: To head off to intercept; to get before; as, an officer heads off a thief who is escaping. “We'll head them off at the pass.”To head up to close, as a cask or barrel, by fitting a head to. To serve as the leader of; as, to head up a team of investigators.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Headed; p. pr. & vb. n. Heading

sn.def: To be at the head of; to put one's self at the head of; to lead; to direct; to act as leader to; as, to head an army, an expedition, or a riot.
To form a head to; to fit or furnish with a head; as, to head a nail.
To behead; to decapitate.
To cut off the top of; to lop off; as, to head trees.
To go in front of; to get in the front of, so as to hinder or stop; to oppose; hence, to check or restrain; as, to head a drove of cattle; to head a person; the wind heads a ship.
To set on the head; as, to head a cask.
To originate; to spring; to have its source, as a river.
sn.q: A broad river, that heads in the great Blue Ridge.

sn.def: To go or point in a certain direction; to tend; as, how does the ship head?
To form a head; as, this kind of cabbage heads early.

entry.def: Pain in the head; cephalalgia.
entry.q: Headachesand shivering fits.

entry.def: Afflicted with headache.

sn.def: A fillet; a band for the head.
sn.q: Theheadbandsand the tablets.

sn.def: The band at each end of the back of a book.

entry.def: A board or boarding which marks or forms the head of anything; as, the headboard of a bed; the headboard of a grave.

sn.def: The chief of a frankpledge, tithing, or decennary, consisting of ten families; -- called also borsholder boroughhead boroughholder, and sometimes tithingman. See Borsholder.
A petty constable.

entry.def: A dish made of portions of the head, or head and feet, of swine, cut up fine, seasoned, and pressed into a cheeselike mass.

sn.def: A covering or ornament for the head; a headtire; as, chiefs among the plains Indians had elaborate long headdresses with many feathers.
