entry.def: Leadership; preponderant influence or authority; -- usually applied to the relation of a government or state to its neighbors or confederates.
A hedge.

entry.note: ☞ The starting point of the Era was made to begin, not from the date of the flight, but from the first day of the Arabic year, which corresponds to July 16, a. d. 622.
entry.def: The flight of Mohammed from Mecca, September 13, a. d. 622 (subsequently established as the first year of the Moslem era); hence, any flight or exodus regarded as like that of Mohammed.
A deciduous much-branched shrub (Lyonia ligustrina) with dense downy panicles of small bell-shaped white flowers.
entry.syn: maleberry, male berry, privet andromeda, Lyonia ligustrina.

entry.ety: OE. hayfare, AS. heáhfore heáfore; the second part of this word seems akin to AS. fearr bull, ox; akin to OHG. farro, G. farre, D. vaars, heifer, G. färse, and perh. to Gr. �, �, calf, heifer
entry.def: A young cow.
An exclamation of surprise, joy, dejection, uneasiness, weariness, etc.

cs.cd: aloud.
cs.q: He] spake these same words, all on hight.

entry.ety: OE. heighte heght heighthe, AS. heáhðu hēhðu fr. heah high; akin to D. hoogte, Sw. höjd, Dan. höide, Icel. hæð, Goth. hauhiþa. See High

sn.def: The condition of being high; elevated position.
sn.q: Behold the height of the stars, how high they are!

sn.def: The distance to which anything rises above its foot, above that on which in stands, above the earth, or above the level of the sea; altitude; the measure upward from a surface, as the floor or the ground, of an animal, especially of a man; stature.
sn.q: Goliath'sheight was six cubits and a span.

sn.def: Degree of latitude either north or south.
sn.q: Guinea lieth to the north sea, in the same height as Peru to the south.

sn.def: That which is elevated; an eminence; a hill or mountain; as, Alpine heights .
Elevation in excellence of any kind, as in power, learning, arts; also, an advanced degree of social rank; preëminence or distinction in society; prominence.
sn.q: Measure your mind's height by the shade it casts.
All would in his power hold, all make his subjects.

sn.def: Progress toward eminence; grade; degree.
sn.q: Social duties are carried to greater heights, and enforced with stronger motives by the principles of our religion.

An early photographic process invented by Nicéphore Niepce, and still used in photo-engraving. It consists essentially in exposing under a design or in a camera a polished metal plate coated with a preparation of asphalt, and subsequently treating the plate with a suitable solvent. The light renders insoluble those parts of the film which is strikes, and so a permanent image is formed, which can be etched upon the plate by the use of acid.

An inert, monoatomic, gaseous element occurring in the atmosphere of the sun and stars, and in small quantities in the earth's atmosphere, in several minerals and in certain mineral waters. It is obtained from natural gas in industrial quantities. Symbol, He; atomic number 2; at. wt., 4.0026 (C=12.011). Helium was first detected spectroscopically in the sun by Lockyer in 1868; it was first prepared by Ramsay in 1895. Helium has a density of 1.98 compared with hydrogen, and is more difficult to liquefy than the latter. Chemically, it is an inert noble gas, belonging to the argon group, and cannot be made to form compounds. The helium nucleus is the charged particle which constitutes alpha rays, and helium is therefore formed as a decomposition product of certain radioactive substances such as radium. The normal helium nucleus has two protons and two neutrons, but an isotope with only one neutron is also observed in atmospheric helium at an abundance of 0.013 %. Liquid helium has a boiling point of -268.9° C at atmospheric pressure, and is used for maintaining very low temperatures, both in laboratory experimentation and in commercial applications to maintain superconductivity in low-temperature superconducting devices. Gaseous helium at normal temperatures is used for buoyancy in blimps, dirigibles, and high-altitude balloons, and also for amusement in party balloons.

entry.cs: To help forward to assist in advancing. To help off to help to go or pass away, as time; to assist in removing. Locke. To help on to forward; to promote by aid. To help out to aid, as in delivering from a difficulty, or to aid in completing a design or task. The god of learning and of light Would want a god himself to help him out. Swift. To help over to enable to surmount; as, to help one over an obstacle. To help to to supply with; to furnish with; as, to help one to soup. To help up to help (one) to get up; to assist in rising, as after a fall, and the like. “A man is well holp up that trusts to you.” Shak.
entry.usage: To Help Aid Assist. These words all agree in the idea of affording relief or support to a person under difficulties. Help turns attention especially to the source of relief. If I fall into a pit, I call for help; and he who helps me out does it by an act of his own. Aid turns attention to the other side, and supposes coöperation on the part of him who is relieved; as, he aided me in getting out of the pit; I got out by the aid of a ladder which he brought. Assist has a primary reference to relief afforded by a person who “stands by” in order to relieve. It denotes both help and aid. Thus, we say of a person who is weak, I assisted him upstairs, or, he mounted the stairs by my assistance. When help is used as a noun, it points less distinctively and exclusively to the source of relief, or, in other words, agrees more closely with aid. Thus we say, I got out of a pit by the help of my friend.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Helped hĕlpt Obs. imp. Holp hōlp p. p. Holpen hōl"p'n); p. pr. & vb. n. Helping

entry.q: Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him!

sn.def: a quantity of food served as part of a meal.
the activity of contributing to the fulfillment of a need or furtherance of an effort or purpose.
Destitute of help or strength; unable to help or defend one's self; needing help; feeble; weak; as, a helpless infant.
sn.q: How shall I then your helpless fame defend?

sn.def: Beyond help; irremediable.
sn.q: Some helpless disagreement or dislike, either of mind or body.

sn.def: Bringing no help; unaiding.
sn.q: Yet since the gods have beenHelpless foreseers of my plagues.

sn.def: Unsupplied; destitute; -- with of.
sn.q: Helpless of all that human wants require.

entry.ety: A corruption of the “help meet for him” of Genesis ii. 18. Fitzedward Hall.
entry.def: A helper; a companion; specifically, a wife.
entry.q: In Minorca the ass and the hog are common helpmates, and are yoked together in order to turn up the land.
A waiting woman was generally considered as the most suitable helpmate for a parson.

entry.def: A wife; a helpmate.
entry.q: The Lord God created Adam, . . . and afterwards, on his finding the want of a helpmeet, caused him to sleep, and took one of his ribs and thence made woman.

entry.ety: An onomat�poetic word. Cf. G. holter-polter, D. holder de bolder
entry.def: In hurry and confusion; without definite purpose; irregularly.
entry.q: Helter-skelter have I rode to thee.
A wistaria vine running helter-skelter across the roof.

entry.ety: OE. helve helfe, AS. hielf helf hylf, cf. OHG. halb; and also E. halter helm of a rudder

sn.def: The handle of an ax, hatchet, or adze.

sd.def: The lever at the end of which is the hammer head, in a forge hammer.
A forge hammer which is lifted by a cam acting on the helve between the fulcrum and the head.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Helved; p. pr. & vb. n. Helving
entry.def: To furnish with a helve, as an ax.
Same as Helvetic.

entry.ety: L. Helveticus, fr. Helvetii the Helvetii
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Helvetii, the ancient inhabitant of the Alps, now Switzerland, or to the modern states and inhabitant of the Alpine regions; as, the Helvetic confederacy; Helvetic states.

entry.ety: L. helvus of a light bay color
entry.def: A mineral of a yellowish color, consisting chiefly of silica, glucina, manganese, and iron, with a little sulphur.
A genus of plants consisting of one species; a dwarf creeping mat-forming evergreen herb.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. him heom, dative pl. of. hē he. See He They
entry.def: Them
An onomatopoetic word used as an expression of hesitation, doubt, etc. It is often a sort of voluntary half cough, loud or subdued, and would perhaps be better expressed by hm.
entry.q: Cough or cry hem, if anybody come.

entry.def: An utterance or sound of the voice, hem or hm, often indicative of hesitation or doubt, sometimes used to call attention.
entry.q: His morninghems.

entry.def: To make the sound expressed by the word hem; hence, to hesitate in speaking.
entry.q: Hem, and stroke thy beard.

entry.ety: AS. hem, border, margin; cf. Fries. hämel, Prov. G. hammel hem of mire or dirt

sn.def: The edge or border of a garment or cloth, doubled over and sewed, to strengthen it and prevent raveling.
Border; edge; margin.
sn.q: Hemof the sea.

sn.def: A border made on sheet-metal ware by doubling over the edge of the sheet, to stiffen it and remove the sharp edge.

entry.cs:
To hem about To hem aroundorTo hem in
to inclose and confine; to surround; to environ. “With valiant squadrons round about to hem.” Fairfax. “Hemmed in to be a spoil to tyranny.” Daniel. To hem out to shut out. “You can not hem me out of London.” J. Webster.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hemmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Hemming

sn.def: To form a hem or border to; to fold and sew down the edge of.
To border; to edge
sn.q: All the skirt about Was hemmed with golden fringe.

entries.entry: Hem"a-. Same as Hæma-.

entry.ety: L. haemachates; Gr. a"i^ma blood + 'acha`ths agate
entry.def: A species of agate, sprinkled with spots of red jasper.
Same as Hæmachrome.
A composition made from blood, mixed with mineral or vegetable substances, used for making buttons, door knobs, etc.
An instrument for measuring the velocity with which the blood moves in the arteries.
The act of measuring the velocity with which the blood circulates in the arteries; hæmotachometry.
The principles of dynamics in their application to the blood; that part of science which treats of the motion of the blood.
An instrument by which the pressure of the blood in the arteries, or veins, is measured by the height to which it will raise a column of mercury; -- called also a hæmomanometer.

entry.note: ☞ As applied to vertebrates, hemal is the same as ventral, the heart and great blood vessels being on the ventral, and the central nervous system on the dorsal, side of the vertebral column.

cs.cd: the ventral arch in a segment of the spinal skeleton, formed by vertebral processes or ribs.

entry.def: Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situated in the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great blood vessels; -- opposed to neural.
Same as Hæmaphæin.

entries.entry:
‖Hem`a*poph"y*sis
Hem`a*po*phys"i*al # a.
n.; pl.Hemapophyses . NL. See Hæma-, and Apophysis
Anat The second element in each half of a hemal arch, corresponding to the sternal part of a rib. Owen.

entry.def: Same as Hemostatic.
Laws relating to the equilibrium of the blood in the blood vessels.
Same as Hæmatachometer.
A reddish brown or violet crystalline substance, C16H12O6, got from hematoxylin by partial oxidation, and regarded as analogous to the phthaleins.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + � a vomiting, fr. � to vomit
entry.def: A vomiting of blood.
A warm-blooded animal.
Warm-blooded; hematothermal.
Same as Hæmatic.
A medicine designed to improve the condition of the blood.

sn.def: Hematoxylin.

A bluish black, amorphous substance containing iron and obtained from blood. It exists the red blood corpuscles united with globulin, and the form of hemoglobin or oxyhemoglobin gives to the blood its red color.

entry.def: Any substance, such as an iron salt or organic compound containing iron, which when ingested tends to increase the hemoglobin contents of the blood.
A form of hemoglobinometer.
Relating to the measurement of the amount of hematin or hemoglobin contained in blood, or other fluids.
A red consisting of silica, borax, and soda, fused with oxide of copper and iron, and used in enamels, mosaics, etc.

entry.ety: L. haematites, Gr. � bloodlike, fr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood
entry.def: An important ore of iron, the sesquioxide, so called because of the red color of the powder. It occurs in splendent rhombohedral crystals, and in massive and earthy forms; -- the last called red ocher. Called also specular iron oligist iron rhombohedral iron ore, and bloodstone. See Brown hematite, under Brown.
Of or pertaining to hematite, or resembling it.

entries.entry: Hem"a*to. See Hæma-.

entry.ety: Hemato- + Gr. � tumor: cf. F. hématocèle
entry.def: A tumor filled with blood.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + kry`os cold
entry.def: The cold-blooded vertebrates, that is, all but the mammals and birds; -- the antithesis to Hematotherma.
See Hemoglobin.
Resembling blood.

A crystalline or amorphous pigment, free from iron, formed from hematin in old blood stains, and in old hemorrhages in the body. It resembles bilirubin. When present in the corpora lutea it is called hæmolutein.
The science which treats of the blood.
The lysis of erythrocytes in the blood with the release of hemoglobin.

A localised leakage of blood from the blood vessels into nearby tissues, usually confined within a tissue or organ; especially, a local swelling produced by an effusion of blood beneath the skin, which may clot and discolor the affected area.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + filei^n to love
entry.def: Same as hemophilia; -- an obsolete term.
The hematin of blood.
Sanguification; the conversion of chyle into blood.
The arterialization of the blood in the lungs; the formation of blood in general; hæmatogenesis.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. a"i^ma a"i`matos, blood + thermo`s warm
entry.def: The warm-blooded vertebrates, comprising the mammals and birds; -- the antithesis to hematocrya.
Warm-blooded.
Hæmatoxylin.
Passage of urine mingled with blood; blood in the urine.
The obtaining of a curve similar to a pulse curve or sphygmogram by allowing the blood from a divided artery to strike against a piece of paper.

entries.entry:
‖Hem*el"y*tron ? or ? ‖Hem*el"y*trum -trŭm cf. Elytron, 277, n.; pl.Hemelytra. NL. See Hemi, and Elytron
Zoöl One of the partially thickened anterior wings of certain insects, as of many Hemiptera, the earwigs, etc.

entry.note: ☞ Some writers (as Quain) use the word in the opposite sense, i. e., day blindness. See Nyctalopia.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, the opposite of �; � day + � of �. See Nyctalopia
entry.def: A disease of the eyes, in consequence of which a person can see clearly or without pain only by daylight or a strong artificial light; day sight.
A neuropterous insect of the genus Hemerobius, and allied genera.
Of relating to the hemerobians.
A natural family of insects including the brown lacewings.
one of many subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Lily family Liliaceae, but not widely accepted; it includes the genus Hemerocallis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; � day + ka`llos beauty
entry.def: A genus of plants, some species of which are cultivated for their beautiful flowers; day lily.

entries.entry:
Hem"i-. Gr. "hmi-. See Semi-
A prefix signifying half.

entry.def: Same as Hemialbumose.
An albuminous substance formed in gastric digestion, and by the action of boiling dilute acids on albumin. It is readily convertible into hemipeptone. Called also hemialbumin.
Anæsthesia upon one side of the body.
An order of fishes having an incomplete or reduced branchial apparatus. It includes the sticklebacks, the flutemouths, and Fistularia.
A lateral half of the heart, either the right or left.
One portion of a fruit that spontaneously divides into halves.
A lateral half of the cerebrum.
See Semiglutin.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. hémicrânie. See Cranium, and Megrim
entry.def: A pain that affects only one side of the head.
Hemicranis.

sn.def: A half circle; a semicircle.
A semicircular place, as a semicircular arena, or room, or part of a room.
sn.q: The collections will be displayed in the hemicycle of the central pavilion.

entry.def: Any species of Old World geckoes of the genus Hemidactylus. The hemidactyls have dilated toes, with two rows of plates beneath.
A short note, equal to one fourth of a semiquaver, or the sixty-fourth part of a whole note.
The lesser third.
Having one of the two florets in the same spikelet neuter, and the other unisexual, whether male or female; -- said of grasses.
The half channel or groove in the edge of the triglyph in the Doric order.

entry.ety: Hemi- + Gr. � seat, base, fr. � to sit
entry.def: Having half of the similar parts of a crystals, instead of all; consisting of half the planes which full symmetry would require, as when a cube has planes only on half of its eight solid angles, or one plane out of a pair on each of its edges; or as in the case of a tetrahedron, which is hemihedral to an octahedron, it being contained under four of the planes of an octahedron.
The property of crystallizing hemihedrally.
A solid hemihedrally derived. The tetrahedron is a hemihedron.
Presenting hemihedral forms, in which half the sectants have the full number of planes.
Having half as many (three) carboxyl radicals as mellitic acid; -- said of an organic acid.
Those insects which have an incomplete metamorphosis.
Having an incomplete metamorphosis, the larvæ differing from the adults chiefly in laking wings, as in the grasshoppers and cockroaches.
Having the two ends modified with unlike planes; -- said of a crystal.

entry.note: ☞ The obtaining of these small crystals, from old blood clots or suspected blood stains, constitutes one of the best evidences of the presence of blood.
entry.def: A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic, prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strong acetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals. Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.

entries.entry:
‖He*mi"na n.; pl.Heminæ #. L., fr. Gr. �
Rom. Antiq A measure of half a sextary.
Med A measure equal to about ten fluid ounces.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a half ass, a mule
entry.def: A wild ass found in Tibet; the kiang.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � half + Gr. � sight
entry.def: A defect of vision in consequence of which a person sees but half of an object looked at.
Same as Monoclinic.

entry.note: ☞ Unlike antipeptone it is convertible into leucin and tyrosin, by the continued action of pancreatic juice. See Peptone. It is also formed from hemialbumose and albumin by the action of boiling dilute sulphuric acid.
entry.def: A product of the gastric and pancreatic digestion of albuminous matter.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; � half + � a stroke; cf. F. hémiplagie
entry.def: A palsy that affects one side only of the body.
Hemiplegia.
Any bird of the genus Turnix. Various species inhabit Asia, Africa, and Australia.
An insoluble, proteid substance, described by Schützenberger, formed when albumin is heated for some time with dilute sulphuric acid. It is apparently identical with antialbumid and dyspeptone.
One of the Hemiptera.

entry.note: ☞ They are divided into the Heteroptera, including the squash bug, soldier bug, bedbug, etc.; the Homoptera, including the cicadas, cuckoo spits, plant lice, scale insects, etc.; the Thysanoptera, including the thrips, and, according to most recent writers, the Pediculina or true lice.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � half + � wing, fr. � to fly
entry.def: An order of hexapod insects having a jointed proboscis, including four sharp stylets (mandibles and maxillæ), for piercing. In many of the species (Heteroptera) the front wings are partially coriaceous, and different from the others.
Of or pertaining to the Hemiptera.
One of the Hemiptera; an hemipter.
A natural family of fish including the halfbeaks, marine and freshwater fishes closely related to the flying fishes but not able to glide.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hemisected; p. pr. & vb. n. Hemisecting
entry.def: To divide along the mesial plane.
A division along the mesial plane; also, one of the parts so divided.

entry.cs: Cerebral hemispheres. Anat See Brain. Magdeburg hemispheres Physics two hemispherical cups forming, when placed together, a cavity from which the air can be withdrawn by an air pump; -- used to illustrate the pressure of the air. So called because invented by Otto von Guericke at Magdeburg.
entry.ety: L. hemisphaerium, Gr. �; � half = � sphere: cf. F. hémisphère. See Hemi-, and Sphere

sn.def: A half sphere; one half of a sphere or globe, when divided by a plane passing through its center.
Half of the terrestrial globe, or a projection of the same in a map or picture.
The people who inhabit a hemisphere.
sn.q: He died . . . mourned by a hemisphere.

entry.def: Containing, or pertaining to, a hemisphere; as, a hemispheric figure or form; a hemispherical body.
A half of a spheroid.
Resembling, or approximating to, a hemisphere in form.
A half spherule.

entry.ety: L. hemistichium, Gr. "hmisti`chion; "hmi- half + sti`chos row, line, verse: cf. F. hémistiche
entry.def: Half a poetic verse or line, or a verse or line not completed.
Pertaining to, or written in, hemistichs; also, by, or according to, hemistichs; as, a hemistichal division of a verse.

entry.note: ☞ Hemisystole is noticed in rare cases of insufficiency of the mitral valve, in which both ventricles at times contract simultaneously, as in a normal heart, this condition alternating with contraction of the right ventricle alone; hence, intermittent hemisystole.
entry.def: Contraction of only one ventricle of the heart.
See Semitone.

sn.def: Turned half round; half inverted.
Having the raphe terminating about half way between the chalaza and the orifice; amphitropous; -- said of an ovule.

entry.ety: Hemi- + Gr. � to turn: cf. F. hémitrope
entry.def: Half turned round; half inverted; Crystallog having a twinned structure.
That which is hemitropal in construction; Crystallog a twin crystal having a hemitropal structure.
Twin composition in crystals.

entry.note: ☞ The potion of hemlock administered to Socrates is by some thought to have been a decoction of Cicuta virosa, or water hemlock, by others, of Conium maculatum.
entry.cs: Ground hemlockorDwarf hemlock . See under Ground.
entry.ety: OE. hemeluc humloc, AS. hemlic hymlic

sn.def: The name of several poisonous umbelliferous herbs having finely cut leaves and small white flowers, as the Cicuta maculata Cicuta bulbifera, and Cicuta virosa, and the Conium maculatum. See Conium.
An evergreen tree common in North America (Abies CanadensisorTsuga Canadensis); hemlock spruce.
sn.q: The murmuring pines and the hemlocks.

sn.def: The wood or timber of the hemlock tree.

entry.ety: Scot. hemmel hammel, Prov. E. hemble hovel, stable, shed, perh. allied to D. hemel heaven, canopy, G. himmel; cf. E. heaven. √14
entry.def: A shed or hovel for cattle.
One who, or that which, hems with a needle.
An attachment to a sewing machine, for turning under the edge of a piece of fabric, preparatory to stitching it down.
A tool for turning over the edge of sheet metal to make a hem.
a stitch used in sewing hems on skirts and dresses.

entries.entry: Hem"o-. Same as Hæma- Hæmo-.

entry.def: The normal coloring matter of the red blood corpuscles of vertebrate animals. It is composed of hematin and globulin, and is also called hæmatoglobulin. In arterial blood, it is always combined with oxygen, and is then called oxyhemoglobin. It crystallizes under different forms from different animals, and when crystallized, is called hæmatocrystallin. See Blood crystal, under Blood.
Same as Hæmochromometer.
The lysis of erythrocytes with the release of hemoglobin; the breaking apart of red blood cells in the blood.
of or pertaining to hemolysis; causing hemolysis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma, blood + filei^n to love
entry.def: A condition characterized by a tendency to profuse and uncontrollable hemorrhage from the slightest wounds; it is caused by an absence or abnormality of a clotting factor in the blood, and is a recessive genetic disease linked to the X-chromosome, and therefore usually occurs only in males; there are several specific forms. It may be treated by administering purified clotting factor. It was formerly termed Hematophilia.
A person afflicted with hemophilia; called also hemophile.
of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or afflicted with hemophilia; hemophilic.

sn.def: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or afflicted with hemophilia; hemophiliac.
Growing best in a medium containing blood, or in blood; -- of bacteria.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. a"i^ma blood + � to spit: cf. F. hémoptysie
entry.def: The expectoration of blood, due usually to hemorrhage from the mucous membrane of the lungs.

entry.note: ☞ The blood circulates in a system of closed tubes, the rupture of which gives rise to hemorrhage.
entry.ety: L. haemorrhagia, Gr. a"imorragi`a; a"i^ma blood + "rhgny`nai to break, burst: cf. F. hémorragie hémorrhagie
entry.def: Any discharge of blood from the blood vessels.
Pertaining or tending to a flux of blood; consisting in, or accompanied by, hemorrhage.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, hemorrhoids.
Of or pertaining to the rectum; rectal; as, the hemorrhoidal arteries, veins, and nerves.

entry.usage: The sing. hemorrhoid is rarely used
entry.ety: L. haemorrhoidae, pl., Gr. �, sing., � (sc. �), pl., veins liable to discharge blood, hemorrhoids, fr. � flowing with blood; a"i^ma blood + � to flow: cf. F. hémorroïdes hémorrhoïdes. See Rheum
entry.def: Livid and painful swellings formed by the dilation of the blood vessels around the margin of, or within, the anus, from which blood or mucus is occasionally discharged; piles; emerods.

a granular yellowish-brown substance composed of protein and ferric oxide, resulting from the breakdown of hemoglobin; it has a higher iron content than ferritin, and its presence in body tissues or phagocytes can be a symptom of disturbed iron metabolism.
The accumulation of abnormal amounts of hemosiderin in the tisssues. Several causes have been recognized.
a surgical instrument that stops bleeding by clamping the blood vessel.

entry.ety: Hemo- + Gr. statiko`s causing to stand, fr. � to stand

sn.def: Of or relating to stagnation of the blood.
Serving to arrest hemorrhage; styptic.

entry.def: A medicine or application to arrest hemorrhage.
An effusion of blood into the cavity of the pleura.

entry.cs:
African hemp Bowstring hemp . See under African, and Bowstring. Bastard hemp the Asiatic herb Datisca cannabina. Canada hemp a species of dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum), the fiber of which was used by the Indians. Hemp agrimony a coarse, composite herb of Europe (Eupatorium cannabinum), much like the American boneset. Hemp nettle a plant of the genus Galeopsis Galeopsis Tetrahit), belonging to the Mint family. Indian hemp. See under Indian a.
Manila hemp the fiber of Musa textilis. Sisal hemp the fiber of Agave sisalana, of Mexico and Yucatan. Sunn hemp a fiber obtained from a leguminous plant (Crotalaria juncea). Water hemp an annual American weed (Acnida cannabina), related to the amaranth.
entry.ety: OE. hemp, AS. henep hænep; akin to D. hennep, OHG. hanaf, G. hanf, Icel. hampr, Dan. hamp, Sw. hampa, L. cannabis cannabum, Gr. ka`nnabis ka`nnabos; cf. Russ. konoplia, Skr. çaṇa; all prob. borrowed from some other language at an early time. Cf. Cannabine Canvas

sn.def: A plant of the genus Cannabis Cannabis sativa), the fibrous skin or bark of which is used for making cloth and cordage. The name is also applied to various other plants yielding fiber.
The fiber of the skin or rind of the plant, prepared for spinning. The name has also been extended to various fibers resembling the true hemp.
Made of hemp; as, a hempen cord.
Like hemp.
sn.q: Beat into ahempenstate.

entry.def: Like hemp.
Themselves; -- used reflexively.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hemstitched; p. pr. & vb. n. Hemstitching
entry.def: To ornament at the head of a broad hem by drawing out a few parallel threads, and fastening the cross threads in successive small clusters; as, to hemstitch a handkerchief.
Having a broad hem separated from the body of the article by a line of open work; as, a hemistitched handkerchief.
The roebuck in its third year.

entry.note: ☞ Used adjectively or in combination to indicate the female; as, hen canary, hen eagle, hen turkey, peahen.
entry.cs: Hen clam. Zoöl A clam of the Mactra, and allied genera; the sea clam or surf clam. See Surf clam. A California clam of the genus Pachydesma. Hen driver. See Hen harrierbelow). Hen harrier Zoöl a hawk (Circus cyaneus), found in Europe and America; -- called also dove hawk henharm henharrow hen driver, and usually, in America, marsh hawk. See Marsh hawk. Hen hawk Zoöl one of several species of large hawks which capture hens; esp., the American red-tailed hawk (Buteo borealis), the red-shouldered hawk (Buteo lineatus), and the goshawk.
entry.ety: AS. henn hen hæn; akin to D. hen, OHG. henna, G. henne, Icel. h�na, Dan. höna; the fem. corresponding to AS. hana cock, D. haan, OHG. hano, G. hahn, Icel. hani, Dan. & Sw. hane. Prob. akin to L. canere to sing, and orig. meaning, a singer. Cf. Chanticleer
entry.def: The female of the domestic fowl; also, the female of grouse, pheasants, or any kind of birds; as, the heath hen; the gray hen.

A plant of the genus Hyoscyamus Hyoscyamus niger). All parts of the plant are poisonous, and the leaves are used for the same purposes as belladonna. It is poisonous to domestic fowls; whence the name. Called also, stinking nightshade, from the fetid odor of the plant. See Hyoscyamus.
A weed of the genus Lamium Lamium amplexicaule) with deeply crenate leaves.

entry.note: ☞ Hence is used, elliptically and imperatively, for go hence; depart hence; away; be gone. “Hence with your little ones.” Shak. From hence, though a pleonasm, is fully authorized by the usage of good writers.
entry.ety: OE. hennes hensthe s is prop. a genitive ending; cf. -wards), also hen henne hennen heonnen heonene, AS. heonan heonon heona hine; akin to OHG. hinnān, G. hinnen, OHG. hina, G. hin; all from the root of E. he. See He

sn.def: From this place; away.
sn.q: Or that wehencewend.
Arise, let us go hence.
I will send thee far hence unto the Gentiles.

sn.def: From this time; in the future; as, a week hence .
sn.q: Half an hourhence.

sn.def: From this reason; therefore; -- as an inference or deduction.
sn.q: Hence, perhaps, it is, that Solomon calls the fear of the Lord the beginning of wisdom.

sn.def: From this source or origin.
sn.q: All other faces borrowed hence Their light and grace.
Whence come wars and fightings among you? Come they not hence, even of your lusts?
An ancient author prophesied from hence.
Expelled from hence into a world Of woe and sorrow.

entry.def: To send away.
From this time forward; henceforward.
entry.q: I never from thy side henceforth to stray.

entry.def: From this time forward; from now into the indefinite future; henceforth.
A page; a servant.

entries.entry: Hench"man hĕnch"m�n n.; pl.-men -m�n. OE. hencheman henxman; prob. fr. OE. & AS. hengest horse + E. man, and meaning, a groom. AS. hengest is akin to D. & G. hengst stallion, OHG. hengist horse, gelding An attendant; a servant; a follower. Now chiefly used as a political cant term.

entry.def: A coop or cage for hens.

entry.ety: OE., near, handy, kind, fr. AS. gehende near, fr. hand hand. See Handy

sn.def: Skillful; dexterous; clever.
Friendly; civil; gentle; kind.

entry.ety: Gr. � eleven + � angle: cf. F. hendécagone
entry.def: A plane figure of eleven sides and eleven angles.
A hydrocarbon, C11H24, of the paraffin series; -- so called because it has eleven atoms of carbon in each molecule. Called also endecane undecane.
Pertaining to a line of eleven syllables.

entry.ety: L. hendecasyllabus, Gr. � eleven-syllabled; � eleven + � syllable: cf. F. hendécasyllabe
entry.def: A metrical line of eleven syllables.
Undecylic; pertaining to, or derived from, hendecane; as, hendecatoic acid.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � � � one by two
entry.def: A figure in which the idea is expressed by two nouns connected by and, instead of by a noun and limiting adjective; as, we drink from cups and gold, for golden cups .
See Hende.
Hence.
A marine fish; the sea bream.
A young bib. See Bib n., 2.

entries.entry: Heng obs. imp. of Hang . Hung.

entry.def: Cowardly; timid; chicken-hearted.

entries.entry: Hen"house` n.; pl.Henhouses. A house or shelter for fowls.

entry.def: A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
See Jeniquen.

entry.ety: Ar. hinnā alcanna (Lawsonia inermis syn. Lawsonia alba). Cf. Alcanna Alkanet Orchanet

entries.entry:
Hep"ta. See Seven

entry.ety: L. heptas the number seven. Gr. �, �, fr. "epta` seven

A book in seven languages.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "epta` seven + �, �, man, male: cf. F. heptandrie

Any one of several isometric hydrocarbons, C7H16, of the paraffin series (nine are possible, four are known); -- so called because the molecule has seven carbon atoms. Specifically, a colorless liquid, found as a constituent of petroleum, in the tar oil of cannel coal, etc.

entry.ety: Hepta- + angular: cf. F. heptangulaire. Cf. Septangular

entry.note: ☞ The word is most commonly applied to England, when it was divided into seven kingdoms; as, the Saxon heptachy, which consisted of Kent, the South Saxons (Sussex), West Saxons (Wessex), East Saxons (Essex), the East Angles, Mercia, and Northumberland.
entry.def: A government by seven persons; also, a country under seven rulers.
Having seven seeds.
A composition consisting of seven lines or verses.

entry.ety: L. heptateuchos, Gr. "epta` seven + � tool, book; � to prepare, make, work: cf. F. heptateuque

cs.cd: in England, an ancient corporation, dependent upon the crown, instituted or perhaps recognized by Richard III. in 1483, consisting of the three Kings-at-Arms and the Chester, Lancaster, Richmond, Somerset, Windsor, and York Heralds, together with the Earl Marshal. This retains from the Middle Ages the charge of the armorial bearings of persons privileged to bear them, as well as of genealogies and kindred subjects; -- called also College of Arms.

entry.ety: OE. herald heraud, OF. heralt heraut herault, F. héraut, LL. heraldus haraldus, fr. (assumed) OHG. heriwalto hariwaldo, a (civil) officer who serves the army; hari heri, army + waltan to manage, govern, G. walten; akin to E. wield. See Harry Wield

sn.def: An officer whose business was to denounce or proclaim war, to challenge to battle, to proclaim peace, and to bear messages from the commander of an army. He was invested with a sacred and inviolable character.

In the Middle Ages, the officer charged with the above duties, and also with the care of genealogies, of the rights and privileges of noble families, and especially of armorial bearings. In modern times, some vestiges of this office remain, especially in England. See Heralds' Collegebelow), and King-at-Arms.
A proclaimer; one who, or that which, publishes or announces; as, the herald of another's fame.
A forerunner; a a precursor; a harbinger.

cs.cd: one of several species of grass, highly esteemed for hay. See under Grass.

entry.ety: OE. herd heord, AS. heord; akin to OHG. herta, G. herde, Icel. hjörð, Sw. hjord, Dan. hiord, Goth. haírda; cf. Skr. çardha troop, host

entry.def: A kind of low-hung cab.

entries.entry: Herd"man Herds"man, n.; pl.-men. The owner or keeper of a herd or of herds; one employed in tending a herd of cattle.
Herds"wom`an n.; pl. -women. A woman who tends a herd.
