The part of a gland, or similar organ, where the blood vessels and nerves enter; the hilus; as, the hilum of the kidney.

entry.def: Same as Hilum, 2.
Them. See Hem.

entry.note: ☞ In old English his and him were respectively the genitive and dative forms of it as well as of he. This use is now obsolete. Poetically him is sometimes used with the reflexive sense of himself.
entry.ety: AS. him, dat. of hē. √183. See He
entry.def: The objective case of he. See He.
entry.q: Him that is weak in the faith receive.
Friends who have given him the most sympathy.
I never saw but Humphrey, duke of Gloster, Did bear him like a noble gentleman.

entry.ety: Skr. himālaya, prop., the abode of snow
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Himalayas, the great mountain chain in Asia.
A small genus of terrestrial orchids of Europe and Mediterranean region.
one of two genera of stilts; they are similar to avocets but with straight bills.
A hymn.

entry.note: ☞ Himself was formerly used instead of itself. See Note under Him.

cs.cd: alone; unaccompanied; apart; sequestered; as, he sits or studies by himself.
to withdraw from him; to let him take his own course.

sn.def: An emphasized form of the third person masculine pronoun; -- used as a subject usually with he; as, he himself will bear the blame; used alone in the predicate, either in the nominative or objective case; as, it is himself who saved himself .
sn.q: But he himself returned from the quarries.
David hid himself in the field.
The Lord himself shall give you a sign.
Who gave himself for us, that he might . . . purify unto himself a peculiar people.
With shame remembers, while himself was one Of the same herd, himself the same had done.
It comprehendeth in himself all good.

sn.def: One's true or real character; one's natural temper and disposition; the state of being in one's right or sane mind (after unconsciousness, passion, delirium, or abasement); as, the man has come to himself .

entries.entry:
Him*self" Him*selve"
Him*selv"en�), pron. pl. Themselves. See Hemself. Obs

entry.def: See 1st Himself.

Pertaining to Himyar, an ancient king of Yemen, in Arabia, or to his successors or people; as, the Himjaritic characters, language, etc.; applied esp. to certain ancient inscriptions showing the primitive type of the oldest form of the Arabic, still spoken in Southern Arabia.
A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing three quarts, one pint, one gill, English measure.

sn.def: a major school of Buddhism teaching personal salvation through one's own efforts.
one of two great schools of Buddhist doctrine emphasizing personal salvation through one's own efforts; chiefly in Sri Lanka (Ceylon); Myanmar (Burma); Thailand; Cambodia.

entry.def: an adherent of Hinayana Buddhism.

entry.ety: AS. hind; akin to D. hinde, OHG. hinta, G. hinde hindin, Icel., Sw., & Dan. hind, and perh. to Goth. hinþan to seize (in comp.), E. hunt, or cf. Gr. kema`s a young deer

sn.def: The female of the red deer, of which the male is the stag.
A spotted food fish of the genus Epinephelus, as Epinephelus apua of Bermuda, and Epinephelus Drummond-hayi of Florida; -- called also coney John Paw spotted hind.

entry.ety: OE. hine, AS. hīne hīna, orig. gen. pl. of hīwan domestics; akin to Icel. hjū man and wife, domestics, family, Goth. heiwafrauja master of the house, G. heirath marriage; cf. L. civis citizen, E. city or E. home. Cf. Hide a measure of land

sn.def: A domestic; a servant.
A peasant; a rustic; a farm servant.
sn.q: The hind, that homeward driving the slow steer Tells how man's daily work goes forward here.

entry.amorph: Compar. Hinder; superl. Hindmost, or Hindermost
entry.ety: OE. hind, adv., back, AS. hindan behind. See Hinder a.
entry.def: In the rear; -- opposed to front; of or pertaining to the part or end which follows or is behind, in opposition to the part which leads or is before; as, the hind legs or hind feet of a quadruped; the hind man in a procession.

entry.ety: AS. hindberie; akin to OHG. hintberi, G. himbeere. So called because hinds or stags are fond of them. See 1st Hind, and Berry
entry.def: The raspberry.
The posterior of the three principal divisions of the brain, including the epencephalon and metencephalon. Sometimes restricted to the epencephalon only.

entry.ety: OE. hindere, AS. hinder, adv., behind; akin to OHG. hintar, prep., behind, G. hinter, Goth. hindar; orig. a comparative, and akin to AS. hine hence. See Hence He, and cf. Hind a. Hindmost
entry.def: Of or belonging to that part or end which is in the rear, or which follows; as, the hinder part of a wagon; the hinder parts of a horse.
entry.q: He was in the hinder part of the ship.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hindered; p. pr. & vb. n. Hindering
entry.ety: OE. hindren hinderen, AS. hindrian, fr. hinder behind; akin to D. hinderen, G. hindern, OHG. hintar�n, Icel. & Sw. hindra, Dan. hindre. See Hinder a.

sn.def: To keep back or behind; to prevent from starting or moving forward; to check; to retard; to obstruct; to bring to a full stop; -- often followed by from; as, an accident hindered the coach; drought hinders the growth of plants; to hinder me from going.
sn.q: Them that were entering in ye hindered.
I hinder you too long.

sn.def: To prevent or embarrass; to debar; to shut out.
sn.q: What hinders younger brothers, being fathers of families, from having the same right?
sn.syn: To check; retard; impede; delay; block; clog; prevent; stop; interrupt; counteract; thwart; oppose; obstruct; debar; embarrass.

entry.def: To interpose obstacles or impediments; to be a hindrance.
entry.q: This objection hinders not but that the heroic action of some commander . . . may be written.

entries.entry: Hin"der*ance. n. Same as Hindrance.

entry.def: One who, or that which, hinders.
Hindermost;superl. of Hind a.

entry.ety: AS. hinderling one who comes behind his ancestors, fr. AS. hinder behind. See Hinder a., and cf. Hilding
entry.def: A worthless, base, degenerate person or animal.

entry.ety: The superlative of hind. See Hind a.
Cf. AS. hindemaakin to Goth. hindumists), a superlative from the same source as the comparative hinder. See Hinder, a., and cf. Aftermost
entry.def: Furthest in or toward the rear; last.
entry.q: Rachel and Josephhindermost.

entry.def: The posterior part of the alimentary canal, including the rectum, and sometimes the large intestine also.

entry.ety: Prop. a Per. adj. meaning, Indian, Hindoo
entry.def: The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustani language which is chiefly spoken by native Hindus. In employs the Devanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written.

entries.entry: Hind"ley"s screw`. Mech A screw cut on a solid whose sides are arcs of the periphery of a wheel into the teeth of which the screw is intended to work. It is named from the person who first used the form.

Hin"doo Hin"du
?; 277 n.; pl.Hindoos #orHindus. Per. Hindū, fr. Hind Hindūstān, India. Cf. Indian
A native inhabitant of Hindostan. As an ethnical term it is confined to the Dravidian and Aryan races; as a religious name it is restricted to followers of the Veda.

Hin"doo calendarorHindu calendar
The intercalary month has the name of the one which precedes it. The year usually commences about April 11. The months are follows: Baisakh . . . . . . . . . . April-May Jeth . . . . . . . . . . . . . May-June Asarh . . . . . . . . . . . . June-July Sawan (Sarawan) . . . . . . . July-Aug. Bhadon . . . . . . . . . . . Aug.-Sept. Asin (Kuar). . . . . . . . . . Sept.-Oct. Katik (Kartik) . . . . . . . . Oct.-Nov. Aghan . . . . . . . . . . . . Nov.-Dec. Pus . . . . . . . . . . . . . Dec.-Jan. Magh . . . . . . . . . . . . . Jan.-Feb. Phagun (Phalgun) . . . . . . . Feb.-March Chait . . . . . . . . . . . . March-April
. A lunisolar calendar of India, according to which the year is divided into twelve months, with an extra month inserted after every month in which two new moons occur (once in three years).

entry.def: The religious doctrines and rites of the Hindus; Brahmanism.

entry.ety: Hind. Hindūstānī an Indian, fr. Hind. and Per. Hindūstān India
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Hindoos or their language.

def2.def: The language of Hindustan; the name given by Europeans to the most generally spoken of the modern Aryan languages of India. It is Hindi with the addition of Persian and Arabic words.

entry.def: Same as Hindustani. See Hindoostanee.
the back half of a side of meat, from about the twelfth rib back.

Something between a hindrance and a help.

cs.cd: Perfect understanding of an event after it has happened; -- a term usually used with sarcasm in response to criticism of one's decision, implying that the critic is unfairly judging the wisdom of the decision in light of information that was not available when the decision was made.

entry.def: understanding the nature of an event after it has happened; as, hindsight is always clearer than foresight.
Same as Hindoo. This is now the more commonly used spelling.

sn.def: the dominant religion of India; characterized by a caste system anud belief in reincarnation.
a complex of beliefs and values and customs including worship of many gods, especially the Trimurti composed of Brahma the Creator; Vishnu the preserver; and Shiva the destroyer.

of or pertaining to Hindustan or its inhabitants.

a form of Hindi spoken around Delhi. See Hindoostanee.

entry.cs: Hinge joint. Anat See Ginglymus. Mech Any joint resembling a hinge, by which two pieces are connected so as to permit relative turning in one plane. To be off the hinges to be in a state of disorder or irregularity; to have lost proper adjustment. Tillotson.
entry.ety: OE. henge heeng; akin to D. heng, LG. henge, Prov. E. hingle a small hinge; connected with hang, v., and Icel. hengja to hang. See Hang

sn.def: The hook with its eye, or the joint, on which a door, gate, lid, etc., turns or swings; a flexible piece, as a strip of leather, which serves as a joint to turn on.
sn.q: The gate self-opened wide, On golden hinges turning.

sn.def: That on which anything turns or depends; a governing principle; a cardinal point or rule; as, this argument was the hinge on which the question turned.
One of the four cardinal points, east, west, north, or south.
sn.q: When the moon is in the hinge at East.
Nor slept the winds . . . but rushed abroad.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hinged; p. pr. & vb. n. Hinging

sn.def: To attach by, or furnish with, hinges.
To bend.

entry.def: To stand, depend, hang, or turn, as on a hinge; to depend chiefly for a result or decision or for force and validity; -- usually with on or upon; as, the argument hinges on this point.
Furnished with hinges.
Without a hinge or joint.
A reaping hook.
To neigh; to whinny.

entries.entry: Hin"ny n.; pl.Hinnies #. L. hinnus, cf. Gr. � A hybrid between a stallion and an ass; -- correlative of the mule.

entry.def: A term of endearment; darling; -- corrupted from honey.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hinted; p. pr. & vb. n. Hinting
entry.ety: OE. henten hinten, to seize, to catch, AS. hentan to pursue, take, seize; or Icel. ymta to mutter, ymtr a muttering, Dan. ymte to whisper. √36. Cf. Hent
entry.def: To bring to mind by a slight mention or remote allusion; to suggest in an indirect manner; as, to hint a suspicion.
entry.q: Just hint a fault and hesitate dislike.

cs.cd: to allude to lightly, indirectly, or cautiously.

entry.def: To make an indirect reference, suggestion, or allusion; to allude vaguely to something.
entry.q: We whisper, and hint, and chuckle.

entry.def: A remote allusion; slight mention; intimation; insinuation; a suggestion or reminder, without a full declaration or explanation; also, an occasion or motive.
entry.q: Our hint of woe Is common.
The hint malevolent, the look oblique.

entry.def: a remote and undeveloped area; originally, the land or region lying behind the coast district. The term is used esp. with reference to the so-called doctrine of the hinterland, sometimes advanced, that occupation of the coast supports a claim to an exclusive right to occupy, from time to time, the territory lying inland of the coast.
In a hinting manner.

cs.cd: the innominate bone; -- called also haunch bone and huckle bone.
the pelvic girdle.
the articulation between the thigh bone and hip bone.
a finial, ball, or other ornament at the intersection of the hip rafters and the ridge.
a molding on the hip of a roof, covering the hip joint of the slating or other roofing.
the rafter extending from the wall plate to the ridge in the angle of a hip roof.
a roof having sloping ends and sloping sides. See Hip n., 2., and Hip v. t., 3.
a tile made to cover the hip of a roof.
cs.mcol: To catch upon the hiporTo have on the hip
cs.cd: to have or get the advantage of; -- a figure probably derived from wresting.
to overthrow completely; to defeat utterly.

entry.ety: OE. hipe huppe, AS. hype; akin to D. heup, OHG. huf, G. hüfte, Dan. hofte, Sw. höft, Goth. hups; cf. Icel. huppr, and also Gr. � the hollow above the hips of cattle, and Lith. kumpis ham

sn.def: The projecting region of the lateral parts of one side of the pelvis and the hip joint; the haunch; the huckle.
The external angle formed by the meeting of two sloping sides or skirts of a roof, which have their wall plates running in different directions.
In a bridge truss, the place where an inclined end post meets the top chord.

entry.cs: Hipped roof. See Hip roof, under Hip.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hipped; p. pr. & vb. n. Hipping

sn.def: To dislocate or sprain the hip of, to fracture or injure the hip bone of (a quadruped) in such a manner as to produce a permanent depression of that side.
To throw (one's adversary) over one's hip in wrestling (technically called cross buttock).
To make with a hip or hips, as a roof.

cs.cd: the dog-rose.

entry.ety: OE. hepe, AS. heópe; cf. OHG. hiufo a bramble bush
entry.def: The fruit of a rosebush, especially of the English dog-rose (Rosa canina); called also rose hip.
Used to excite attention or as a signal; as, hip hip, hurra!
See Hyp n.

sn.def: Aware of the latest ideas, trends, fashions, and developments in popular music and entertainment culture; not square; -- same as hep.

Aware of the latest fashions and behaving as expected socially, especially in clothing style and musical taste; exhibiting an air of casual sophistication; cool; with it; -- used mostly among young people in the teens to twenties.

entry.def: Either of two large flaring bones, each forming one half of the pelvis; made up of the ilium and ischium and pubis.

entries.entry: Hipe n. Also Hype . Etym. uncertain Wrestling A throw in which the wrestler lifts his opponent from the ground, swings him to one side, knocks up his nearer thigh from the back with the knee, and throws him on his back.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hiped; p. pr. & vb. n. Hiping
entry.def: To throw by means of a hipe.
A small portable flask, usually made of metal, used to hold liquor.
Lame in the hip.
having hips which are not prominent; seeming to have no hips; as, slim and hipless ; -- of people. Opposite of broad-hipped

sn.def: the line formed by measuring the hip at its greatest part.
the line formed by the lower edge of hiplength garment.

entries.entry: Hip lock. Wrestling A lock in which a close grip is obtained and a fall attempted by a heave over the hip.

entry.def: A genus of marine decapod crustaceans, which burrow rapidly in the sand by pushing themselves backward; -- called also bait bug. See Illust. under Anomura.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a pony, dim. of � a horse
entry.def: An extinct genus of Tertiary mammals allied to the horse, but three-toed, having on each foot a small lateral hoof on each side of the main central one. It is believed to be one of the ancestral genera of the Horse family.
An amaryllis of tropical America (Hippeastrum puniceum) often cultivated as a houseplant for its showy white to red flowers.
Somewhat hypochondriac; melancholy. See Hyppish.
entry.q: When we are hipped or in high spirits.

sn.def: having hips; or, having hips of a specified type; -- used in combination; as, wide-hipped .
peaked and having sloping ends rather than gables; -- of roofs; as, a hipped roof has sloping ends rather than gables.

entry.def: Someone who rejects the established culture, dresses casually, and advocates extreme liberalism in politics and lifestyle. Used especially of those in the late 1960's, mostly in their late teens and early twenties, who conspicuously rejected traditional culture by dressing casually, if male wore their hair long, and wore folksy or used clothing adorned with beads, headbands, and often flowers; they emphasized the importance of love and direct personal relations rather than success-oriented businesslike behavior, strove for spontaneity, sometimes lived communally, and in some cases tried to expand their consciousness by various psychological techniques such as meditation, or through the use of consciousness-altering drugs such as marijuana or LSD. By the end of the Vietnam war in the 1970's, the numbers of people living a visibly hippie lifestyle had dramatically decreased, though some people continue to develop similar views and live with the same outlook.
Same as hippopotamus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "i`ppos horse + � to feed
entry.def: A genus of dipterous insects including the horsefly or horse tick.
A natural family of winged or wingless dipterans: louse flies.
See Hippocampus.
Of or pertaining to the hippocampus.

entry.note: ☞ They swim slowly, in an erect position, and often cling to seaweeds by means of the incurved prehensile tail. The male has a ventral pouch, in which it carries the eggs till hatched.
entry.ety: L., the sea horse, Gr. � a hippocampus (in senses 1 and 2); "i`ppos horse + � to bend

sn.def: A fabulous monster, with the head and fore quarters of a horse joined to the tail of a dolphin or other fish (Hippocampus brevirostris), -- seen in Pompeian paintings, attached to the chariot of Neptune.
A genus of lophobranch fishes of several species in which the head and neck have some resemblance to those of a horse; -- called also sea horse.

A name applied to either of two ridges of white matter in each lateral ventricle of the brain. The larger is called hippocampus major or simply hippocampus. The smaller, hippocampus minor, is called also ergot and calcar.

entry.def: Same as Centaur.

entry.ety: F. hippocras hypocras, NL. vinum hippocraticum, lit., wine of Hippocrates
entry.def: A cordial made of spiced wine, etc.

cs.cd: a conical strainer, made by stitching together two adjacent sides of a square piece of cloth, esp. flannel of linen.

entry.def: A famous Greek physician and medical writer, born in Cos, about 460 b. c.

cs.cd: the change produced in the countenance by death, or long sickness, excessive evacuations, excessive hunger, and the like. The nose is pinched, the eyes are sunk, the temples hollow, the ears cold and retracted, the skin of the forehead tense and dry, the complexion livid, the lips pendent, relaxed, and cold; -- so called, as having been described by Hippocrates.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Hippocrates, or to his teachings.

entry.note: ☞ An English translation of the oath reads: I swear by Apollo the physician, by Aesculapius, and Health, and All-heal, and all the gods and goddesses, that according to my ability and my judgement, I will keep this Oath and this stipulation -- to reckon him who taught me this Art equally dear to me as my parents, to share my substance with him, and relieve his necessities if required; to look upon his offspring in the same footing as my own brothers, and to teach them this Art, if they wish to learn it, without fee or stipulation; and that by precept, lecture, and every mode of instruction, I will impart a knowledge of the Art to my own sons, and of my teachers, and to disciples bound by a stipulation and oath according to the law of medicine, but to none others. I will follow that system or regimen which, according to my ability and judgement, I consider for the benefit of my patients, and abstain from whatever is deleterious and mischievous. I will give no deadly medicine to any one if asked, nor suggest any such counsel; and in like manner I will not give to a woman a pessary to produce abortion. With purity and with holiness I will pass my life and practice my Art. I will not cut persons labouring under the stone, but will leave this to be done by men who are practitioners of this work. Into whatever houses I enter, I will go into them for the benefit of the sick, and will abstain from every voluntary act of mischief and corruption; and, further, from the seduction of females or males, of freemen and slaves. Whatever, in connection with my professional service, or not in connection with it, I see or hear, in the life of men, which ought not to be spoken of abroad, I will not divulge, as reckoning that all such should be kept secret. While I continue to keep this Oath unviolated, may it be granted to me to enjoy life and the practice of the Art, respected by all men, in all times. But should I trespass and violate this Oath, may the reverse be my lot.
entry.def: An oath said to have been dictated by Hippocrates to his disciples. Such an oath is still administered to candidates for graduation in medicine.
The medical philosophy or system of Hippocrates.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; "i`ppos horse + � a fountain
entry.def: A fountain on Mount Helicon in Bœotia, fabled to have burst forth when the ground was struck by the hoof of Pegasus. Also, its waters, which were supposed to impart poetic inspiration.
entry.q: Nor maddening draughts of Hippocrene.

entries.entry:
Hip`po*pot"a*mus n.; pl. E. Hippopotamuses #, L. Hippopotami #. L., from Gr.�; "i`ppos horse + � river. Cf. Equine
Zoöl A large, amphibious, herbivorous mammal (Hippopotamus amphibius), common in the rivers of tropical Africa. It is allied to the hogs, and has a very thick, naked skin, a thick and square head, a very large muzzle, small eyes and ears, thick and heavy body, and short legs. It is supposed to be the behemoth of the Bible. Called also zeekoe, and river horse. A smaller species (Hippopotamus Liberiencis) inhabits Western Africa.

entry.ety: Gr. "i`ppos horse + � to cut: cf. F. hippotomie
entry.def: Anatomy of the horse.

cs.cd: a white crystalline substance, containing nitrogen, present in the urine of herbivorous animals, and in small quantity in human urine. By the action of acids, it is decomposed into benzoic acid and glycocoll.

entry.ety: Gr. "i`ppos horse + o"y`ron urine: cf. F. hippurique
entry.def: Obtained from the urine of horses; as, hippuric acid.

entry.ety: Gr. � decked with a horse's tail; "i`ppos horse + � tail: cf. F. hippurite
entry.def: A fossil bivalve mollusk of the genus Hippurites, of many species, having a conical, cup-shaped under valve, with a flattish upper valve or lid. Hippurites are found only in the Cretaceous rocks.

entry.ety: OE. hire hure, AS. hȳr; akin to D. huur, G. heuer, Dan. hyre, Sw. hyra

sn.def: The price, reward, or compensation paid, or contracted to be paid, for the temporary use of a thing or a place, for personal service, or for labor; wages; rent; pay.
sn.q: The laborer is worthy of his hire.

sn.def: A bailment by which the use of a thing, or the services and labor of a person, are contracted for at a certain price or reward.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hired hīrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Hiring
entry.ety: OE. hiren huren, AS. hȳrian; akin to D. huren, G. heuern, Dan. hyre, Sw. hyra. See Hire n.

sn.def: To procure (any chattel or estate) from another person, for temporary use, for a compensation or equivalent; to purchase the use or enjoyment of for a limited time; as, to hire a farm for a year; to hire money.
To engage or purchase the service, labor, or interest of (any one) for a specific purpose, by payment of wages; as, to hire a servant, an agent, or an advocate.

To grant the temporary use of, for compensation; to engage to give the service of, for a price; to let; to lease; -- now usually with out, and often reflexively; as, he has hired out his horse, or his time.
sn.q: They . . . have hired out themselves for bread.

entry.note: used in contrast with the owner or family members who work in an enterprise

entry.def: One who is hired, or who serves for wages; esp., one whose motive and interest in serving another are wholly gainful; a mercenary.

entry.def: Serving for hire or wages; venal; mercenary.
entry.q: Hirelingmourners.

entries.entry: Hire purchase or, more fully Hire purchase agreementorHire and purchase agreement . Law A contract (more fully called contract of hire with an option of purchase) in which a person hires goods for a specified period and at a fixed rent, with the added condition that if he shall retain the goods for the full period and pay all the installments of rent as they become due the contract shall determine and the title vest absolutely in him, and that if he chooses he may at any time during the term surrender the goods and be quit of any liability for future installments upon the contract. In the United States such a contract is generally treated as a conditional sale, and the term hire purchase is also sometimes applied to a contract in which the hirer is not free to avoid future liability by surrender of the goods. In England, however, if the hirer does not have this right the contract is a sale.

entry.def: One who hires.
Hers; theirs. See Here pron.

entry.ety: L. hirsutus; prob. akin to horridus horrid. Cf. Horrid

sn.def: Rough with hair; set with bristles; shaggy.

entry.note: ☞ Also formerly used in connection with a noun simply as a sign of the possessive. “The king his son.” Shak. “By young Telemachus his blooming years.” Pope. This his is probably a corruption of the old possessive ending -is or -es, which, being written as a separate word, was at length confounded with the pronoun his.

Who can impress the forest, bid the tree Unfix his earth-bound root?

of or pertaining to Haiti.

entries.entry:
Hiss hĭs. v. i.
imp. & p. p. Hissed hĭst; p. pr. & vb. n. Hissing
AS. hysian; prob. of imitative origin; cf. LG. hissen, OD. hisschen
To make with the mouth a prolonged sound like that of the letter s, by driving the breath between the tongue and the teeth; to make with the mouth a sound like that made by a goose or a snake when angered; esp., to make such a sound as an expression of hatred, passion, or disapproval. The merchants among the people shall hiss at thee.
To make a similar noise by any means; to pass with a sibilant sound; as, the arrow hissed as it flew. Shod with steel, We hissed along the polished ice.

sn.def: To condemn or express contempt for by hissing.
sn.q: If the tag-rag people did not clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and displeased them.
Malcolm. What is the newest grief?Ros. That of an hour's age doth hiss the speaker.

sn.def: To utter with a hissing sound.
sn.q: The long-necked geese of the world that are ever hissing dispraise.

sn.def: A prolonged sound like that letter s, made by forcing out the breath between the tongue and teeth, esp. as a token of disapprobation or contempt.
sn.q: “Hiss” implies audible friction of breath consonants.
A dismal, universal hiss, the sound Of public scorn.

entry.sn:
Any sound resembling that above described; as: The noise made by a serpent. But hiss for hiss returned with forked tongue.
The note of a goose when irritated.
The noise made by steam escaping through a narrow orifice, or by water falling on a hot stove.

sn.def: The act of emitting a hiss or hisses.
The occasion of contempt; the object of scorn and derision.
sn.q: I will make this city desolate, and a hissing.

entry.def: With a hissing sound.

That branch of biological science, which treats of the minute (microscopic) structure of animal and vegetable tissues; -- called also histiology.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "isto`s tissue + � to loosen, dissolve

that meaning of a passage which is deduced from the circumstances of time, place, etc., under which it was written.
the capacity to conceive and represent the unity and significance of a past era or age.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to history, or the record of past events; as, an historical poem; the historic page.

entries.entry:
His"to*ry
History piece a representation in painting, drawing, etc., of any real event, including the actors and the action. Natural history a description and classification of objects in nature, as minerals, plants, animals, etc., and the phenomena which they exhibit to the senses.
History Chronicle Annals. History is a methodical record of important events which concern a community of men, usually so arranged as to show the connection of causes and effects, to give an analysis of motive and action etc. A chronicle is a record of such events, conforming to the order of time as its distinctive feature. Annals are a chronicle divided up into separate years. By poetic license annals is sometimes used for history. n.; pl.Histories #. L. historia, Gr. 'istori`a history, information, inquiry, fr. 'istwr "istwr, knowing, learned, from the root of � to know; akin to E. wit. See Wit, and cf. Story
A learning or knowing by inquiry; the knowledge of facts and events, so obtained; hence, a formal statement of such information; a narrative; a description; a written record; as, the history of a patient's case; the history of a legislative bill.
A systematic, written account of events, particularly of those affecting a nation, institution, science, or art, and usually connected with a philosophical explanation of their causes; a true story, as distinguished from a romance; -- distinguished also from annals, which relate simply the facts and events of each year, in strict chronological order; from biography, which is the record of an individual's life; and from memoir, which is history composed from personal experience, observation, and memory.
Histories are as perfect as the historian is wise, and is gifted with an eye and a soul. For aught that I could ever read, Could ever hear by tale or history. What histories of toil could I declare! Chronicle; annals; relation; narration. Justly Cæsar scorns the poet's lays; It is to history he trusts for praise. No more yet of this; For 't is a chronicle of day by day, Not a relation for a breakfast. Many glorious examples in the annals of our religion.

entry.def: To narrate or record.
The dissection of organic tissues.
A soluble enzyme occurring in the animal body, to the presence of which many normal decompositions and synthetical processes are supposed to be due.
A player.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hit; p. pr. & vb. n. Hitting
entry.ety: OE. hitten hutten, of Scand. origin; cf. Dan. hitte to hit, find, Sw. & Icel. hitta

sn.def: To reach with a stroke or blow; to strike or touch, usually with force; especially, to reach or touch (an object aimed at).
sn.q: I think you have hit the mark.

sn.def: To reach or attain exactly; to meet according to the occasion; to perform successfully; to attain to; to accord with; to be conformable to; to suit.
sn.q: Birds learning tunes, and their endeavors to hit the notes right.
There you hit him; . . . that argument never fails with him.
Whose saintly visage is too bright To hit the sense of human sight.
He scarcely hit my humor.

sn.def: To guess; to light upon or discover.
sn.q: Thou hasthitit.

sn.def: To take up, or replace by a piece belonging to the opposing player; -- said of a single unprotected piece on a point.

entry.cs:
To hit onorTo hit upon
to light upon; to come to by chance; to discover unexpectedly; as, he hit on the solution after days of trying. “None of them hit upon the art.” Addison.

sn.def: To meet or come in contact; to strike; to clash; -- followed by against or on.
sn.q: If bodies be extension alone, how can they move and hit one against another?
Corpuscles, meeting with or hitting on those bodies, become conjoined with them.

sn.def: To meet or reach what was aimed at or desired; to succeed, -- often with implied chance, or luck.
sn.q: And oft it hits Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.
And millions miss for one that hits.

entry.cs: Base hit Safe hit Sacrifice hit . Baseball See under Base Safe, etc.

sn.q: So he the famed Cilician fencer praised, And, at each hit, with wonder seems amazed.

A performance, as a musical recording, movie, or play, which achieved great popularity or acclaim; also used of books or objects of commerce which become big sellers; as, the new notebook computer was a big hit with business travellers.
sn.q: What late he called a blessing, now was wit, And God's good providence, a lucky hit.

sn.def: A peculiarly apt expression or turn of thought; a phrase which hits the mark; as, a happy hit .
A game won at backgammon after the adversary has removed some of his men. It counts less than a gammon.
A striking of the ball; as, a safe hit; a foul hit ; -- sometimes used specifically for a base hit.
An act of murder performed for hire, esp. by a professional assassin.

entry.def: Having become very popular or acclaimed; -- said of entertainment performances; as, a hit song, a hit movie.

entry.ety: Cf. Scot. hitch a motion by a jerk, and hatch hotch, to move by jerks, also Prov. G. hiksen, G. hinken, to limp, hobble; or E. hiccough; or possibly akin to E. hook

sn.def: To become entangled or caught; to be linked or yoked; to unite; to cling.
sn.q: Atoms . . . which at length hitched together.

sn.def: To move interruptedly or with halts, jerks, or steps; -- said of something obstructed or impeded.
sn.q: Slides into verse, and hitches in a rhyme.
To ease themselves . . . by hitching into another place.

sn.def: To hit the legs together in going, as horses; to interfere.

entry.def: To hitchhike; -- mostly used in the phrase to hitch a ride; as, he hitched his way home; he hitched a ride home.

entry.cs: To hitch up. To fasten up. To pull or raise with a jerk; as, a sailor hitches up his trousers. To attach, as a horse, to a vehicle; as, hitch up the gray mare. Colloq
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hitched; p. pr. & vb. n. Hitching

sn.def: To hook; to catch or fasten as by a hook or a knot; to make fast, unite, or yoke; as, to hitch a horse, or a halter; hitch your wagon to a star.
To move with hitches; as, he hitched his chair nearer.
A catch; anything that holds, as a hook; an impediment; an obstacle; an entanglement.
The act of catching, as on a hook, etc.
A stop or sudden halt; a stoppage; an impediment; a temporary obstruction; an obstacle; as, a hitch in one's progress or utterance; a hitch in the performance.
A sudden movement or pull; a pull up; as, the sailor gave his trousers a hitch .
A knot or noose in a rope which can be readily undone; -- intended for a temporary fastening; as, a half hitch; a clove hitch; a timber hitch, etc.
A small dislocation of a bed or vein.

entry.def: See Hatchel.
To travel by getting free rides from passing vehicles; as, to hitchhike across the country.
a person who travels by getting free rides from passing vehicles; one who hitchhikes.

entry.ety: AS. hȳð. Cf. Hide to conceal
entry.def: A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe, now Lambeth .

entry.cs: Hither and thither to and fro; backward and forward; in various directions. “Victory is like a traveller, and goeth hither and thither.” Knolles.
entry.ety: OE. hider, AS. hider; akin to Icel. hēðra, Dan. hid, Sw. hit, Goth. hidrē; cf. L. citra on this side, or E. here he. √183. Cf. He

sn.def: To this place; -- used with verbs signifying motion, and implying motion toward the speaker; correlate of hence and thither; as, to come or bring hither .
To this point, source, conclusion, design, etc.; -- in a sense not physical.

Applied to time: On the hither side of, younger than; of fewer years than.
sn.q: And on the hither side, or so she looked, Of twenty summers.
To the present generation, that is to say, the people a few years on the hither and thither side of thirty, the name of Charles Darwin stands alongside of those of Isaac Newton and Michael Faraday.

entry.def: Nearest on this side.

sn.def: To this place; to a prescribed limit.

entry.def: To get along well together; to be compatible; to work well together; -- of people in interactive situations; as, the new chemist hit it off immediately with his supervisor.
of or pertaining to Adolf Hitler; resembling the policies of Hitler.

performed without care or close attention; slipshod; careless; -- of the manner of performing a task. Opposite of careful conscientious or methodical.

cs.cd: A baseball player who gets many extra-base hits.
A person who is very important or is very effective at his profession.

sn.def: One who hits or strikes; as, a hard hitter .
The batter; as, there are two strikes on the hitter .

entry.def: The act of striking one thing against another; as, repeated hitting raised a large bruise

A member of an ancient people (or perhaps group of peoples) whose settlements extended from Armenia westward into Asia Minor and southward into Palestine. They are known to have been met along the Orontes as early as 1500 b. c., and were often at war with the Egyptians and Assyrians. Especially in the north they developed a considerable civilization, of which numerous monuments and inscriptions are extant. Authorities are not agreed as to their race. While several attempts have been made to decipher the Hittite characters, little progress has yet been made.

entries.entry: Hit"torf rays. Elec Rays (chiefly cathode rays) developed by the electric discharge in Hittorf tubes.

Hit"torf tube. Elec A highly exhausted glass tube with metallic electrodes nearly in contact so as to exhibit the insulating effects of a vacuum. It was used by the German physicist W. Hittorfb. 1824). A Crookes tube.

cs.cd: the honeybee.

sn.def: A box, basket, or other structure, for the reception and habitation of a swarm of honeybees.
The bees of one hive; a swarm of bees.

a large sandwich on a long crusty roll that is split lengthwise and filled with meats and cheese (and tomato and onion and lettuce and condiments); different names are used in different sections of the U. S., such as hero grinder, and submarine.

entry.def: A store, stock, or quantity of anything accumulated or laid up; a hidden supply; a treasure; as, a hoard of provisions; a hoard of money.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hoarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Hoarding
entry.def: To collect and lay up; to amass and deposit in secret; to store secretly, or for the sake of keeping and accumulating; as, to hoard grain.
To lay up a store or hoard, as of money.
entry.q: To hoard for those whom he did breed.

entry.def: One who hoards.

entry.ety: From OF. hourd hourt, barrier, palisade, of German or Dutch origin; cf. D. horde hurdle, fence, G. horde hürde; akin to E. hurdle. √16. See Hurdle

sn.def: A screen of boards inclosing a house and materials while builders are at work.
sn.q: Posted on every dead wall and hoarding.

sn.def: A fence, barrier, or cover, inclosing, surrounding, or concealing something.
sn.q: The whole arrangement was surrounded by a hoarding, the space within which was divided into compartments by sheets of tin.

entry.def: Moldy; musty.
The white particles formed by the congelation of dew; white frost.
entry.q: He scattereth the hoarfrost like ashes.

entry.def: Same as Horehound.
The state of being hoary.

entry.ety: OE. hors, also hos has, AS. hās; akin to D. heesch, G. heiser, Icel. hāss, Dan. hæs, Sw. hes. Cf. Prov. E. heazy

sn.def: Having a harsh, rough, grating voice or sound, as when affected with a cold; making a rough, harsh cry or sound; as, the hoarse raven.
sn.q: The hoarse resounding shore.

sn.def: Harsh; grating; discordant; -- said of any sound.

entry.def: With a harsh, grating sound or voice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hoarsened; p. pr. & vb. n. Hoarsening
entry.def: To make hoarse.
entry.q: I shall be obliged to hoarsen my voice.

entry.def: Harshness or roughness of voice or sound, due to mucus collected on the vocal cords, or to swelling or looseness of the cords.
A stone designating the bounds of an estate; a landmark.

cs.cd: an American bat (Atalapha cinerea), having the hair yellowish, or brown, tipped with white.

sn.def: White or whitish.
sn.q: Thehoarywillows.

sn.def: White or gray with age; hoar; as, hoary hairs.
sn.q: Reverence the hoary head.

entry.sn: Hence, remote in time past; as, hoary antiquity.

sn.def: Moldy; mossy; musty.
Of a pale silvery gray.
Covered with short, dense, grayish white hairs; canescent.

entry.def: Same as Hoazin.

entry.ety: Prob. contr. fr. hocus, in hocus-pocus
entry.def: A deception for mockery or mischief; a deceptive trick or story; a practical joke.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hoaxed; p. pr. & vb. n. Hoaxing
entry.def: To deceive by a story or a trick, for sport or mischief; to impose upon sportively.
One who hoaxes.
A remarkable South American bird (Opisthocomus cristatus); the crested touraco. By some zoölogists it is made the type of a distinct order (Opisthocomi).

entry.ety: Prob. akin to hump. Cf. Hub.

sn.def: The hub of a wheel. See Hub.
The flat projection or iron shelf at the side of a fire grate, where things are put to be kept warm.
A threaded and fluted hardened steel cutter, resembling a tap, used in a lathe for forming the teeth of screw chasers, worm wheels, etc.
A peg, pin, or mark used as a target in some games, as an iron pin in quoits; also, a game in which such a target is used.

entry.ety: Orig. an abbrev. of Robin Robert; Robin Goodfellow a celebrated fairy, or domestic spirit. Cf. Hobgoblin, and see Robin

sn.def: A fairy; a sprite; an elf.
sn.q: From elves, hobs, and fairies, . . . Defend us, good Heaven !

sn.def: A countryman; a rustic; a clown.

entry.def: The male ferret.
Same as Hobnob.

The philosophical system of Thomas Hobbes , an English materialist (1588-1679); esp., his political theory that the most perfect form of civil government is an absolute monarchy with despotic control over everything relating to law, morals, and religion.
One who accepts the doctrines of Thomas Hobbes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hobbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Hobbling
entry.ety: OE. hobelen hoblen, freq. of hoppen to hop; akin to D. hobbelen hoblen hoppeln. See Hop to jump, and cf. Hopple

sn.def: To walk lame, bearing chiefly on one leg; to walk with a hitch or hop, or with crutches.
sn.q: The friar was hobbling the same way too.

sn.def: To move roughly or irregularly; -- said of style in writing.
sn.q: The hobbling versification, the mean diction.

sn.def: To fetter by tying the legs; to hopple; to clog.
sn.q: Theyhobbledtheir horses.

sn.def: To perplex; to embarrass.
An unequal gait; a limp; a halt; as, he has a hobble in his gait.
Same as Hopple.
Difficulty; perplexity; embarrassment.

entry.def: A low bush (Viburnum lantanoides) having long, straggling branches and handsome flowers. It is found in the Northern United States. Called also shinhopple.

entry.ety: Cf. Prob. E. hobbledygee with a limping movement; also F. hobereau, a country squire, E. hobby, and OF. hoi to-day; perh. the orig. sense was, an upstart of to-day
entry.def: A youth between boy and man; an awkward, gawky young fellow .
entry.q: All the men, boys, and hobbledehoys attached to the farm.

entry.def: One who hobbles.

entry.ety: OE. also hobeler, OF. hobelier, LL. hobellarius. See Hobby a horse
entry.def: One who by his tenure was to maintain a horse for military service; a kind of light horseman in the Middle Ages who was mounted on a hobby.

entries.entry:
Hob"ble skirt
Hob"ble-skirt`ed a. . A woman's skirt so scant at the bottom as to restrain freedom of movement after the fashion of a hobble.

entry.def: With a limping step.
Rough; uneven; causing one to hobble; as a hobbly road.

entries.entry: Hob"by n.; pl.Hobbies #. OE. hobi; cf. OF. hobe hobé, F. hobereau a hobby, a species of falcon. OF. hober to move, stir. Cf. Hobby a horse Zoöl A small, strong-winged European falcon (Falco subbuteo), formerly trained for hawking.

entry.ety: OE. hobin a nag, OF. hobin hobby; cf. hober to stir, move; prob. of German or Scand. origin; cf. Dan. hoppe a mare, dial. Sw. hoppa; perh. akin to E. hop to jump

sn.def: A strong, active horse, of a middle size, said to have been originally from Ireland; an ambling nag.
A stick, often with the head or figure of a horse, on which boys make believe to ride.

A subject or plan upon which one is constantly setting off; a favorite and ever-recurring theme of discourse, thought, or effort; that which occupies one's attention unduly, or to the weariness of others; a ruling passion.
sn.q: Not one of them has any hobbyhorse, to use the phrase of Sterne.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or having, a hobby or whim; eccentric; whimsical.
A frightful goblin; an imp; a bugaboo; also, a name formerly given to the household spirit, Robin Goodfellow.
A light horseman. See 2d Hobbler.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.

cs.cd: a disease in which the liver is shrunken, hard, and covered with projections like hobnails; one of the forms of cirrhosis of the liver.

sn.def: A short, sharp-pointed, large-headed nail, -- used in shoeing houses and for studding the soles of heavy shoes.
A clownish person; a rustic.

entry.def: To tread down roughly, as with hobnailed shoes.
entry.q: Your rights and charters hobnailed into slush.

entry.def: See with hobnails, as a shoe.

entry.ety: AS. habban to have + habban to have not; ne not + habban to have. See Have, and cf. Habnab

sn.def: Have or have not; -- a familiar invitation to reciprocal drinking.
At random; hit or miss. (Obs

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hornobbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Hornobbing

sn.def: To drink familiarly (with another).
To associate familiarly; to be on intimate terms; as, to hobnob with the political elite.

entry.def: Familiar, social intercourse.

entries.entry:
Ho"bo
Ho"bo*ism # n.
n.; pl. Hobos or Hoboes # . Of uncertain origin A professional tramp; one who spends his life traveling from place to place, esp. by stealing rides on trains, and begging for a living. U. S tramp, bum.

entry.def: See Hobnob.
A hautboy or oboe.

entries.entry: Hob"son's choice" ☞ It is said to have had its origin in the name of one Hobson, at Cambridge, England, who let horses, and required every customer to take in his turn the horse which stood next the stable door.. A choice without an alternative; the thing offered or nothing.

entry.def: The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. See Curassow.
Hotchpot.

entry.ety: So called from Hochheim, in Germany
entry.def: A Rhenish wine, of a light yellow color, either sparkling or still. The name is also given indiscriminately to all Rhenish wines.

entry.ety: AS. h�h the heel; prob. akin to Icel. hāsinn hock sinew, Dan. hasc, G. hechse hächse, LG. hacke, D. hak; also to L. coxa hip (cf. Cuisses), Skr. kaksha armpit. √12. Cf. Heel

sd.def: The joint in the hind limb of quadrupeds between the leg and shank, or tibia and tarsus, and corresponding to the ankle in man.
A piece cut by butchers, esp. in pork, from either the front or hind leg, just above the foot.

sn.def: The popliteal space; the ham.
To disable by cutting the tendons of the hock; to hamstring; to hough.
To pawn; as, to hock one's jewelry.
The state of having been pawned; usually preceded by in; as, all her jewelry is in hock .
The state of being in debt; as, it took him two years to get out of hock .

entry.def: A Rhenish wine.
A holiday commemorating the expulsion of the Danes, formerly observed on the second Tuesday after Easter; -- called also hocktide.

sn.def: A game in which two parties of players, armed with sticks curved or hooked at the end, attempt to drive any small object (as a ball or a bit of wood) toward opposite goals.
The stick used by the players.

entry.def: The mallow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hockled; p. pr. & vb. n. Hockling

sn.def: To hamstring; to hock; to hough.
To mow, as stubble.
To deceive or cheat.
To adulterate; to drug; as, liquor is said to be hocused for the purpose of stupefying the drinker.
To stupefy with drugged liquor.
One who cheats or deceives.
Drugged liquor.

entry.ety: Prob. invented by jugglers in imitation of Latin. Cf. Hoax Hocus

sn.def: A term used by magicians or conjurers in pretended incantations.
A juggler or trickster.
A magician's trick; a cheat; nonsense.
Obfuscating talk or elaborate but meaningless activity intended to hide a deception or to obscure what is actually happening; verbal misrepresentation intended to take advantage of you in some way.
sn.syn: trickery, slickness, hanky panky, jiggery-pokery, skulduggery, skullduggery.

entry.def: To cheat.

entry.ety: Prov. E. for holdi. e., that which holds. See Hold

sn.def: A kind of wooden tray with a handle, having V-shaped trough, made of wood or metal, attached to a long handle and usually carried over the shoulder; it is a tool used by construction workers for carrying bricks or mortar.
A utensil for holding coal; a coal scuttle.

entry.def: A construction worker whose main function is to carry construction materials in a hod{1}.

entry.ety: Perh. akin to E. hoiden rustic, clownish
entry.def: Applied to coarse cloth made of undyed wool, formerly worn by Scotch peasants.
See Dun crow, under Dun a.

entry.ety: Prob. E. also hoddypeke hoddypoule hoddymandoddy
entry.def: An awkward or foolish person.
A mixed mass; a medley. See Hotchpot.

entries.entry: Hodg`kin's dis*ease". Med A morbid condition characterized by progressive anæmia and enlargement of the lymphatic glands; -- first described by Dr. Hodgkin, an English physician.

entry.def: Of this day; belonging to the present day.

entries.entry: Hod"man n.; pl.Hodmen�). A man who carries a hod; a mason's tender.

entry.def: See Dodman.

A curve described by the moving extremity of a line the other end of which is fixed, this line being constantly parallel to the direction of motion of, and having its length constantly proportional to the velocity of, a point moving in any path; -used in investigations respecting central forces.

entry.ety: Gr. "odo`metron "odo`metros, an instrument for measuring distance; "odo`s way, path, road + me`tron measure: cf. F. odométre hodométre. See also odometer
entry.def: A device for measuring the length of a path, consisting of a wheel of known circumference attached to a rod held in the hand, and pushed along a surface, which is usually the ground or a floor. The number of times the wheel makes a complete circle multiplied by the circumference is a measure of the length of the path traversed. It may be used to measure distances on curved as well as straight paths. A variant which registers the miles and rods traversed is sometimes used by surveyors.

sn.def: A blind god; misled by Loki he kills Balder by throwing a bough of mistletoe.

cs.cd: one having the blade set for use in the manner of a spade.
a kind of cultivator.

entry.ety: OF. hoe, F. houe; of German origin, cf. OHG. houwa howa, G. haue, fr. OHG. houwan to hew. See Hew to cut

sn.def: A tool chiefly for digging up weeds, and arranging the earth about plants in fields and gardens. It is made of a flat blade of iron or steel having an eye or tang by which it is attached to a wooden handle at an acute angle.
The horned or piked dogfish. See Dogfish.

cs.cd: to do one's share of a job.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hoed; p. pr. & vb. n. Hoeing
entry.def: To cut, dig, scrape, turn, arrange, or clean, with a hoe; as, to hoe the earth in a garden; also, to clear from weeds, or to loosen or arrange the earth about, with a hoe; as, to hoe corn.
To use a hoe; to labor with a hoe.
A cake of Indian meal, water, and salt, baked before the fire or in the ashes; -- so called because often cooked on a hoe.

entry.ety: A local Orkney name; cf. Icel. hār
entry.def: The basking or liver shark; -- called also homer. See Liver shark, under Liver.

entry.ety: AS. hogful hohful, fr. hogu care, anxiety
entry.def: Careful; wary.

entry.note: ☞ The domestic hogs of Siam, China, and parts of Southern Europe, are thought to have been derived from Sus Indicus.
entry.cs: Bush hog Ground hog, etc.. See under Bush Ground, etc. Hog caterpillar Zoöl the larva of the green grapevine sphinx; -- so called because the head and first three segments are much smaller than those behind them, so as to make a resemblance to a hog's snout. See Hawk moth. Hog cholera an epidemic contagious fever of swine, attended by liquid, fetid, diarrhea, and by the appearance on the skin and mucous membrane of spots and patches of a scarlet, purple, or black color. It is fatal in from one to six days, or ends in a slow, uncertain recovery. Law (Farmer's Veter. Adviser Hog deer Zoöl the axis deer. Hog gum Bot West Indian tree (Symphonia globulifera), yielding an aromatic gum. Hog of wool the trade name for the fleece or wool of sheep of the second year. Hog peanut Bot a kind of earth pea. Hog plum Bot a tropical tree, of the genus Spondias Spondias lutea), with fruit somewhat resembling plums, but chiefly eaten by hogs. It is found in the West Indies. Hog's bean Bot the plant henbane. Hog's bread.Bot See Sow bread. Hog's fennel. Bot See under Fennel. Mexican hog Zoöl the peccary. Water hog. Zoöl See Capybara.
entry.ety: Prob. akin to E. hack to cut, and meaning orig., a castrated boar; cf. also W. hwch swine, sow, Armor. houc'h hoc'h. Cf. Haggis Hogget, and Hoggerel

sn.def: A quadruped of the genus Sus, and allied genera of Suidæ; esp., the domesticated varieties of Sus scrofa, kept for their fat and meat, called, respectively, lard and pork; swine; porker; specifically, a castrated boar; a barrow.
A mean, filthy, or gluttonous fellow.
A young sheep that has not been shorn.
A rough, flat scrubbing broom for scrubbing a ship's bottom under water.
A device for mixing and stirring the pulp of which paper is made.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hogged; p. pr. & vb. n. Hogging

sn.def: To cut short like bristles; as, to hog the mane of a horse.
To scrub with a hog, or scrubbing broom.

entry.def: To become bent upward in the middle, like a hog's back; -- said of a ship broken or strained so as to have this form.
An earth-covered Navajo lodge; it is traditionally built with the entrance facing east.

sn.def: An upward curve or very obtuse angle in the upper surface of any member, as of a timber laid horizontally; -- the opposite of camber.
See Hogframe.
A ridge formed by tilted strata; hence, any ridge with a sharp summit, and steeply sloping sides.

entry.def: A chain or tie rod, in a boat or barge, to prevent the vessel from hogging.
An American sole (Achirus lineatus syn. Achirus achirus), related to the European sole, but of no market value.
A shed for swine; a sty.
A large West Indian and Florida food fish (Lachnolæmus).
The pigfish or sailor's choice.
An American fresh-water fish; the log perch.
A large, red, spiny-headed, European marine fish (Scorpæna scrofa).

A trussed frame extending fore and aft, usually above deck, and intended to increase the longitudinal strength and stiffness. Used chiefly in American river and lake steamers. Called also hogging frame, and hogback.
Broken or strained so as to have an upward curve between the ends. See Hog v. i.
A stocking without a foot, worn by coal miners at work.

entry.ety: From the same source as hog; prob. orig., a sheep clipped the first year. See Hog
entry.def:
A sheep of the second year. hogrel
Ash.
The upper terminal pipe of a mining pump.
The top pump in the pit.
Hoggish character or manners; selfishness; greed; beastliness.
entry.q: Crime and shame And all their hoggery.

sn.def: A young boar of the second year.
A sheep or colt alter it has passed its first year.

entry.cs: Hogging frame. See Hogframe.
entry.def: Drooping at the ends; arching;-in distinction from sagging.
Swinish; gluttonous; filthy; selfish.
entry.q: Is not a hoggish life the height of some men's wishes?

entry.ety: Icel. haugr hill, mound; akin to E. high. See High
entry.def: A hill; a cliff.
A swineherd.

The old name, in Scotland, for the last day of the year, on which children go about singing, and receive a dole of bread or cakes; also, the entertainment given on that day to a visitor, or the gift given to an applicant.

entries.entry: Hog"nose`snake". Zoöl A harmless North American snake of the genus Heterodon, esp. Heterodon platyrhynos; -- called also puffing adder blowing adder, and sand viper.
Hog"nut` n. Bot The pignut. See Hickory. In England, the Bunium flexuosum, a tuberous plant.

entry.def: High flavor; strong scent.
A pen or sty for hogs.
A civil officer charged with the duty of impounding hogs running at large.
One who puts rings into the snouts of hogs.
A hogback.
A distance line drawn across the rink or course between the middle line and the tee.

entry.note: ☞ The London hogshead of beer was 54 beer gallons, the London hogshead of ale was 48 ale gallons. Elsewhere in England the ale and beer hogsheads held 51 gallons. These measures are no longer in use, except for cider.
entry.ety: D. okshoofd; akin to Sw. oxhufvud, Dan. oxehoved, G. oxhoft; apparently meaning orig., ox head, but it is not known why this name was given. Cf. Ox Head

sn.def: An English measure of capacity, containing 63 wine gallons, or about 521/2 imperial gallons; a half pipe.
A large cask or barrel, of indefinite contents; esp. one containing from 100 to 140 gallons.

entry.def: Leather tanned from a hog's skin. Also used adjectively.

entries.entry: Hog"sty` n.; pl.Hogsties. A pen, house, or inclosure, for hogs.

sn.def: Swill.
Meaningless talk; nonsense; balderdash; bunk; -- also used as an interjection, expressing scornful disbelief.

entry.def: A common weed (Ambrosia artemisiæge). See Ambrosia, 3.
In England, the Heracleum Sphondylium.

entry.ety: OE. hoydon a lout, rustic, OD. heyden a heathen, gypsy, vagabond, D. heiden, fr. OD. heyde heath, D. heide. See Heathen Heath

sn.def: A rude, clownish youth.
A rude, bold girl; a romp.

entry.def: Rustic; rude; bold.
To romp rudely or indecently.
State of being a hoiden.
Like, or appropriate to, a hoiden.
To hoist.
entry.q: They . . . hoised up the mainsail to the wind.

cs.cd: a steam engine for operating a hoist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Hoisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Hoisting
entry.ety: OE. hoise hyse, OD. hyssen, D. hijshen; akin to LG. hissen, Dan. hisse, Sw. hissa
entry.def: To raise; to lift; to elevate; esp., to raise or lift to a desired elevation, by means of tackle, as a sail, a flag, a heavy package or weight.
entry.q: They land my goods, and hoist my flying sails.
Hoisting him into his father's throne.

cs.cd: a drawbridge that is lifted instead of being swung or drawn aside.

sn.def: That by which anything is hoisted; the apparatus for lifting goods.
The act of hoisting; a lift.

sd.def: The perpendicular height of a flag, as opposed to the fly, or horizontal length when flying from a staff.
The height of a fore-and-aft sail next the mast or stay.

entry.def: Hoisted.
entry.q: 'T is the sport to have the enginerHoist with his own petar.

entry.def: A mechanical lift. See Elevator.
An opening for the hoist, or elevator, in the floor of a wareroom.

entry.ety: Gf. W. hoetian to dally, dandle
entry.def: To leap; to caper; to romp noisily.

Thoughtless; giddy; flighty; also, haughty; patronizing; as, to be in hoity-toity spirits, or to assume hoity-toity airs; used also as an exclamation, denoting surprise or disapprobation, with some degree of contempt.
entry.q: Hoity-toity! What have I to do with dreams?

entry.def: Same as Hockday.
Scorn; derision; abusive talk.
The northernmost of the main islands of Japan. Together with the islands of Honshu, Kyushu and Shikoku it forms the bulk of the land area of Japan.
Whole.

entries.entry:
Hol"arc*tic a.
Holo- + arctic
Of or pert. to the arctic regions collectively; specif. Zoögeography designating a realm or region including the northern parts of the Old and the New World. It comprises the Palearctic and Nearctic regions or subregions.

entry.def: Having a single series of large scutes on the posterior side of the tarsus; -- said of certain birds.

entry.ety: Gr. 'olka`s -a`dos, a ship which is towed, a ship of burden, fr. 'e`lkein to draw. Gf. Hulk
entry.def: A large ship of burden, in ancient Greece.

entry.ety: D. hol hole, hollow. See Hole
entry.def: The whole interior portion of a vessel below the lower deck, in which the cargo is stowed.

entry.cs: To hold a wager to lay or hazard a wager. Swift. To hold forth v. t. to offer; to exhibit; to propose; to put forward. “The propositions which books hold forth and pretend to teach.” Locke. v. i. To talk at length; to harangue. To held in to restrain; to curd. To hold in hand to toy with; to keep in expectation; to have in one's power. Obs O, fie! to receive favors, return falsehoods, And hold a lady in hand. Beaw. & Fl. To hold in play to keep under control; to dally with. Macaulay. To hold off to keep at a distance. To hold on to hold in being, continuance or position; as, to hold a rider on. To hold one's day to keep one's appointment. Obs Chaucer. To hold one's own. To keep good one's present condition absolutely or relatively; not to fall off, or to lose ground; as, a ship holds her own when she does not lose ground in a race or chase; a man holds his own when he does not lose strength or weight. To hold one's peace to keep silence.- To hold out. To extend; to offer. “Fortune holds out these to you as rewards.” B. Jonson. To continue to do or to suffer; to endure. “He can not long hold out these pangs.” Shak. To hold up. To raise; to lift; as, hold up your head. To support; to sustain. “He holds himself up in virtue.”Sir P. Sidney. To exhibit; to display; as, he was held up as an example. To rein in; to check; to halt; as, hold up your horses. to rob, usually at gunpoint; -- often with the demand to “hold up” the hands. To delay. To hold water. Literally, to retain water without leaking; hence (Fig.), to be whole, sound, consistent, without gaps or holes; -- commonly used in a negative sense; as, his statements will not hold water. Colloq Naut To hold the oars steady in the water, thus checking the headway of a boat.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Held; p. pr. & vb. n. Holding. Holden p. p., is obs. in elegant writing, though still used in legal language
entry.ety: OE. haldan, D. houden, OHG. hoten, Icel. halda, Dan. holde, Sw. hålla Goth. haldan to feed, tend (the cattle); of unknown origin. Gf. Avast Halt Hod

sn.def: To cause to remain in a given situation, position, or relation, within certain limits, or the like; to prevent from falling or escaping; to sustain; to restrain; to keep in the grasp; to retain.
sn.q: The loops held one curtain to another.
Thy right hand shall hold me.
They all hold swords, being expert in war.
In vain he seeks, that having can not hold.
France, thou mayst hold a serpent by the tongue, . . . A fasting tiger safer by the tooth, Than keep in peace that hand which thou dost hold.

sn.def: To retain in one's keeping; to maintain possession of, or authority over; not to give up or relinquish; to keep; to defend.
sn.q: We mean to hold what anciently we claim Of deity or empire.

sn.def: To have; to possess; to be in possession of; to occupy; to derive title to; as, to hold office.
sn.q: This noble merchant held a noble house.
Of him to hold his seigniory for a yearly tribute.
And now the strand, and now the plain, they held.

sn.def: To impose restraint upon; to limit in motion or action; to bind legally or morally; to confine; to restrain.
sn.q: We can not hold mortality's strong hand.
Death! what do'st? O, hold thy blow.
He had not sufficient judgment and self-command to hold his tongue.

sn.def: To maintain in being or action; to carry on; to prosecute, as a course of conduct or an argument; to continue; to sustain.
sn.q: Hold not thy peace, and be not still.
Seedtime and harvest, heat and hoary frost, Shall hold their course.

sn.def: To prosecute, have, take, or join in, as something which is the result of united action; as to, hold a meeting, a festival, a session, etc.; hence, to direct and bring about officially; to conduct or preside at; as, the general held a council of war; a judge holds a court; a clergyman holds a service.
sn.q: I would hold more talk with thee.

sn.def: To receive and retain; to contain as a vessel; as, this pail holds milk; hence, to be able to receive and retain; to have capacity or containing power for.
sn.q: Broken cisterns that can hold no water.
One sees more devils than vast hell can hold.

sn.def: To accept, as an opinion; to be the adherent of, openly or privately; to persist in, as a purpose; to maintain; to sustain.
sn.q: Stand fast and hold the traditions which ye have been taught.
But still he held his purpose to depart.

sn.def: To consider; to regard; to esteem; to account; to think; to judge.
sn.q: I hold him but a fool.
I shall never hold that man my friend.
The Lord will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.

sn.def: To bear, carry, or manage; as he holds himself erect; he holds his head high.
sn.q: Let him hold his fingers thus.

entry.cs:
Hold on! Hold up! wait; stop; forbear. Collog To hold forth
to speak in public; to harangue; to preach. L'Estrange. To hold in to restrain one's self; as, he wanted to laugh and could hardly hold in. To hold off to keep at a distance. To hold on to keep fast hold; to continue; to go on. “The trade held on for many years,” Swift. To hold out to last; to endure; to continue; to maintain one's self; not to yield or give way. To hold over to remain in office, possession, etc., beyond a certain date.
To hold toorTo hold with
to take sides with, as a person or opinion. To hold together to be joined; not to separate; to remain in union. Dryden. Locke. To hold up. To support one's self; to remain unbent or unbroken; as, to hold up under misfortunes. To cease raining; to cease to stop; as, it holds up. Hudibras. To keep up; not to fall behind; not to lose ground. Collier.
entry.def: In general, to keep one's self in a given position or condition; to remain fixed. Hence:

sn.def: Not to move; to halt; to stop; -- mostly in the imperative.
sn.q: And damned be him that first cries, “Hold, enough!”

sn.def: Not to give way; not to part or become separated; to remain unbroken or unsubdued.
sn.q: Our force by land hath nobly held.

sn.def: Not to fail or be found wanting; to continue; to last; to endure a test or trial; to abide; to persist.
sn.q: While our obedience holds.
The rule holds in land as all other commodities.

sn.def: Not to fall away, desert, or prove recreant; to remain attached; to cleave; -- often with with to, or for.
sn.q: He will hold to the one and despise the other.

sn.def: To restrain one's self; to refrain.
sn.q: His dauntless heart would fain have held From weeping, but his eyes rebelled.

sn.def: To derive right or title; -- generally with of.
sn.q: My crown is absolute, and holds of none.
His imagination holds immediately from nature.

sn.def: The act of holding, as in or with the hands or arms; the manner of holding, whether firm or loose; seizure; grasp; clasp; grip; possession; -- often used with the verbs take and lay.
sn.q: Ne have I not twelve pence within mine hold.
Thou should'st lay hold upon him.
My soul took hold on thee.
Take fast hold of instruction.

sn.def: The authority or ground to take or keep; claim.
sn.q: The law hath yet another hold on you.

sn.def: Binding power and influence.
sn.q: Fear . . . by which God and his laws take the surest hold of.

sn.def: Something that may be grasped; means of support.
sn.q: If a man be upon an high place without rails or good hold, he is ready to fall.

sn.def: A place of confinement; a prison; confinement; custody; guard.
sn.q: They . . . put them in hold unto the next day.
King Richard, he is in the mighty hold Of Bolingbroke.

sn.def: A place of security; a fortified place; a fort; a castle; -- often called a stronghold.
sn.q: New comers in an ancient hold

sn.def: A character [thus �] placed over or under a note or rest, and indicating that it is to be prolonged; -- called also pause, and corona.

entry.def: a capacious bag or basket.

sn.def: Check; hindrance; restraint; obstacle.
sn.q: The only holdback is the affection . . . that we bear to our wealth.

sn.def: The projection or loop on the thill of a vehicle. to which a strap of the harness is attached, to hold back a carriage when going down hill, or in backing; also, the strap or part of the harness so used.

entry.def: One who is employed in the hold of a vessel.

entry.note: ☞ Holder is much used as the second part of a compound; as, shareholder, officeholder, stockholder,etc.

sn.def: One who, or that which, holds.
One who holds land, etc., under another; a tenant.
The payee of a bill of exchange or a promissory note, or the one who owns or holds it.

entry.def: One who speaks in public; an haranguer; a preacher. See hold forth under hold.

sn.def: Something used to secure and hold in place something else, as a long flat-headed nail, a catch a hook, a clinch, a clamp, etc.; hence, a support.
sn.q: Hisholdfastwas gone.

sn.def: A conical or branching body, by which a seaweed is attached to its support, and differing from a root in that it is not specially absorbent of moisture.

cs.cd: a note sustained in one part, while the other parts move.

sn.def: The act or state of sustaining, grasping, or retaining.
A tenure; a farm or other estate held of another.
That which holds, binds, or influences.
The burden or chorus of a song.

entry.def: A company that controls other independently incorporated companies by ownership of most or all of their stock, but does not directly control the daily operations of those companies.

sn.def: a negotiator who hopes to gain concessions by refusing to come to terms after most other participants have signed an agreement; as, their star pitcher was a holdout for six weeks.
a refusal by a negotiator to come to terms in the hope of obtaining a better deal.
the act of hiding playing cards in a gambling game so they are available for personal use later.

entry.def: Any person or thing remaining from a previous period of use, tenure, etc;
an official who remains in office after his term.

sn.def: a robbery, usually at gunpoint.
a delay.
sn.q: What's theholdup?

sn.def: highway robbery2}.
To rob, usually at gunpoint or knifepoint.
To delay; as, bad weather held up the satellite launch for two days.

entry.def: Whole.

entry.cs: Hole and corner clandestine, underhand. Colloq “The wretched trickery of hole and corner buffery.” Dickens. Hole board Fancy Weaving a board having holes through which cords pass which lift certain warp threads; -- called also compass board.
entry.ety: OE. hol hole, AS. hol, hole, cavern, from hol, a., hollow; akin to D. hol, OHG. hol, G. hohl, Dan. huul hollow, hul hole, Sw. hål, Icel. hola; prob. from the root of AS. helan to conceal. See Hele Hell, and cf. Hold of a ship

sn.def: A hollow place or cavity; an excavation; a pit; an opening in or through a solid body, a fabric, etc.; a perforation; a rent; a fissure.
sn.q: The holes where eyes should be.
The blind walls Were full of chinks and holes.
The priest took a chest, and bored a hole in the lid.

sn.def: An excavation in the ground, made by an animal to live in, or a natural cavity inhabited by an animal; hence, a low, narrow, or dark lodging or place; a mean habitation.
sn.q: The foxes have holes, . . . but the Son of man hath not where to lay his head.

sd.def: A small cavity used in some games, usually one into which a marble or ball is to be played or driven; hence, a score made by playing a marble or ball into such a hole, as in golf.
At Eton College, England, that part of the floor of the court between the step and the pepperbox.
sd.syn: Hollow; concavity; aperture; rent; fissure; crevice; orifice; interstice; perforation; excavation; pit; cave; den; cell.

sn.def: To cut, dig, or bore a hole or holes in; as, to hole a post for the insertion of rails or bars.
To drive into a hole, as an animal, or a billiard ball.

entry.def: To go or get into a hole.

entries.entry: Hole in the air. Aëronautics same as Air hole, above; an air pocket.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a holethnos or parent race.

entry.def: A parent stock or race of people, not yet divided into separate branches or tribes.
having pores or holes.
See Halibut.
See Halidom.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States legal holidays, so called, are determined by law, commonly by the statutes of the several States. The holidays most generally observed are: the 22d day of February (Washington's birthday), the 30th day of May (Memorial day), the 4th day of July (Independence day), the 25th day of December (Christmas day). In most of the States the 1st day of January is a holiday. When any of these days falls on Sunday, usually the Monday following is observed as the holiday. In many of the States a day in the spring (as Good Friday, or the first Thursday in April), and a day in the fall (as the last Thursday in November) are now regularly appointed by Executive proclamation to be observed, the former as a day of fasting and prayer, the latter as a day of thanksgiving and are kept as holidays. In England, the days of the greater church feasts (designated in the calendar by a red letter, and commonly called red-letter days) are observed as general holidays. Bank holidays are those on which, by act of Parliament, banks may suspend business. Although Sunday is a holiday in the sense of a day when business is legally suspended, it is not usually included in the general term, the phrase “Sundays and holidays” being more common.

cs.cd: any fixed or usual period for relaxation or festivity; especially, Christmas and New Year's day with the intervening time.

sn.def: A consecrated day; religious anniversary; a day set apart in honor of some person, or in commemoration of some event. See Holyday.
A day of exemption from labor; a day of amusement and gayety; a festival day.
sn.q: And young and old come forth to play On a sunshine holiday.

sn.def: A day fixed by law for suspension of business; a legal holiday.
Of or pertaining to a festival; cheerful; joyous; gay.
Occurring rarely; adapted for a special occasion.
sn.q: Courage is but a holiday kind of virtue, to be seldom exercised.

entry.def: being excessively or hypocritically pious while condemning others as being less virtuous than oneself.
entry.syn: pietistic, pietistical, pharisaic, pharisaical, sanctimonious, self-righteous.

sn.def: Piously; with sanctity; in a holy manner.
Sacredly; inviolably.

cs.cd: a title of the pope; -- formerly given also to Greek bishops and Greek emperors.

sn.def: The state or quality of being holy; perfect moral integrity or purity; freedom from sin; sanctity; innocence.
sn.q: Who is like thee, glorious in holiness!

sn.def: The state of being hallowed, or consecrated to God or to his worship; sacredness.
sn.q: Israel was holiness unto the Lord.
sn.syn: Piety; devotion; godliness; sanctity; sacredness; righteousness.

entry.def: See Hollo v. i.

entry.def: A sauce consisting essentially of a seasoned emulsion of butter and yolk of eggs with a little lemon juice or vinegar.

A very hard, semi-glazed, green or dark brown brick, which will not absorb water; -- called also, Dutch clinker.

entry.def: Ho there; stop; attend; hence, a loud cry or a call to attract attention; a halloo.
entry.q: And every day, for food or play, Came to the mariner's hollo.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Holloed; p. pr. & vb. n. Holloing
entry.ety: See Hollo interj., and cf. Halloo
entry.def: To call out or exclaim; to halloo.
Same as Hollo.

entry.cs: Hollow newel Arch an opening in the center of a winding staircase in place of a newel post, the stairs being supported by the wall; an open newel; also, the stringpiece or rail winding around the well of such a staircase. Hollow quoin Engin a pier of stone or brick made behind the lock gates of a canal, and containing a hollow or recess to receive the ends of the gates. Hollow root. Bot See Moschatel. Hollow square. See Square. Hollow ware hollow vessels; -- a trade name for cast-iron kitchen utensils, earthenware, etc.
entry.ety: OE. holow holgh holf, AS. holh a hollow, hole. Cf. Hole

sn.def: Having an empty space or cavity, natural or artificial, within a solid substance; not solid; excavated in the interior; as, a hollow tree; a hollow sphere.
sn.q: Hollow with boards shalt thou make it.

sn.def: Depressed; concave; gaunt; sunken.
sn.q: With hollow eye and wrinkled brow.

sn.def: Reverberated from a cavity, or resembling such a sound; deep; muffled; as, a hollow roar.
Not sincere or faithful; false; deceitful; not sound; as, a hollow heart; a hollow friend.
sn.syn: - Concave; sunken; low; vacant; empty; void; false; faithless; deceitful; treacherous.

sn.def: A cavity, natural or artificial; an unfilled space within anything; a hole, a cavern; an excavation; as the hollow of the hand or of a tree.
A low spot surrounded by elevations; a depressed part of a surface; a concavity; a channel.
sn.q: Forests grew Upon the barren hollows.
I hate the dreadful hollow behind the little wood.

entry.def: Wholly.

entry.note: ☞ The holly is much used to adorn churches and houses, at Christmas time, and hence is associated with scenes of good will and rejoicing. It is an evergreen tree, and has a finegrained, heavy, white wood. Its bark is used as a febrifuge, and the berries are violently purgative and emetic. The American holly is the Ilex opaca, and is found along the coast of the United States, from Maine southward.

cs.cd: the black scrub oak. See Scrub oak.
a West Indian shrub, with showy, yellow flowers (Turnera ulmifolia).
a species of Eryngium. See Eryngium.

sn.def: A tree or shrub of the genus Ilex. The European species (Ilex Aquifolium) is best known, having glossy green leaves, with a spiny, waved edge, and bearing berries that turn red or yellow about Michaelmas.
The holm oak. See 1st Holm.

entry.note: Rose mallow is listed as a variety of Hibiscus, not Hollyhock in several Web pages. Name change???
